Location: SOUTH WEST INDIAN OCEAN 275 MILES NORTH WEST OF SAINT-DENIS, REUNION
SummaryOfEvents:
THE CAMBODIAN-FLAGGED GENERAL CARGO SHIP 'PEACE' SUSTAINED MECHANICAL FAILURE AND DRIFTED IN THE SOUTH WEST INDIAN OCEAN 275 MILES NORTH WEST OF SAINT-DENIS, REUNION IN IN LAT. 17 33S., LONG. 053 58E., AT 1539 HOURS LT ON 01/01/14.

EXACT NATURE OF PROBLEM UNKNOWN. CREW ABANDONED SHIP TO LIFERAFT 220 MILES NORTHWEST OF SAINT-DENIS IN LAT. 17 37S., LONG. 054 34E., ON 02/01/14. MT 'PATRIS' PROCEEDED TO ASSIST AND RESCUED 9 CREW AND 1 BODY FROM THE LIFERAFT. SURVIVORS TAKEN TO CAPE TOWN, SOUTH AFRICA. ABANDONED DERELICT VESSEL HAD DRIFTED 190 MILES SOUTHWEST TO LAT. 20 14S., LONG. 053 08E., BY 15/01/14.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents: At around 0830 on 29 December 2013, the Cambodia registered general cargo vessel SAE BYOL, owned by Dalian Jinyang shipping Co., Ltd., ran aground on the reef to the west of Haimao isle(AP 38°52′.2N；121°00′.8E) while on passage from Panjin，China to Nampo, DPRK in ballast. The vessel was subsequently declared a total loss without casualties, with a direct economic loss of $ 1,200,000.

SOLASStatus: GRAVITY HIGHWAY: Unknown/unspecified, Maritime Maisie: SOLAS
Location: about nine nautical miles (nms) southeast of Busan, the Republic of Korea
SummaryOfEvents: At 0206 hours on 29 December 2013, a collision occurred between the Hong Kong registered oil/chemical tanker “Maritime Maisie” and the Bahamas registered vehicles carrier “Gravity Highway” at about nine nautical miles (nms) southeast of Busan, the Republic of Korea (South Korea).

SOLASStatus: AL GHARRAFA: Unknown/unspecified, HANJIN ITALY: SOLAS
SummaryOfEvents: On 28 December 2013 the vessel HANJIN ITALY was traveling in the Singapore Strait when a tanker AL GHARRAFA collided with her starboard side at 20:25hrs (LT).  HANJIN ITALY had recently left Pasir Pajang Terminal and was headed to Shanghai when the incident occurred.

Location: OFF PORO POINT, LA UNION, PHILIPPINES
SummaryOfEvents:
STRANDED IN THE SOUTH CHINA SEA OFF PORO POINT, LA UNION, PHILIPPINES IN LAT. 16 38N., LONG. 120 17E., AT 1300 HOURS LT ON 28/12/13. DAMAGED BEYOND ECONOMICAL REPAIR AND BROKEN UP AT BUSAN, S. KOREA IN OCTOBER 2014.
NO INJURIES OR POLLUTION REPORTED. P & I CLUB SURVEYORS ATTENDED THE SCENE. 23,000 BAGS OF RICE CARGO LIGHTERED TO BARGE PRIOR TO REFLOATING ATTEMPTS. ADVERSE WEATHER CONDITIONS HAMPERED FURTHER SALVAGE OPERATIONS. REFLOATED IN SEPT 2014 AND TOWED TO BATANGAS, PHILIPPINES FOR TEMPORARY REPAIRS PRIOR TO SALE FOR DEMOLITION.

We would like to inform your esteemed Organization that a very serious marine casualty has occurred on the 26th of December 2013 on board M/V EVER URBAN IMO 9169160 under Panama Flag as per attached Marine Casualty Notification. 
Herewith we would like to inform you that "Hellenic Bureau for Marine Casualties Investigation" has initiated a formal  safety investigation for issued very serious marine accident, pursuant to Directive 2009/18/EC and IMO "Casualty Investigation Code",  as incorporated in our National legislation by Law 4033/2011 (Official Government Gazette 264 A).

A freak (abnormal) wave struck the vessel “SAFMARINE LONGA” after departing Lisbon. The anchor team were on the forecastle at the time securing both anchors - Five crewmen (all from Sri Lanka) were on the focsle deck and one inside the stores. Of the five on focsle, one was swept overboard and the remaining four, all suffered injuries. The injured four landed in Lisbon for hospitalizing on the same day and the missing person has been found as ceased. From the injured 4 there were 2 with minor injured who were discharged from hospital the next day 25th, while 2 remained hospitalized in Lisbon
Under the investigation process, Portuguese investigation body asked the cooperation of the South African Investigation Body to undergo interviews to the ship's crew
There have been full cooperation of the ship's company (based in Germany), flag State and SAMSA.

La cause de l'échouement du navire SILVER est la présence d'un haut fond, constitué par un banc de sable, dont le chenal d'accès au port de TANTAN.
Le haut fond réduit la profondeur d'eau disponible et résulte d'un défaut de dragage du chenal d'accès.

On 25 December 2013 at 16:08hrs (LT) in the Atlantic Ocean near Morocco the vessel IRENES RAINBOW lost 6 containers overboard and incurred damages to several other containers and the ship due to strong winds and seas.

We V-Ships Ship Management (India)Pte Ltd are the Technical Managers of the vessel Jindal Varad, IMO No. 9082879  - PANAMA FLAG . 

We would like to bring to your kind attention that the subject vessel is at Qinhuangdao port, China where there was a Fire in the E/Off cabin.

Location: EAST CHINA SEA 2 MILES NORTHWEST OF AMAMI ISLAND, KAGOSHIMA, JAPAN
SummaryOfEvents:
REPORTED MISSING IN THE EAST CHINA SEA 2 MILES NORTHWEST OF AMAMI ISLAND, KAGOSHIMA, JAPAN IN LAT. 28 23N., LONG. 129 18E., CIRCA 22/12/13.

COASTGUARD SHIPS AND AIRCRAFT EFFECTED EXTENSIVE SAR OPERATION BUT NO TRACE OF VESSEL OR CREW FOUND. VESSEL WAS ON DELIVERY VOYAGE FROM HIROSHIMA, JAPAN TO NEW OWNERS IN MINDANAO, PHILIPPINES WITH 6 CREW ON BOARD. ALTHOUGH CONTACT WITH THE VESSEL WAS LOST ON 22/12/13 THE COASTGUARD WAS NOT ADVISED UNTIL 01/01/14.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

Location: ATLANTIC OCEAN 125 MILES EAST OF CANSO, NS, CANADA
SummaryOfEvents:
FOUNDERED IN THE ATLANTIC OCEAN 125 MILES EAST OF CANSO, NS, CANADA IN LAT. 44 28N., LONG. 058 19W., AT 0822 HOURS UTC ON 22/12/13.
4 CREW ABANDONED VESSEL AND TOOK TO A LIFERAFT AND WERE RESCUED BY FV 'OCEAN CONCORD'. THE 4 CREW MEMBERS WERE SUBSEQUENTLY TRANSFERRED TO THE CANADIAN COASTGUARD VESSEL 'SPINDRIFT'. NO INJURIES OR POLLUTION REPORTED

At about 2048 hours of December 2013, two vessels MV Niki C (Bulk Carrier) and MT Charon (Tanker Barge) had just left Lagos for Warri and Agbara respectively. The MV Niki C while navigating, collided with the amidship port side of MT Charon, The Resultant damage caused the MT Charon to sink and loss of two crew members out of nine

The pleasure boat "Cochicho" with 7 persons on board, when in transit to Lisbon, when was approaching to the Tejo river entrance, over the "Cachopo do Sul" sandbank,  have been stroked by a wave with a height over the media and had capsized. From the accident it had resulted that 6 persons had died. It had been found that the excessive speed was the cause of the accident. It had contributed to the severity of the accident the fact that no one on board wearied life jackets and that all safety equipment was stowed inside the cabinet. It had been found that the crew onboard didn't know what was the equipment that was available on board the boat in an emergence event.

At 1840 on 20 December 2013, the 93m chemical tanker Key Bora made heavy contact with the western approach jetty at Alexandra Dock, Hull. The vessel’s CPP system had a history of responding slowly to demands for astern pitch, and did not respond in time to the pilot’s order of full astern to prevent the bow striking the quay.
The bulbous bow was holed above the waterline, there was no pollution.

On 20 December 2013, at about 0310 (UTC+8), the oil tanker Universal Prime collided with MFV Hedaiyu 204268, which was apparently engaged in fishing in position 32° 30.6’N  124° 06.6’E.  At the time of the collision, the vessel was proceeding at a speed of about 9.0 knots.  The fishing vessel was observed to be making about 2.0 knots. 

The master on board Universal Prime tried to contact the fishing vessel after the collision on VHF Channel 16 but received no response. 

There were no reported injuries as a result of the collision. 

The Maltese vessel reported damages in way of one of her bunker tanks.  As a result of the damage, a very small quantity of fuel oil spilled over the side. 

The safety investigation concluded that the immediate cause of the accident was inaccurate awareness of the developing situation on board both vessels.

On 17 December 2013, the hydraulic remote control system for the ballast valves was found malfunctioning on board the Hong Kong,  China registered bulk carrier “Sainty Vanguard” (hereinafter referred to as the Vessel). On the next day, the crew tried to repair the system by entering the Valve Box Compartments in double bottom though the No.1 to No.4 cargo holds that were loaded with cargo “Coal”.  
	On 19 December 2013, the Bosun entered alone No.7 cargo hold forward access space without the permission or knowledge of senior shipboard staffs. The Bosun lost his conscious and was found lying on the spiral ladder in No.7 cargo hold forward access space. Thereafter both the Chief Officer and the Ordinary Seaman1 (OS1) tried to rescue and entered the same space consecutively without following the enclosed space entry procedure neither. Fortunately, the Chief Officer and the OS1 were rescued by other crew and did not lose their lives throughout the incident. The Bosun was sent to hospital by helicopter. But he was certified death by the hospital on the same date. 
	Investigation into the accident revealed that cargo hold access spaces were not safe for entry when the cargo holds were loaded with hazardous cargoes. The Bosun was overcome by high concentration of carbon monoxide and oxygen depletion inside the space that was lethal to him.

At 19.15 hrs on 18 December 2013, crewman X was pulled overboard from the forward mooring area of the general cargo ship Sea Melody when his foot became caught in the bight of a mooring rope as the ship was shifting berth. Despite an extensive search by the crew, a rescue helicopter, a lifeboat, coastguards and police divers the crewman's body was not found.
GROUNDING IN LAT: 01º05.525 LONG:100º19.02E (5NM OF TELUK BAYUR) AT 10.00 LT ON 06 18/DEC/2013

On the 18th of December 2013, at about 18:50, passenger-hydrofoil "Flying Dolphin XVII" (Greek flag, registry of Piraeus 11483) grounded on the Isles of "Tselevinia". The hydrofoil was on route from the island of Hydra to the island of Poros, carrying 29 passengers. The Captain informed the Port Authority of Poros by telephone and a rescue enterprise was carried out thereafter. All the passengers were transferred to the port of Galata (right opposite to the port of Poros) by passenger launch "John-Nakis" (registry of Poros 22) and passenger vessel "Christos" (registry of Hydra 190). No injury or pollution was noted."Flying Dolphin XVII" re-floated by her own means and reached safely under the supervision of HCG Patrol Boat 607 and launch "Liakos" (registry of Poros 21) the port of Poros with one engine.The hydrofoil had suffered damage at the rudder and at both her propellers.

While the vessel was moored at the berth of Cedros Island, Mexico, the second officer was found in an unconscious state on the dolphin wharf, about 5 to 6 meters below a shore gangway.
　It was found that the trolley wire of the shore gangway had parted.
　Subsequently, he was transferred to the terminal dispensary, but was confirmed dead.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Ship remains fit to proceed

SummaryOfEvents:
The second incident onboard M.V EVER APEX   
  
On 16th December 2013 at 0700Hrs there was a second incident onboard your vessel M.V EVER APEX when my pilot Mr Peter Wong was disembarking at DG7, when he was on the last two to three steps of the ladder before landing to the pilot boat the whole pilot ladder gave way. Fortunately Pilot Peter Wong was quick enough to jump on to the waiting pilot boat landing flat on his back on the deck. He sustained cut, scratch and bruises on his right hand from falling pilot ladder which requiring him to have medical first aid in the boat.

Location: ST. LAWRENCE RIVER 2 MILES WEST OF GROS MORNE, QC, CANADA IN LAT. 49 15N
SummaryOfEvents:
BROKE FROM TOW, DRIFTED AND STRANDED IN THE ST. LAWRENCE RIVER 2 MILES WEST OF GROS MORNE, QC, CANADA IN LAT. 49 15N., LONG. 065 34W., AT 1924 HOURS LT ON 15/12/13 IN STRONG WINDS. BROKEN UP IN SITU IN AUGUST 2014.
VESSEL WAS BEING TOWED BY THE TUG 'ANDRE H' AT THE TIME OF THE INCIDENT. NO INJURIES OR POLLUTION REPORTED. FIREFIGHTERS FROM MONT-LOUIS AND LOCAL COASTGUARD ATTENDED THE SCENE.

Location: ST. LAWRENCE RIVER 2 MILES WEST OF GROS MORNE, QC, CANADA
SummaryOfEvents:
BROKE FROM TOW, DRIFTED, STRANDED AND PARTIALLY SANK IN THE ST. LAWRENCE RIVER 2 MILES WEST OF GROS MORNE, QC, CANADA IN LAT. 49 15N., LONG. 065 34W., AT 1924 HOURS LT ON 15/12/13 IN STRONG WINDS. BROKEN UP IN SITU IN AUG 2014.
SUSTAINED DAMAGE TO HULL AND TOOK WATER. VESSEL WAS BEING TOWED BY THE TUG 'ANDRE H' AT THE TIME OF THE INCIDENT. NO INJURIES OR POLLUTION REPORTED. FIREFIGHTERS FROM MONT-LOUIS AND LOCAL COASTGUARD ATTENDED THE SCENE.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents: At 1530hrs on 12 December 2013, the general cargo ship MERWEBORG, flying the flag of Curacao, collided in fog with the CAROLINE RUSS, which was laid up ahead of her at the ro-ro berth and flies the flag of Antigua & Barbuda, while mooring at Steubenhöft in Cuxhaven with the intention of collecting a technician to have the starboard radar system repaired. The MERWEBORG's starboard bow and rescue boat with davit were damaged. Moreover, the bridge wing buckled and the gantry crane was torn from its guideway. The CAROLINE RUSS had two tears on her bow above the waterline. The accident did not give rise to injuries and no pollutants escaped. The master, the chief officer, as well as the Elbe and port pilots manned the bridge of the MERWEBORG.

On 12nd December, 2013, the fishing boat SEGUNDO HERMANOS PAPIN suffered an engine stop due to the propeller blocked with a rope or a piece of net. The crewmen lost of control of the boat, and due to strong waves she stranded at rocky area. The five crew members swam to the rocks without serious consequences. The hull broken totally because of the successive batterings of the sea.

BROKE MOORINGS, STRUCK THE QUAY, CAPSIZED AND PARTIALLY SANK AT RHODES, GREECE AT 1215 HOURS LT ON 11/12/13 IN HEAVY WEATHER.
ALL 4 CREW EVACUATED SAFELY. NO INJURIES OR POLLUTION REPORTED. PORT AUTHORITY WORKERS AND CREW FROM NEARBY MV 'PREVELIS' ATTEMPTED TO REATTACH MOORING LINES BUT THE VESSEL WAS REPEATEDLY THROWN AGAINST THE QUAY AND SUSTAINED SERIOUS DAMAGE. NOW LYING ON PORT SIDE PARTIALLY SUBMERGED BY QUAY.

Location: NANKEIPINPARAM REEF 6 MILES NORTHEAST OF KOLONIA, POHNPEI, MICRONESIA
SummaryOfEvents:
STRANDED ON THE NANKEIPINPARAM REEF 6 MILES NORTHEAST OF KOLONIA, POHNPEI, MICRONESIA IN LAT. 07 03N., LONG. 158 14E., AT 0520 HOURS LT ON 11/12/13. WRECK ABANDONED IN SITU.
NO INJURIES REPORTED. REFLOATING ATTEMPTS WITH ASSISTANCE FROM SEVERAL UNKNOWN VESSELS UNSUCCESSFUL. SUSTAINED DAMAGE TO HULL AND LEAKAGE OF BUNKER FUEL INTO SEA REPORTED ON 21/01/14. CREW REMAINED ON BOARD AND WERE SUPPLIED WITH FRESH PROVISIONS BY LOCAL AUTHORITIES. SOME BUNKER FUEL REMOVED BY LOCAL SALVORS IN FEB 2014.

SOLASStatus: DARYA GAYATRI: Unknown/unspecified, PAULA C: Unknown/unspecified
Location: South-west lane of Dover Strait TSS
SummaryOfEvents: While underway in the south-west traffic lane of the Dover Strait TSS, the general cargo vessel altered her course to avoid a fishing vessel that its officer of the watch had assessed as a crossing vessel. When the OOW saw that the fishing vessel had also taken avoiding action, he again altered the vessels course to take a full turn out. In doing so, the general cargo vessel rounded towards a bulk carrier which was overtaking it on its starboard side. despite the bulk carriers OOW taking avoiding action, the port anchor and bow of the bulk carrier collided with the port bridgewing and port aft hull of the general cargo vessel. Both vessels were damaged in the collision but there were no injuries or pollution.

On the 11th of December, about 8:50, the fishing vessel VILA DE CARIO capsized near the Picn beach (La Corua). The fishing vessel sank by the pounding waves. There were signs of pollution due to the wreck and the oil spill, about 150 liters of diesel. The only crewman got reach land by one's own means without get injured.
Consequences1: Pollution,Ship rendered unfit to proceed,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents: Two stevedores died due to injuries sustained while lashing rolls of steel.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Ship remains fit to proceed

SummaryOfEvents: On arrival Hareid on a regular run in it's route, the HSC Tidefjord, a carboncomposite catamaran, experienced a malfunction in the maneuversystem. When the maneuverhandle where set astern, the ship continued ahead and increased speed. The captain switched over to the emergency system in order to crash-stop the vessel, but before the system reacted, the ship hit the pier with one of the catamaran's pontoon. One passenger and two crewmembers sustained some light injuries and were treated by a local clinic ashore. the ship remained docked, awaiting inspection and necessary repair. The ship was out of service until repair and new certification was in place.

SOLVÅG AV GLOMMEN departed Björkö just before midnight on December 7, 2013 with destination Skagen, Denmark. After departure, the master took the watch and after about 4 hours the deckhand relieved him on the bridge. During the crossing the southerly wind increased more and more and the ship got a drift northwards. This was not noticed. As the ship approached Skagen the deckhand searched after a certain blue light in the harbour but did not find it. He then noticed on the chart plotter that the ship had gone too far northward. Shortly thereafter SOLVÅG AV GLOMMEN went aground. They were not able to get afloat by the ship’s own power, and because of the increasing wind, tug assistance was not available. The master and deckhand therefore decided to abandon the ship, and a rescue vessel from Skagen came to their assistance. When they tried to move to the rescue vessel, the master ended up in the water and had to swim ashore while the deckhand remained onboard SOLVÅG AV GLOMMEN. He was soon after rescued by helicopter.
Consequences1: Pollution,Serious injuries,Ship rendered unfit to proceed,Total loss of the ship

SOLASStatus: JIA LI HAI: Unknown/unspecified, XIUMEI TIANJIN: Unknown/unspecified
Location: EAST CHINA SEA 9 MILES SOUTH OF ZHOUSHAN, CHINA
SummaryOfEvents:
IN COLLISION WITH MV 'XIUMEI TIANJIN' IN THE EAST CHINA SEA 9 MILES SOUTH OF ZHOUSHAN, CHINA IN LAT. 29 50N., LONG. 122 12E., AT 0935 HOURS LT ON 06/12/13 IN POOR VISIBILITY. SUBSEQUENTLY SOLD FOR BREAKING UP.
SUSTAINED DAMAGE TO PORT SIDE OF HULL IN AFT HOLD AREA AND TOOK WATER. 7 RESCUE VESSELS, 4 POLLUTION CONTROL VESSELS AND 12 TUGS ATTENDED THE SCENE. RESCUE TUG 'DONG HAI JIU 117' EFFECTED TOW TO SHALLOW WATERS OFF ZHOUSHAN TO REDUCE RISK OF SINKING. NO INJURIES OR POLLUTION REPORTED. MOVED TO SHIPYARD AT ZHOUSHAN ON 20/12/13 FOR TEMPORARY REPAIRS.

The sailing boat "Beagle" had left Rota marina in Spain (near Cadiz) intended to go to Vilamoura marina in Portugal on December 5th, 2013, around 1200.On December 6th, near Cabo de Sta Maria (Portugal), when the skipper was on watch and the other 2 crew members were slipping, the skipper had mistaken the Faro/Olhão entrance for the Vilamoura marine entrance.
Having noticed the mistake when he was already inside the river branch, he decided to go out again. When he was around 0,5 mi far away from the breakwaters he find the course to Vilamoura on the Plotter and established the autopilot.
Than he went inside the cabinet of the yacht to talk with the others crew members. 10 min later he found that the yacht had grounded on the beach at Barreta Islet. On board there wasn't any digital or paper chart of the area and the Spanish pilot that cover the Algarve waters was not up-to-date. The skipper had no information nor navigational auxiliaries the can inform him about the hydrography of the area between Gibraltar Strait and Vilamoura

BROKE MOORINGS, DRIFTED AND STRUCK A FLOATING DOCK AT THE PETERSEN & SORENSEN SHIPYARD, SVENDBORG, DENMARK AM ON 06/12/13 IN HEAVY WEATHER. SUBSEQUENTLY SCUTTLED AS AN ARTIFICIAL REEF OFF BALLEN, DENMARK ON 05/10/14.
SUSTAINED SEVERE DAMAGE. NO INJURIES OR POLLUTION REPORTED. TUG 'EGESUND' EFFECTED TOW BACK TO BERTH FOR INSPECTION. VESSEL HAD BEEN LAID UP UNMANNED AWAITING SALE FOR DEMOLITION.

Location: 53 MILES SOUTH EAST OF PORT IRENE, PHILIPPINES
SummaryOfEvents:
DEVELOPED LIST AFTER SHIFT OF CARGO, HULL DAMAGED, TOOK WATER AND SANK IN THE PHILIPPINE SEA 53 MILES SOUTH EAST OF PORT IRENE, PHILIPPINES IN LAT. 17 53N., LONG. 122 46E., AT 2040 HOURS LT ON 05/12/13 IN HEAVY WEATHER.
ALL 20 CREW ABANDONED SHIP. NEARBY MV 'YANGTZE ETERNAL' AND MV 'NAVIOS ORBITER' CAME TO ASSIST. 19 CREW RESCUED BY MV 'YANGTZE ETERNAL' AND TAKEN TO SHENZHEN, CHINA. REMAINING CREW MEMBER RESCUED BY MV 'NAVIOS ORBITER' AND TAKEN TO GUANGZHOU, CHINA. NO SERIOUS INJURIES REPORTED.

The fishing boat ALBORADA PRIMERO, when operating in the vicinity of Cove Esteiro (Ria de Muros and Noia) hit her hull against the rocks. This caused its collapse just few meters away from Punta Borneira shoal. The four crew members were rescued. No casualties neither injured were caused during this accident.

Boiler was stopped – 3rd Eng, 2nd Eng, Ch Eng opened combustion chamber, and nozzle was removed. Combustion chamber was left opened.
Approximately 5 minutes after combustion chamber was opened back fire happened. Motorman was cleaning deck for some drops of FO that were spilled while removing the nozzle, in front of opened chamber, approximately 2 meters from boiler.
The flame flash from boiler hit his face and arms. He was immediately escorted to the ships hospital. Chief Mate and Master were informed. Ch/mate administered first aid consisting of cleaning affected areas, applied lidocaine, and bandaged his hands with paraffin gauze, he was then taken to the hospital ashore. 
 
*To EMSA:
The vessel was built in 2008, and then delivered and registered the 5. january 2009.

Corona Seaways was on passage to Klaipeda in Lithuania via Copenhagen.  At 0215 on 4 December 2013 a fire was discovered on the main deck which was loaded with a variety of accompanied and unaccompanied vehicles which included a number which were second-hand and of unknown condition.

The fire was contained and brought under control using the fixed CO2 system.  The vessel entered Helsingborg (Sweden) during the early hours of the morning and was met by the city's fire and rescue service who conducted further firefighting.  Cargo was unloaded to provide access and the fire was declared extinguished at 1330.

Investigations found that the fire originated from a faulty engine staring solenoid of one of the trucks which was loaded with a van.  There was minor structural damage to the vessel and damage to 9 vehicles.  The shipper have introduced revised procedures to carry out material checks of the vehicle being carried.

Location: T THE KARNAGIO HARBOUR, RHODES, GREECE
SummaryOfEvents:
SANK WHILST MOORED AT THE KARNAGIO HARBOUR, RHODES, GREECE IN LAT. 36 25N., LONG. 028 14E., ON 04/12/13.
NO INJURIES REPORTED. SOME MINOR POLLUTION REPORTED IN WATER. ANTI POLLUTION BOOM DEPLOYED AND CLEAN UP MEASURES EFFECTED. VESSEL HAD BEEN LAID UP SINCE 2005.

Location: T THE KARNAGIO HARBOUR, RHODES, GREECE
SummaryOfEvents:
SANK WHILST MOORED AT THE KARNAGIO HARBOUR, RHODES, GREECE IN LAT. 36 25N., LONG. 028 14E., ON 04/12/13.
NO INJURIES REPORTED. SOME MINOR POLLUTION REPORTED IN WATER. ANTI POLLUTION BOOM DEPLOYED AND CLEAN UP MEASURES EFFECTED. VESSEL HAD BEEN LAID UP SINCE 2005.

The fisherman got injured when he got his foot crushed in a trawl block when shooting of trawl doors. He was washed away with a sea trawl door and got stucked with his foot under the block. Wire was raised and feet freed. Safety boots removed, movement in feet ok. Skin cracking and damage is below the ankle right foot.
Radio Medico contacted for advice. Sailed to Tananger where the injured were driven further for hospital treatment.
While checking mooring lines during cargo discharge operations, alongside in Bilbao, Spain, one mooring rope burst and seriuosly injured an AB Seaman (Indian nationality).

Location: STRANDED ON A BEACH AT YENISAKRAN, TURKEY
SummaryOfEvents:
STRANDED ON A BEACH AT YENISAKRAN, TURKEY IN LAT. 38 53N., LONG. 027 03E., ON 03/12/13 IN HEAVY WEATHER. WRECK ABANDONED IN SITU.
NO INJURIES OR POLLUTION REPORTED. TUGS ATTENDED THE SCENE. VESSEL HAD BEEN ANCHORED OFF ALIAGA, TURKEY SINCE AUGUST 2013 AWAITING CLEARANCE FOR BEACHING FOR DEMOLITION.
The 2/E died due to injuries sustained when a chain block failed and load that was being lifted landed on him.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Ship remains fit to proceed

SummaryOfEvents: During departure at 16:55 LT on December 1st vessel ran aground  in the chanel at a distance 0.63 NM from the breakwater (sea side),  being loaded with  15484 tons of fuel oil . She was refloated again with the assistance of tug boats and departed for the port of KUGA at 19:47 LT – no changes in the double bottom soundings and COT ullages noted.No damage reported.
WHERE ONE CREW MEMBER DEAD IN DURING THE CARGO OPERATION, IN SANTOS BASIN OFFSHORE, BRAZIL, ON DECEMBER 01TH 2013.

At 08:03hrs (LT) on 1 December 2013, the vessel ARION struck the jetty when she was mooring in Port Suez Oil Terminal.  The contact between the vessel and jetty resulted in minor damages to ARION’s hull as well as 3 of the jetty’s wooden fenders.
Ocean Emerald touch berth #4 East and have damage in ballast tank #2 starboard side.

On November 30th, 2013, m/v OCEAN EMERALD contacted the pier/dock during berthing maneuvering with pilot on board. OCEAN EMERALD sustained minor damages; and the pier/dock was damage as well. No injuries or pollution incidents were reported.
Cargo1: General cargo in container / 8813 Long ton

SummaryOfEvents: Operational accident on board St. Kitts & Nevis flagged Ro-Ro vessel LYGRA. Longshoremen were bringing lorries with containers to the area, and then the crewmembers were making fast them to the lashing devices fitted on deck. As it was meal time, there were less longshoremen and crewmembers that used to. Suddenly, a crewmember was struck between the container on one lorry and another container that had been already lashed. Nobody witnessed the accident. One of his fellow heard something like a shout and approach to the area. Immediately shouted to the driver and once free of container they could give some aid to the injured and raise alarms. Crewmember suffered serious injuries in his chest and was moved to the local hospital with very severe prognosis. After several weeks in the hospital, he could be repatriated to Russia, where he will follow his recovery.

On the 2013 november 29th in the afternoon, the trawler "Baie des Anges"entering the port of "Le Trport" at a wrong time, regarding the level of the water, runs aground. (See SR1) Despite the French regulation frame for this type of ship there is no enginer on board. (See SR2) The master tries to run astern with the engine. Later on, he has declared that the pitch controlling device had broken and that he that he had not used the electric emergency device. Nothing else is attempted while (tide coming) the depth increasing, the ship goes on drifting.(See SR1) 3 crewmembers are evacuated by the local fire brigade ship. Later on the skipper will be evacuated by the helicopter. The ship drifts till the beach and is severely damaged. Everybody has been conducted to the hospital. The master has suffered a light traumatic shock on the head that has been immediatly cured at his arrival.Everybody will suffer a light hypothermia and leave the hospital on the same day. Nobody has been severely physicaly injured. The master, after being rescued, will disapear and found again 4 months later. They will have 2 months leave. The youngest AB will suffer of a traumatic shock with effects lasting several months.The ship is lost, it will be completely destroyed during the following hours.
Consequences1: Pollution,Serious injuries,Ship rendered unfit to proceed,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents:
On thursday 28th november 2013, Condor Rapide was shifting berth in St Malo from rampe2 to lay-by position on rampe 1 after completing discharge and with only operational crew aboard. Seafarer was in position to receive heaving line from ashore to pass stern-line.
After two attempts where the heaving line fell short, the seafarer holding a boat hook, placed himself right next to the aft fairlead's stag-horn looking upwards. He over balanced falling over the two low rails and fell between the stag-horn and the adjacent railings striking his head and coming to rest on the port buckets and guard.
Having sustained injury to knee and a blow to the head the seafarer was signed off work for a week.

Location: SOUTH CHINA SEA 310 MILES EAST OF VUNG TAU, VIETNAM
SummaryOfEvents:
CAUGHT FIRE IN ENGINE ROOM IN THE SOUTH CHINA SEA 310 MILES EAST OF VUNG TAU, VIETNAM IN LAT. 09 34N., LONG. 111 38E., AT 1005 HOURS LT ON 27/11/13. SUBSEQUENTLY TOWED TO ALANG, INDIA WHERE ARRIVED ON 30/01/14 FOR BREAKING UP.
CREW UNABLE TO CONTROL BLAZE AND ABANDONED SHIP. MV 'MAIDEN VOYAGE' PROCEEDED TO ASSIST, RESCUED ALL 26 CREW AND TOOK THEM TO HONG KONG. NO INJURIES REPORTED. TOWED TO UNKNOWN PORT FOR INSPECTION.

SOLASStatus: Estrela do Oceano: Unknown/unspecified, Jade V: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents: On November 27th, 2013 the sailing yacht "Jade V", catamaran type - 2 floaters, in transit to Cascais more or less 25 mi away from Portuguese coast near Espinho, with the head of 170 and a speed between 6 and 10 knots depending of the wind speed, collided with the fishing vessel "Estrela do Oceano" that was sailing with a head of 060 and a speed around 7 / 8 knots. From that accident had resulted some damages on the head of both floaters of the catamaran, more serious on the starboard floater than on the port one, and some minor damages on the port side midships of the fishing vessel due to a metal stiffening plate that she had on the impact zone. It was found that the collision had resulted from: a misinterpretation of the relative movement of the yacht related to the fishing vessel, done by the skipper of this ship; a use of an excessive speed by the fishing vessel; an wrong application of the Colreg determinations to the situation that had occurred; and, a lack application of the 17th rule, line b), by the skipper of the catamaran.
Duty engineer fell overboard while he was washing debris of dredging spoils in the hold of hopper barge moored in the Gdansk harbour. The engineer drowned despite the immediate rescue action.
ClassificationSociety1: Polski Rejestr Statkow (Polish Register of Shipping) (PRS)

SummaryOfEvents: At time the vessel anchoring 2nd engineer was found a stuck in the elevator shaft between the elevator and elevator shaft walls, no signs of life. The emergence of the elevator circumstances are not yet known.

The 88-metre cargo ship XING LONG ZHOU 65, heading to Tianjin municipality sank off Yantai City on Sunday 25 November 2013 at 9:00 pm (local time). The bodies of three crew members were recovered and nine others remain missing.
The ship lost power at about 8:50 pm and started to lean in the strong gales.  The accident happened in heavy seas (strong winds and waves).  Search and rescue teams are searching the areas

STRANDED AFTER DRAGGING ANCHOR AT ULSAN, S. KOREA IN LAT. 35 29N., LONG. 129 25E., AT 0315 HOURS LT ON 25/11/13 IN HEAVY WEATHER.
ALL 11 CREW RESCUED BY COASTGUARD. NO INJURIES REPORTED. SUSTAINED DAMAGE TO HULL.

A Tianjin-registered cargo ship ZIHAISHUN, carrying 14 crew members, sank off Weihai City on Monday 26 November at 2:58 am (local time).  7 bodies were recovered and 7 people are still missing.   Search and rescue teams are searching the areas.

On November 25, 2013, the fishing vessel NUEVO MUGARDOS grounded on a rocky zone, called Punta Herminia, at the entrance channel of La Corua port. The skipper didn't modify the speed or vessel course, prior to grounding, to avoid it. After that, the fishing vessel was pulled out the grounding point and was assisted to enter La Corua port by two tugs. The fishing vessel had propulsion, nevertheless, she hadnt directional control. There was pollution, but nevertheless the amount of fuel spilled was impossible to determine.

SOLASStatus: GSF Grand Banks: Unknown/unspecified, MAERSK DETECTOR: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents: On the afternoon of 24 November 2011, the offshore supply vessel Maersk Detector was using dynamic positioning while loading cargo from the mobile offshore drilling unit GSF Grand Banks in the White Rose oil field. Weather was deteriorating at the time, with increasing swells arriving from the south. The vessel did not maintain position and, at 1530:39 Newfoundland and Labrador Standard Time, the port stern of the Maersk Detector struck the port aft intermediate column of the GSF Grand Banks, holing both the vessel and the rig. No injuries or pollution resulted from this occurrence.

InitialEvent: Hull failure / failure of watertight doors / ports, etc.
SummaryOfEvents:
Incident of flooding of the pump room occurred on board the vessel MT BANKIM CHANDRA CHATTERJEE, while the vessel was discharging cargo at the terminal. One of the bolts of the securing plate, holding the mechanical seal of the Ballast pump No. 2, was found to be adrift. This, apparently, caused ingress of water, during the ballasting operation and flooded the pump room upto the height of 10.5 mtrs.
There was no loss of life or property. There was no damage to the environment as the pump room water was transferred to the Slop tank. There was no significant damage to the machinery, located in the pump room, as all operations were immediately stopped and electrical power of the pump room was isolated.

On November 22, 2013, it was reported that the Engine Cadet on board the m/v TEMPTATION had jumped overboard. The Electrician witnessed the incident as he exited the bosun store; he then alerted the rest of the crew. The oiler, hearing the Man Overboard (MOB) alert threw a lifering into the water; however, the Cadet swam away from the vessel. The Master notified other vessels within the vicinity and a search and rescue (SAR) operation was commenced. The following day, the Harbor Master advised the Master of the TEMPTATION to call off the search. The remains of the Cadet was never found.

On november 22nd, 2013 the fishing boat GHANDHI based in Vigo, suffered a severe leak in the engine room while fishing in the Atlantic sea, 150 miles west of Lisbon. When the leak was detected the chief engineer activated two bailing pumps in order to evacuate the income of water. Some minutes later he realized the two pumps were not enough to bail out all the water and decided to evacuate the ship. An helicopter rescued the crew from the deck of the ship.
Consequences1: Serious injuries,Ship rendered unfit to proceed,Total loss of the ship

SOLASStatus: DADIMAR DOS: Unknown/unspecified, DADIMAR DOS: Unknown/unspecified
Location: 335 MILES NORTH OF SAL, CAPE VERDE ISLANDS
SummaryOfEvents:
CAUGHT FIRE, TOOK WATER AND SUBSEQUENTLY SANK IN THE ATLANTIC OCEAN 335 MILES NORTH OF SAL, CAPE VERDE ISLANDS IN LAT. 21 44N., LONG. 022 23W., AT 1137 HOURS LT ON 20/11/13.
ALL 10 CREW ABANDONED SHIP TO LIFERAFTS AND SUBSEQUENTLY RESCUED BY NEARBY FV 'TANIA MARIA'. NO INJURIES REPORTED. 2 SPANISH AF HELICOPTERS PROCEEDED TO THE SCENE BUT WERE NOT REQUIRED. SURVIVORS SUBSEQUENTLY TRANSFERRED TO FV 'MIRISMAR'

received from Piraeus Rescue Centre, timed 0720, UTC: Passenger (cruise) MSC Magnifica (95128 gt, built 2010), en route from Mykonos to Lisbon, with 2469 passengers and 976 crew members on board, came in contact with the dock, while manoeuvring to berth at the Piraeus Port, at 0505 hrs.

On 19 November 2013, at about 1530, an 18 year old crewman on board the 16m scallop dredger Wanderer II suffered a serious hand injury during a routine dredge emptying operation. Following the accident the injured man was evacuated to hospital by helicopter where, due to the extent of his injuries, his damaged hand had to be amputated. The junior deckhand had gone to the assistance of the relief skipper, who had been tipping the starboard dredges alone using the trawl winch’s starboard whipping drum. The junior deckhand used over three full turns around the whipping drum and was then attempting to surge the tipping rope by pushing against the direction of drum rotation when his hand became trapped.

On 14 November 2013 at 1810 hours, BRITANNIA SEAWAYS departed from Sørreisa, Norway, on a voyage to Bergen, Norway, loaded with military equipment, vehicles and a number of tank containers and flatracks  with jerrycans containing petrol and aviation/jet fuel. In addition, there were 12 passengers, all military personnel, on board. 

The weather forecast for the planned voyage predicted gale and storm, and during severe rolling a tank container on the forepart of the weather deck loosened from its lashings and caused damage to some jerrycans. Eventually, leaked petrol was ignited by sparks generated by one or more tank containers that slid across the deck, steel against steel. The fire quickly spread to other jerrycans and tank containers on the forepart of the weather deck and became immense.

The firefighting effort was successful because the ship’s officers and crew were able to expediently exploit and manage the resources available under adverse circumstances. 

No one was injured and there was no pollution of the environment.
Cargo1: Military vehicles and equipment, petrol and jet fuel

Location: GULF OF MEXICO 160 MILES SOUTH OF MOBILE, AL, USA
SummaryOfEvents:
SUSTAINED ENGINE FAILURE, TOOK WATER IN LAZARETTE AND SANK IN THE GULF OF MEXICO 160 MILES SOUTH OF MOBILE, AL, USA IN LAT. 28 23N., LONG. 087 46W., ON 15/11/13 IN HEAVY WEATHER.
ADDITIONAL PUMP AIRDROPPED TO THE VESSEL BY USCG AIRCRAFT BUT CREW UNABLE TO CONTROL THE INGRESS OF WATER. ALL 5 CREW RESCUED BY USCG MH-65 HELICOPTER AND TRANSFERRED TO THE NEARBY MODU 'THUNDERHORSE'. SUBSEQUENTLY TAKEN TO BELLE CHASE, LA THE FOLLOWING DAY. NO INJURIES REPORTED. ENGINE FAILURE REPORTED TO BE CAUSED BY FUEL CONTAMINATION WITH SEA WATER.

ShipsInvolved: DELETE ME (IMO 5103211), HORIZON II (IMO 8955562), NEW DAWN (-)
SOLASStatus: DELETE ME: Unknown/unspecified, HORIZON II: Unknown/unspecified, NEW DAWN: Non-SOLAS
SummaryOfEvents: A fishing vessel skipper was returning to his vessel after an evening ashore. His vessel was outboard of another fishing vessel. As he attempted to climb the other vessel, he slipped and fell between the vessel and the quay wall. Although the alarm was raised immediately, he could not be recovered until 28 minutes later. He died from cold water immersion.

CAUGHT FIRE DURING PROCESS OF DEMOLITION AT TRI RUCHYA, MURMANSK, RUSSIA IN LAT. 68 57N., LONG. 33 00E., AT 1448 HOURS LT ON 18/11/13.
BLAZE EXTINGUISHED BY LOCAL WORKERS. FIRE SERVICES ATTENDED THE SCENE AND ASSISTED WITH COOLING THE AFFECTED AREAS. NO INJURIES REPORTED. EXTENT OF DAMAGE NOT KNOWN. VESSEL HAD BEEN LAID UP FOR SEVERAL YEARS.

Location: St. Lawrence Seaway, Iroquois, Ontario, Canada
SummaryOfEvents: On 06 November 2013, at approximately 2305 Eastern Standard Time, the general cargo vessel Claude A. Desgagnes struck the upper approach wall of the Iroquois Lock in the St. Lawrence Seaway near Iroquois, Ontario. The vessel then crossed the channel and ran aground. No pollution or injuries were reported; however, the vessel sustained minor damage.
The ship grounded while transiting Nekkoyosen.

MSC Didem: Chief Cook Charles Sequeira presumed lost at sea on 6th November 2013M/V MSC DIDEM, SHIP CREW MISSING AT SEA ON 06TH NOVEMBER 2013
M/V MSC DIDEM sailed on a voyage from port of Salalah, Oman to Jeddah, KSA (Saudi Arabia)
On 06th November 2013 the steward of M/V MSC DIDEM at 1930Hrs/LT remarked that Chief Cook
Mr. Charles Sequira was missing and reported this matter to the duty officer 3rd Officer on the bridge
watch.
The duty officer initiated the search operations onboard but the Chief Cook could not be found
Master of M/V MSC DIDEM was informed 2005Hrs/LT on 06th November 2013 by the 3rd Officer on
watch a thorough search again was carried out by ship's crew with no success to find him.
Vessel was swung around the reciprocal course at the last known position where the chief cook was last
seen on board. Accordingly, the search operation was conducted in the adjacent waters
The vessel searched & scanned the water area around the estimated locations of the missing Chief Cook,
without finding him or any traces
The Vessel then after more than 25 hours of search, in consultation with the Management office ceased
the search operations and resumed her original passage to Jeddah Port, KSA

SUSTAINED ENGINE FAILURE, DRIFTED, STRUCK BUOY AND SANK 500 METRES OFF CUA VIET PORT, VIETNAM IN LAT. 16 54N., LONG. 107 12E., AT 1500 HOURS LT ON 06/11/13 IN HEAVY WEATHER. SUBSEQUENTLY REPAIRED AND RETURNED TO SERVICE.
8 CREW RESCUED AND 1 STILL MISSING. VIETNAMESE BORDER GUARDS EFFECTED SAR FOR THE MISSING CREW MEMBER. CARGO OF WOOD CHIPS WAS WASHED ASHORE. SUBSEQUENTLY TOWED TO DOCK IN HAIPHONG, VIETNAM FOR REPAIRS.

TOOK WATER IN STERN AREA AND SANK AT KETAPANG PORT, BANYUWANGI, INDONESIA IN LAT. 08 07S., LONG. 114 24E., AT 0400 HOURS LT ON 06/11/13. WRECK ABANDONED IN SITU.
ALL CREW RESCUED. NO INJURIES OR POLLUTION REPORTED. THE VESSEL WAS AWAITING CARGO DISCHARGE AT BANYUWANGI WHEN STARTED TAKING WATER AND TOWED BY 3 TUGS TO SHALLOW WATER AND GROUNDED. STERN SUBSEQUENTLY SANK COMPLETELY BUT BOW SECTION STILL ABOVE WATER. WRECK STILL IN SITU EARLY 2015.

Location: MOUTH OF THE BONNY RIVER 7 MILES SOUTHWEST OF BONNY, NIGERIA
SummaryOfEvents:
STRANDED ON A SANDBANK AND SUBSEQUENTLY CAPSIZED IN THE MOUTH OF THE BONNY RIVER 7 MILES SOUTHWEST OF BONNY, NIGERIA IN LAT. 04 20N., LONG. 007 05E., AT 1700 HOURS LT ON 05/11/13.
ALL 15 CREW RESCUED BY PATROL VESSEL 'MAP 2' AND TAKEN TO BONNY. NO SERIOUS INJURIES OR POLLUTION REPORTED. TUG WAS ATTEMPTING TO REFLOAT THE STRANDED MT 'SYMPHONY' AT THE TIME OF THE INCIDENT. WRECK LYING ON PORT SIDE PARTIALLY SUBMERGED.

The Antigua & Barbuda flagged ship ROSEBURG arrived at the Kiel-Holtenau roadstead late afternoon on 5 November 2013. The ship left the port of Riga fully laden with timber three days earlier. The voyage passed without any incidents. 
 There were plans to anchor in the Kiel-Holtenau roadstead for an hour to carry out minor repairs in the engine room before starting the passage through Kiel Canal. While turning in the anchor position at 1653, the ROSEBURG suddenly listed to starboard. All the deck cargo started to slide, a reasonable number of lashing straps broke, and more than half the wood pallets fell overboard. This caused the ship to list briefly at up to 40 . Situated in the starboard wing, the chief mate was unable to keep his footing and also fell into the water. He held on to some floating timber until he was picked up by a pilot boat that had rushed to assist.
 
He was taken to hospital for observation but suffered no lasting injuries. The timber that fell overboard was recovered over the next few days but had to be declared cargo damage.
Since the ROSEBURG sailed under the flag of Antigua & Barbuda, a joint investigation was carried out with ADOMS IID. This concluded that a ship may not begin her voyage when she is overloaded and thus compromises the safety of her and her crew.
Consequences1: Serious injuries,Ship remains fit to proceed

SOLASStatus: HANG SHENG 18: Unknown/unspecified, OOCL SOUTHAMPTON: SOLAS
SummaryOfEvents: At about 0051 hours local time 0n 5 November 2013, the south bounding Hong Kong, China registered container vessel "OOCL Southampton" collided with norhteast bounding China registered coastal cargo vessel "Hang Sheng 18" in the position about 22-14.9N, 114-27.5E , the coastal vessel "Hang Sheng 18" sank late, all crew (12) from "Hang Sheng 18" were rescued by "OOCL Southampton", two of them got slight injured on their hands. "OOCL Southampton" got slight scratching and denting on her bulbous bow.

USCG CUTTER 'MARLIN' PROCEEDED TO THE SCENE AND PUT A RESCUE TEAM ABOARD THE 'CHEYENNE' BUT THEY WERE UNABLE TO CONTROL THE INGRESS OF WATER. ALL 3 CREW RESCUED AND TAKEN TO FORT MEYERS BEACH, FL. NO INJURIES REPORTED.

A 12- metre long double-decker passenger ship, with more than 200 persons aboard, capsized and sank 60 miles southeast of Bangkok near the tourist resort of Pattaya on Sunday 3 November 2013 at 17:00 p.m. (local time).
Six people died.  The number of missing people has not been officially disclosed. 
The ship left Lan island for a 30-minute evening trip to Pattaya.  An engine problem prompted passengers on the first deck to rush to the second floor, causing the ship to list and eventually sink.
Marines from Thailand’s Sattahip Naval Base were deployed to search for the ship and the missing passengers.
The National News Bureau of Thailand indicated that the passenger ship was licensed to carry up to 150 people.  The local police said more than 200 passengers were on the ship.
Investigations continue to ascertain the cause of the accident.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents: At approximately 0745 hours (LT) on November 3, 2013 an empty container fell from the shore crane spreader into Cargo Hold No. 6 of NILEDUTCH CHEETAH making a hole inside HF Storage Tank No. 208. Fuel oil immediately began to spill from the hole in the storage tank and into Cargo Hold No. 6 and nearby containers. There were no incidents of environmental pollution or injuries to persons onboard.
On 3 November 2013 at 05:08hrs (LT) a fire broke out in the engine room on the vessel NAVIGATOR CAPRICORN while the vessel was berthed at Sibur Terminal, Ust Luga, Russia.

SummaryOfEvents: The fishing vessel FRANCS suffered a leakage in the engine room due to a badly executed reparation and finally sunk.
Consequences1: Ship rendered unfit to proceed,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents:
At approximately 1250 hours (UTC) on 30 October 2013 the Dominica registered refrigerated ro-ro cargo ship FERNANDA suffered a fire in the engine room while off the coast of Iceland. 

Both engineering watch keepers were absent from the engine room at the time of the outbreak, the Second Engineer had gone to an engine store on the upper deck  to select fuel valves to be re-conditioned and the engineering watch rating was working in the electrical store also  on the upper deck. During this time, a fire broke out in the engine room which was initially detected by the second officer via the fire detection panel’s visual and audible alarms located on the navigation bridge. The Master arrived shortly thereafter to the bridge upon hearing the alarms. Efforts were made to enter the machinery spaces to determine the location of the fire but they were unsuccessful due to the presence of heavy smoke. Flames were seen on the starboard side of the engine room. The main engine stopped resulting in a blackout as electrical power was being supplied by the shaft generator. 

All of the crew were accounted for, the engine room openings were closed and the Master instructed the Chief and Second Engineers to activate the halon fixed fire-fighting system, which initially appeared to suppress the fire. However it soon became apparent to the Master that the fire was gaining ground and he contacted the ship’s agent in Iceland and the managers DP in Estonia to brief them on the situation. The ship’s agent in turn notified the Icelandic Coastguard who broadcast a MAYDAY RELAY although no MADAY call was made by the ship. The decision by the Icelandic Coastguard to broadcast a MAYDAY RELAY was made following an evaluation using sound professional judgement to facilitate the safety of life at sea in an expedited manner. Consideration was given for the type and degree of the emergency, the locale of the emergency and prevailing weather conditions, and previous experiences conducting search and rescue operations consistent with similar circumstances. 

The crew mustered initially on the navigation bridge and later on the boatdeck. Two inflatable liferafts were launched on the port side and one was prepared for launching on the starboard side. 

The wind was estimated by the Master to be about 20/25 metres per second, Beaufort force 7/9 with a heavy sea and swell. FERNANDA was approximately 6 miles offshore and was rolling heavily. 

The Icelandic Coastguard called the ship requesting information and the Master advised that the situation on board was deteriorating rapidly. It was agreed that a helicopter would be dispatched to airlift the crew from the vessel. It was airborne at 1351 hours. At 1436 hours the evacuation of the crew commenced from the open deck forward of the bridge. All eleven crew members were successfully airlifted from the vessel at approximately 1456 hours. They were landed ashore at Reykjavik, Iceland at 1532 hours.

The Icelandic Coastguard tasked a lifeboat from the Vestmannaeyjar Islands, a tug, and their salvage ship THOR to attend the vessel.  Fire-fighting efforts continued overnight until 0230 hours on 31 October 2013 when it was determined that the fire was contained although not fully extinguished.

At 1200 hours on 31 October a number of firefighters from the Icelandic Coastguard boarded the vessel to prepare for towing it to Hafnarfjordur where the vessel was eventually berthed at 0830 hours on 01 November 2013. 

While at Hafnarfjordur, as firefighters from Reyjkavik were preparing to board, it was decided to open the stern ramp to ventilate the cargo spaces which were smoke logged. This decision was also made in order to facilitate access so that foam could be used to extinguish the fire in the remaining hot spots. The action of opening the stern ramp allowed fresh air to enter the cargo compartments of the vessel and the fire flashed again generating large volumes of smoke. A decision was quickly taken to tow the vessel out to sea to allow the fire to burn out. The stern ramp was in the open position and was subsequently lost to the sea. 

The fire continued to burn mainly in the cargo compartments. Heat seeking cameras on THOR confirmed that there were very high temperatures in the lower tween deck and cargo hold. Sea water was directed on to those areas to cool them. 

At 0900 hours on 06 November FERNANDA was towed into Grundartangi Port, Iceland where she berthed starboard side to the quay. Fernanda was identified to have a distinct starboard list. An inspection of the entire vessel was undertaken by the Icelandic Police Service. 

On 09 November 2013 an inspection of the vessel was conducted by the Flag State Investigator in the company of fire-fighting and investigating officials from Iceland. 

On 13 November 2013 the vessel was sold to a metal re-cycling company in Iceland for demolition and de-contamination.

Sea water and all hazardous waste on board was removed and taken to a disposal facility. The remaining fuel oil and sludge was removed and re-cycled.

There were no injuries or fatalities among the crew, the firefighters or the Icelandic Coastguard.
Consequences1: Ship rendered unfit to proceed,Total loss of the ship
Cargo1: In ballast at time of incident

SummaryOfEvents:
SUSTAINED MECHANICAL PROBLEMS IN THE MEDITERRANEAN SEA 40 MILES SOUTHEAST OF RHODES, GREECE IN LAT. 35 5ON., LONG. 028 43E., AT 2320 HOURS LT ON 29/10/13. SUBSEQUENTLY BEACHED AT ALIAGA, TURKEY ON 05/12/13 FOR BREAKING UP.
MV 'UNIWIND' PROCEEDED TO ASSIST AND EFFECTED TOW TO TARTOUS, SYRIA WHERE ARRIVED ON 03/11/13 FOR INSPECTION AND REPAIRS.

During arrival in Brisbane, under harbour pilot guidance, the ship lost control of its propulsion machinery while manoeuvring alongside the wharf.  Despite releasing an anchor the ship struck the wharf.  No injuries or pollution were reported.

The vessel grounded during the inward pilotage of the Brisabne River at the rocks cutting.  No damage or pollution and the ship.  the ship was moved to the Incitec South wharf and divers have been called

CAUGHT FIRE WHILST MOORED AT PORT ADELAIDE, SA, AUSTRALIA AT 0230 HOURS LT ON 29/10/13. NOT REPAIRED AS VESSEL WAS AWAITING DEMOLITION.
BLAZE EXTINGUISHED BY LOCAL FIRE SERVICES. NO INJURIES REPORTED. SUSTAINED EXTENSIVE DAMAGE TO ACCOMMODATION AND BRIDGE. TUG HAD BEEN LAID UP UNMANNED AWAITING DEMOLITION.

CAUGHT FIRE WHILST MOORED AT PORT ADELAIDE, SA, AUSTRALIA AT 0230 HOURS LT ON 29/10/13. NOT REPAIRED AS VESSEL WAS AWAITING DEMOLITION.
BLAZE EXTINGUISHED BY LOCAL FIRE SERVICES. NO INJURIES REPORTED. SUSTAINED EXTENSIVE DAMAGE TO ACCOMMODATION AND BRIDGE. TUG HAD BEEN LAID UP UNMANNED AWAITING DEMOLITION.

At 18:51 hrs on 28 October 2013, the RoPax ferry Stena Alegra grounded after dragging its anchor in Knot winds off Karlskrona, Sweden. 
The ship's bottom plating and frames were damaged, and one ballast tank and one void space were flooded.
Two tugs towed the ship off the rocks after the weather had moderated the next day. Following an underwater inspection the ship proceeded to Gdynia, Poland, for repair.

IN COLLISION WITH MT 'CORAL IVORY' IN THE KIEL CANAL OFF KUDENSEE, GERMANY IN LAT. 53 56N., LONG. 009 12E., AT 0300 HOURS LT ON 28/10/13. DAMAGED BEYOND EONOMICAL REPAIR AND SUBSEQUENTLY BROKEN UP AT GRENAA, DENMARK ON 06/02/14.
NO INJURIES REPORTED. SUSTAINED SERIOUS DAMAGE TO HULL, TOOK WATER IN ENGINE ROOM AND DEVELOPED 24 DEGREE LIST TO PORT. TUGS 'WOLF' AND 'LUCHS' PUSHED THE CASUALTY AGAINST THE EMBANKMENT TO CLEAR THE MAIN CHANNEL. SOME BUNKER FUEL SPILLED INTO WATER. ANTI POLLUTION BOOMS DEPLOYED. SALVORS TT SALVAGE REMOVED BUNKER FUEL AND PUMPED OUT FLOODED ENGINE ROOM. CARGO LIGHTERING COMMENCED 02/11/13. REFLOATED AND TOWED TO BRUNSBUTTEL ON 06/11/13.

The fishing vessel "JESUS DOS NAVEGANTES"  was trying to exit the harbour, when faced a big wave from starboard (SB), which made the vessel to list to port side, while a second wave came and made it to capsize and sink. 
From the eight crewmen onboard, five were taken from the water by SV "PATRÃO MACATRÃO" and from these, one died afterwords at the hospital. The remaining three were lost at the ocean and were presumably dead.
Consequences1: Serious injuries,Ship rendered unfit to proceed,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents:
Our managing vessel MlT CS Crane ran aground on 25th Nov. 2013 around 0142LT at near DIsan
Anchorage. The time tabIe about the aboye mentioned grounding is as under, 1) 0350LT/2013.11.22: Departed at Nagoya, Japan for Next port DIsan, Korea.
2) 0550LT/2013.11.24: Anchored at E-l anchorage, DIsan.
3) 2145LT/2013.11.24: Captain carne up the bridge and checked again the weather / wind direction / wind speed. Wind speed and direction were I7~20 knots & southeasterIy wind at that time. And, instructed again to 2nd officer and 3rd officer that ship's position, weather condition frequentIy check and notify to master immediately if you have any doubt.
4) 0135LT/2013.11.25: Reported from 2/0 tbat ship's anchor dragged.
5) O136LT/2013.11.25: Captain carne up the bridge. 2/0 already notified to DIsan VTS for shifting from anchorage. And also, he notified to EIR for engine stand-by. And notified to 2/0 for heaving anchor by C/O.
6) 0141LT/2013.l1.25: Engine stand-by and Captain ordered the engine dead slow ahead and the heIm to hard port.
7) 0142LT/2013.l1.25: Stand-by for heaving anchor. But at the same time, Engine alarm and Engine shut down with sudden strong wind (60 ~ 65 knots) and big wave to bridge.And, the vessel ran aground.

A crew member on a Carnival Cruise Lines vessel has died in an accident at the port of New Orleans. The crewman was performing maintenance on the Carnival Conquest.  The man was crushed while performing maintenance work on the 2,974-berth Carnival Conquest (built 2002), the cruise line said in a statement provided to TradeWinds.
Cherry picker accident-He was carrying out the work on a man lift, or cherry picker, when he became wedged between the lift and a lifeboat platform. Local paramedics and the ship's own medical team responded to the crew member, "but tragically the crew member died", the Carnival Corp subsidiary said. The vessel was at its home port between voyages at the time of the incident. The victim has not been identified.

On 19 October 2013, at 2330 (LT), the ro-ro vessel Smat dragged anchor, and ran aground off the port of Poti, Georgia.  At the time of the accident, she had a cargo of 35 railway cars.  Her maximum draft was 3.58 m. 

The safety investigation concluded that Smat dragged anchor in Westerly gale force winds, with storm force gusts and rough seas, to which the anchorage area off Poti is exposed.  The master’s efforts to regain control of the situation proved ineffective and unsuccessful in the prevailing conditions. 

No injuries were reported, and there was no pollution. 

The safety investigation also found that the anchoring position, the lack of appreciation of the deteriorating weather conditions, the consequent excessive loads on the anchoring system of the ship while she remained on anchor and attempting to recover the anchor, had all contributed to the accident.

InitialEvent: Hull failure / failure of watertight doors / ports, etc.
SummaryOfEvents:
On 19 October 2013, the Marine Safety Investigation Unit was informed of an accident on board the Maltese registered chemical tanker Umar 1 at Fos sur Mer, France.  Preliminary information indicated over- pressurisation of one of the vessel’s cargo tanks during loading of Methyl Tertiary Butyl Ether.  The accident resulted in significant structural damage in way of the vessel’s cargo length area. 

The safety investigation identified a number of contributing factors which led to the accident.  At the time, the pressure/vacuum valves were not operating as designed.  Moreover, there were no pressure gauges fitted locally on the main deck for the duty crew member to check the pressure inside the cargo tank.  Remotely, inside the cargo room, the audible pressure alarm had been muted and a loading rate in excess of the cargo tank designed rate was not addressed. 

The safety investigation also concluded that in a complex dynamic environment, hazards during the cargo loading operations went undetected by the crew members.

Location: 570 MILES SOUTHWEST OF FREETOWN, SIERRA LEONE
SummaryOfEvents:
FOUNDERED IN THE ATLANTIC OCEAN 570 MILES SOUTHWEST OF FREETOWN, SIERRA LEONE IN LAT. 05 46N., LONG. 022 01W., AT 1055 HOURS LT ON 18/10/13.
ALL 10 CREW ABANDONED SHIP TO LIFERAFTS WHICH WERE LOCATED BY A FRENCH NAVAL ATLANTIC AIRCRAFT OPERATING FROM DAKAR, SENEGAL. MT 'INA THERESA' AND FV'S 'EXPLORER TRES', 'CEDES' AND 'GENE' PROCEEDED TO THE SCENE. ALL CREW RESCUED BY 'EXPLORER III' AND SUBSEQUENTLY TRANSFERRED TO 'GENE' FOR ONWARD TRANSPORTATION TO MINDELO, CAPE VERDE ISLANDS. NO INJURIES REPORTED.

The fishing vessel arrived at Ijmuiden (home port) on 16 october after ending her fishery.She was moored at her regular berth where the upper hold was discharged, the lower hold was scheduled to be discharged the 19 october.
Overnight the vessel was manned with only the second engineer as watch man, which is normal procedure.
At approximately 05:00 on 18 october, alarms was actived and the second engineer immediately went to machine room to check the alarms.
Next he tried to extinguish the fire without result and the fire brigade was alerted.

The fire in upper fish hold, most likely overheating of the electric tracing of the portside bulkhead door, was quickly extinguished and at approximately 09:30 the vessel was released by the fire brigade.
Conséquences: the door in the bulkhead between the fish hold and the dry packaging area had been on fire, resulting in a burning wall, door and adjacent pallets(stored).

Location: 19 Nautical Miles Off-Shore Foorchon, Gulf of Mexico - USA
SummaryOfEvents:
PERSON INVOLDED WAS DOWN IN BALLAST WATER TANK FOR MEASURING O2 level in tank and tank inspection.
during climbing the ladder to the top of the tank, where the exit was, he fell down approx 10 meter.

When the vessel was heading to enter into the port of Fécamp, the “joystick” to control the helm suddenly didn’t respond to the skipper’s order. Surprised by the breakdown, he didn’t had a sufficient time to switch to the hand-steering and the vessel collided brutally the North jetty.  Due to the impact, two seamen had been slightly injured.
After the incident the vessel went to berth by her own means, followed by another fishing vessel; the two seamen were able to resume their work.
A preliminary repairing has been made on the stem in order to let the ship proceed to another port fitted with a lift and a shipyard.
After the incident it has been possible to identify that 2 of the joystick’s electric wires were disconnected.

Location: 900 metres off South Korea's south eastern port city of Pohang
SummaryOfEvents:
A Panamanian-flagged cargo ship, CHENG LU 15, carrying 130 tons of bunker oil and diesel fuel and a crew of 19 sank having collided with a seawall 900 metres off South Korea’s south eastern coast on Tuesday 15 October 2013 at 21:30 local time.  
Eight crew members were rescued, 9 died and 2 are still missing.
The ship had anchored off the port city of Pohang, but high waves and winds forced her against the seawall.
Search and Rescue operations, including helicopters, submarines and special rescue teams were deployed by the South Korean coast guard; however efforts were hampered by strong winds and waves from south sea storm.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents:
Cheng Lu 15 departed from Caofeidian Port, China, carrying 19 crew members
on September 27, 2013. It unloaded some of its cargo at Incheon Port and Pyeongtaek Port, Korea, before entering its final destination, Pohang Port, Korea on October 13, 2013. 

Cheng Lu 15 initially planned to sail to Muroran Port, Japan, at around 16:30 on October 14, 2013 after unloading all its cargo at Pohang Port, but the vessel decided to berth at the north side of the anchorage number M19 near Yeongilmanhang in Pohang, at around 18:00 on the same day due to concern that it would come across Typhoon Wipha.

On October 15, 2013, in the southern waters of the East Sea where Cheng Lu 15 was anchored, a wind wave advisory had been issued at 09:00 which was replaced with a high seas warning at 13:00. 
On the same day, aware of Cheng Lu 15’s position, Pohang VTS Center advised Cheng Lu 15 to heave up the anchor and move out of harbor limits. 
However, Cheng Lu 15 did not comply and instead, decided to set two anchors using the engine.

Cheng Lu 15 could not withstand the deteriorating weather, and it had been at anchor when the left stern came into contact with the north breakwater of Yeongilmanhang in Pohang at around 17:45 of the same day.

Immediately following the initial contact, a strong northeast wind pushed Cheng Lu 15 southwestwards, repeatedly slamming it into the breakwater. It eventually tore a hole in the left stern and sank the vessel. 

From this Marine casualty, Cheng Lu 15 sank due to a hole created in its left stern. Among 19 crew members, 8 were rescued and 11 (10 Chinese and 1 Vietnamese nationalities) were confirmed dead. Among the 10 caissons of the northern breakwater at Yeongilmanhang, the upper and lower parts of 7 caissons were destroyed.

At 2155 (UTC-4) on 14 October 2013, during an engineering watch, one of the motormen suffered second degree burns when adding a water-treatment chemical in the vessel’s reverse osmosis plant. 

The safety investigation conducted by the Marine Safety Investigation Unit (MSIU) found that the motorman had inadvertently added sodium nitrite instead of sodium metabisulfite.  This led to an immediate exothermic chemical reaction. 

It was found that sodium nitrite was stored in the chemical storage locker along with sodium metabisulfite.

A passenger, along with two other adults, had brought their 5 children on to the passenger ferry for a day out. While the ferry was starboard side alongside at a terminal, the passenger's 3 year old child stood on the starboard side seating on the passenger upper deck. While the attention of the child's parent was diverted by one of the other children, the child leaned over the starboard side rail and quickly fell overboard. The child fell about 5m in to the river, between the vessel and the terminal jetty. The master, in the wheelhouse, caught sight of something falling overboard. The ensuing panic and commotion alerted the bridge team that a passenger had fallen overboard. The chief officer ran out of the bridge and down to the terminal. He looked in the water and saw the child floating face up. He quickly climbed down the fendering and grabbed the child. He passed the child up to other crew members assisting. The child was taken to hospital and no injuries were found and was discharged. Subsequently, the child's mother noticed some bruising to the child's buttocks.

Location: CHANGJIANGKOU, YANGTZE RIVER, IN EASTERN CHINA
SummaryOfEvents: Manila, Oct 15 -- Bulk carrier Super Sun (11256 gt, built 1982), carrying a cargo of logs, experienced a fire near the mouth of the Yangtze River in eastern China, on Oct/ 14/2013. The fire started in the engine-room and spread to the crew's accommodation quarters. The vessel's 23 crew members were subsequently rescued by the rescue vessels from the East China Sea rescue Bureau. The fire was later brought under control.

On 11-10-2013 at 0715LT at Roxas (11°35′N 122°45′E), Philippines, while the ship was berthing, one stern line stopper on the Aft of the ship parted. The Second Officer and an A/B were injured. They were sent to the hospital.  The A/B was dead later in the hospital.

At about 1000 on 7 October, a crew member was crushed between one of Toucan Arrow's cargo cranes and a hatch coaming while the ship was being prepared for cargo operations. Emergency services attended the ship and the crew member was taken to hospital. The crew member later died as a result of his injuries.

Location: 40 kilometres (24 miles) southwest of the Dutchnavy port of Den Helder
SummaryOfEvents:
The 32-metre ship MARIA, deployed to guard an oil drilling platform capsized after colliding with the fishing trawler TEXEL 68, in the North Sea, off the Dutch coast (40 kilometres (24 miles) southwest of the Netherlands navy port of Den Helder) at 1:30 am, local time on Monday 7 October 2013.
All five crew members aboard MARIA were wearing life jackets; two crew members were rescued by the fishing trawler and three are missing.
Search and rescue operations, including two rescue ships, two helicopters from the Dutch Coast Guard and divers continue to search for the missing crew members
The cause of the accident is unknown.  An investigation is in process.

At 4:44 local time on October 4, 2013 fishing vessel MAR DE MEDIO informed of a leak to the fishing vessels nearby, about 3.7 miles W of Cabo Peas. The three crew were rescued by fishing vessel ALWAYS MARIA. The ship sinks at 43 40.28 N and 005 56.443 W. N o sea polution. The crew unharmed were transferred to the port of Cudillero.

After leaving La Rochelle early in the morning, the St Hubert II had put its nets in the water and was waiting on the low tide to heave them up. At 8h00 in the morning an alarm concerning the alternator was activated. The captain opened the engine room hatch cover. He noticed that there was a large quantity of water surrounding the engine. The engine stopped and the captain decided to evacuate the ship. Other fishing ships helped by the SAR means and rescued everybody 10 minutes later. The ship sank about 1 hour later.
The fishing vessel LEAL, with 2 POB ground near Isla de la Deva, (Asturias). Water started to enter the vessel and it lasts five minutes in sinking
Third officer fell into the water while using a Jacobs ladder to read the ship's aft draft marks.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Ship remains fit to proceed

SummaryOfEvents:
At about 0445 on 30 September 2013, a crew member working in the main laundry was injured on the Maltese registered cruise ship Celebrity Infinity while she was moored alongside Harwich International Port, UK.  The accident occurred when a conveyor shuttle, forming part of the fully automatic laundry system, moved unexpectedly, crushing the crew member between the conveyor shuttle and the casing of one of the laundry dryer machines.  He suffered internal injuries and was subsequently transferred ashore for emergency treatment and intensive care. 
 
The safety investigation identified that a defective display on one of the dryer control panels required crew members working in the main laundry to frequently enter the laundry shuttle tunnel, which was a restricted access area.  The safety interlock preventing the operation of the conveyor had been knowingly disabled.  Further safety issues were identified relating to risk awareness, training procedures and supervision of laundry staff.

FOUNDERED IN THE PERSIAN GULF 10 MILES NORTHWEST OF DUBAI, UAE IN LAT. 25 25N., LONG. 055 14E., PM ON 30/07/13 IN HEAVY WEATHER.
ALL 7 CREW RESCUED BY DUBAI MARINE POLICE VESSELS. NO INJURIES REPORTED. SOME OF THE CARGO OF BUILDING MATERIALS SUBSEQUENTLY WASHED ASHORE ON LOCAL BEACHES.
Fire and abandonment by 30 persons.

Other Cargo/Multipurpose/General Cargo M/V BSLE SUNRISE currently loading her cargo at Antwerp port, Belgium on 27th September 2013.

It is reported that fitter Mr. Plemen Ivankov Stoimenov was carrying out routine inspection on the cargo hold twin deck no. 1 (lower hold) for securing the lashing; he accidentally fell in an awkward position which resulted in his fracture right glenoid and superficial wound face.

Ship’s crew then made an attempt to rescue him from the cargo hold twin deck no. 1 (lower hold) and they put a ladder and the injured fitter managed to climb by himself. 

Third Officer Stoyanov Dimitar offered him first aid.

The date and time when the accident occurred were at about 18:45(lt), 27th September 2013. 

Master informed immediately with the ship agent to ensure quick transport to bring the injured fitter to the hospital.

SOLASStatus: EIFUKU MARU NO. 18: Unknown/unspecified, JIA HUI: SOLAS
Location: 11 kilometres (7 miles) west of Izu Oshima Island, Tokyo
SummaryOfEvents:
The Japanese-flagged cargo ship EIFUKU MARU No. 18, travelling to Ishikawa from Nagoya (Japan), capsized after colliding with the Sierra Leone-registered cargo ship JIA HUI, travelling to Busan, South Korea from Kawasaki in the morning of Friday, 27 September 2013, 11 kilometres (7 miles), west of Izu Oshima Island.  
The 13 crew members of JIA HUI were reported to be safe, while six crew members of the capsized EIJUKU MARU No. 18 were reported missing.  
Search and rescue operations, including patrol boats and helicopters continue to search for the missing crew members.
Both ships were carrying steel to be delivered to Chiba, east of Tokyo.

STRANDED IN THE SEA OF MAMARA 1 MILE EAST OF UCMAKDERE, TURKEY IN LAT. 40 48N., LONG. 027 23E., AT 0400 HOURS LT ON 26/09/13. SUBSEQUENTLY BROKEN UP IN SITU IN OCTOBER 2013.
NO INJURIES OR POLLUTION REPORTED. ALL CREW RESCUED. COST OF SALAVGE OPERATION NOT JUSTIFIED BY VESSELS VALUE AND BROKEN UP IN SITU.

On the 24th of September 2013, at about 19:07, Ro-Pax "Nisos Rodos" (Greek flag, registry of Piraeus 11520) was moored alongside in the port of Corinthos and a series of maintenance works and repairs at the ship's car ramp was under way. A water supplier truck (water wagon) entered the garage of the ship, to provide water. Inside the truck there was the driver and a friend of his (sex:male, age:56, nationality: Scopian - FYROM). The connection was to be made at the left bow connection valve. The bosun moved together with the truck and they reached the connection point. The driver and owner of the truck along with the bosun began procedures to connect the water hose. The driver was on the water tank so as to open the wagon's exhaust valves and the bosun took the hose to the connection valve of the ship.
At that time, they both heard a sound (like falling on deck) from the side of the water wagon and they saw the driver's friend lying next to the truck's tank almost unconscious.
At once they called for help to the ship's mate (by VHF). An ambulance was called, while the mate applied first aid to the unconscious man. The ambulance arrived and took the man to the hospital, where he was declared deceased.
Investigation is being conducted for the accident.

A crewmember aboard passenger cruise ship MSC OPERA was reported missing when he failed to turn up at muster stations when the vessel was going alongside in Southampton.  Crewmembers interrogated their CCTV coverage and observed the crewman jumping into the sea from deck 6.
Search and rescue operations were enforced; CG rescue helicopter 104 was tasked and Bembridge lifeboat was requested to launch.  A second and final search was carried out on updated datum using CG Helo 106 from Portland and Bembridge and Selsey Lifeboats.  The search and rescue operations terminated on completion of the second search.

Location: NEAR TANJUNG MANIS, 14 MILES WEST OF SARIKEI, SARAWAK, MALAYSIA
InitialEvent: Hull failure / failure of watertight doors / ports, etc.
SummaryOfEvents:
SUSTAINED BREACH IN HULL, TOOK WATER AND SANK IN THE RAJANG RIVER NEAR TANJUNG MANIS, 14 MILES WEST OF SARIKEI, SARAWAK, MALAYSIA IN LAT. 02 06N., LONG. 111 20E., AT 0130 HOURS LT ON 23/09/13.
11 CREW SWAM TO SAFETY BUT 1 CREW MEMBER MISSING. LOCAL AUTHORITIES EFFECTED SAR OPERATION FOR THE MISSING CREW MEMBER.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents: On 22 September 2013 the vessel FEARLESS was grounded at 23:45hrs (LT) due to extreme weather conditions.  The vessel was in Port Sudan’s port approaches waiting for berthing to unload cargo when the incident occurred.

On Sunday 22 September 2013, the platform supply ship VOS RAASAY was due to carry out cargo operations at the SPC platform, however she arrived at the incorrect platform.  On realising the error, the tide took the ship between the 29A and 29Q platform causing a collision with the rig.  VOS RAASAY suffered a dismasting, while the rig suffered slight leg damage.

In accordance with SITRIP message 00036-22092013, 09:59:15, from Humber Coastguard

STRUCK THE PIER, SUSTAINED DAMAGE TO HULL, TOOK WATER AND SUBSEQUENTLY INTENTIONALLY GROUNDED AT ENDE, INDONESIA IN LAT. 08 51S., LONG. 121 38E., AT 1500 HOURS LT ON 22/09/13. WRECK ABANDONED IN SITU.
ALL CREW RESCUED. NO INJURIES OR POLLUTION REPORTED. VESSEL WAS BERTHED AWAITING UNLOADING WHEN SHE WAS STRUCK BY A LARGE WAVE AND MADE CONTACT WITH THE PIER RESULTING IN SERIOUS DAMAGE TO THE HULL. THE ENGINE ROOM STARTED TO TAKE WATER AND THE CAPTAIN INTENTIONALLY GROUNDED THE VESSEL AWAY FROM THE PIER TO AVOID OBSTRUCTING THE BERTH. PARTIALLY SUBMERGED WRECK ABANDONED IN SITU.

BROKE MOORINGS, DRIFTED, STRANDED ON BREAKWATER AND SUBSEQUENTLY CAPSIZED NEAR KURAMO, LAGOS, NIGERIA IN LAT. 06 24N., LONG. 003 24E., AM ON 22/09/13 IN HEAVY WEATHER.
3 CREW MISSING AND 3 RESCUED. NO POLLUTION REPORTED. UNDERSIDE OF CAPSIZED HULL STILL VISIBLE ABOVE WATER.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents:
As LE SOLEAL was heading at low speed (7 knts) in the North of the island Achinkinkan, towards the fjord of Penkigney (Russian coast, in the SW of the Bering Strait), she grounded on a sandbank with gravel.
It appeared that the Russian charts had not been updated of the actual position of the sandbank.
After the investigations conducted by the crew and a diver (one of the crew members), no damage was identified on the hull and to the propellers.
30 hours later, attempts to re-float the vessel by her own means at high water have been successful and the ship resumed her voyage.

During berthing manouevres, ship's engine could not be stopped and the vessel hit the berth and then another vessel. Ship's mooring line was under great tension and the drum over which the line was stowed broke from its foundation and one cadet at the forward mooring station was pressed between the drum and ship's rails. Being severely injured, the cadet lost his life due to his injuries.

On 18 September 2013, at 1250, an able seaman on board the chemical tanker Mitrope was seriously injured by a messenger line while casting off the tug’s towline. 

At 1305, the ambulance medical team was on board and the able seaman was transported to the local hospital where his injuries were diagnosed as epidermis abrasion in the region of the left knee and traumatic amputation of the left lower leg. 

The MSIU safety investigation found inadequate communication between the tug and Mitrope after casting off the tug’s towline as an important contributing factor to the accident.
ClassificationSociety1: Polski Rejestr Statkow (Polish Register of Shipping) (PRS)

Location: 60 MILES NORTHWEST OF OKI ISLAND, JAPAN
SummaryOfEvents:
CAUGHT FIRE IN THE SEA OF JAPAN 60 MILES NORTHWEST OF OKI ISLAND, JAPAN IN LAT. 36 47N., LONG. 132 15E., AT 0700 HOURS LT ON 18/09/13. DAMAGED BEYOND ECONOMICAL REPAIR.
3 KOREAN COASTGUARD VESSELS AND JAPANESE COASTGUARD VESSELS ATTENDED THE SCENE AND ASSISTED WITH FIRE FIGHTING OPERATIONS. 32 CREW ABANDONED SHIP TO LIFERAFTS AND RESCUED BY NEARBY RUSSIAN MV. REMAINING 5 CREW RESCUED BY COASTGUARD VESSEL. NO INJURIES REPORTED. BLAZE EXTINGUISHED. SUSTAINED SEVERE DAMAGE. TOWED TO UNKNOWN PORT FOR INSPECTION.

At 0434 on 18 September 2013, the Malta registered chemical tanker, Ovit, ran aground on the Varne Bank in the Dover Strait while on passage from Rotterdam, Netherlands, to Brindisi, Italy. The vessel, which was carrying a cargo of vegetable oil, remained aground for just under 3 hours; there were no injuries and damage to the vessel was superficial. There was no pollution. Ovit refloated on the rising tide and subsequently berthed in Dover.
Ovit’s primary means of navigation was an electronic chart display and information system (ECDIS). The officer of the watch was following a route shown on the ECDIS display; the route passed directly over the Varne Bank.

SOLASStatus: Sally Jane: Unknown/unspecified, SALLY JANE: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents: On 17 September 2013, the fishing vessel SALLLY JANE foundered approximately 2NM SSE of Hengistbury Head.  The vessel is reported to have foundered due to adverse weather conditions while trawling.  Two crewmembers were recovered from the liferaft and taken to Yarmouth Lifeboat for onward transfer to the hospital.

The Barbados registered general carco ship Scan Fjord 8PWR sustained a hull damage when docking in port of Trondheim in the early hours 170913. She struck an underwater ironbolt sticking out of the pier underwater, which punctured a void space leading to water ingress and serious listing to 15 degree. Local firebrigade where rapidly on scene and placed emergency pumps onboard, mangaing to re-stabilize the ship in order to make a temporary repair on the 17th of september around 0900. At 1500 hours class had been onboard and permited repairs to be carried out for the ship to depart in the same evening. No  injuries or environmental impact where reported.

Our barge  "CREST PROVIDER"  departed Singapore on 15th Sept 2013 @ 0952  hrs for Mynmar. She is being towed by tug  Pacific Platinum.
Today morning our master found  the Safety Officer  missing  and suspected  he has fell overboard.
