He was last seen  at onboard 0300 hrs checking his email.  
he master presume  he fell overboard between  position Lat 02°.53'N 100°.57'E time 1900UTC/16th and 03°06'N 100°46'E 2300UTC/16th.
The tug towing our barge has since turned back to the above position location to search for him.
At the same time, we have alerted Malaysia Authority (Port Klang )  for  SAR  assistance.
Chief Officer fell into the water while reading draft marks.  At the time he was suspended over the ship's side in a bosun chair.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Ship remains fit to proceed

SummaryOfEvents:
Sub : M.V.Ocean Adventure – Motorman Mr. X – Date of Birth : 25.01.1988, Passport no : F6748829.

 

Dear Sir,

 

This is to inform you that on Saturday 14th Sep 2013, around 0700 hrs AM we received first intimation on phone from Master of our

Panama registry vessel MV Ocean Adventure, that MTM X , Age 25 is missing whilst the vessel is at Sea, enroute

From Singapore to Huangpu , China.

Location: DOCK NO. 1 OF SURALAYA POWER PLANT, CILEGON, INDONESIA
SummaryOfEvents:
CAUGHT FIRE IN ENGINE ROOM WHILST PREPARING TO DEPART FROM DOCK NO. 1 OF SURALAYA POWER PLANT, CILEGON, INDONESIA IN LAT. 05 53S., LONG. 106 02E., AT 2345 HRS LT ON 12/09/13. ARRIVED GADANI BEACH, PAKISTAN ON 16/10/14 FOR BREAKING UP.
PATROL BOAT 'KN TRISULA' AND 6 TUGBOATS PROCEEDED TO ASSIST. TOWED TO SAFE ANCHORAGE FOR FIRE FIGHTING OPERATIONS. THE BLAZE WAS EXTINGUISHED ON 17/09/13. NO INJURIES REPORTED. SUSTAINED VERY SEVERE DAMAGE.

The crane operator suffered pelvic fracture due to collapse of a deck crane on board Panamanian cargo ship GREEN HOPE, while the ship was engaging in cargo handling operation at Nakashima quay No.3, Himeji Port, Hyogo Pref., Japan.
Consequences1: Serious injuries,Ship remains fit to proceed

SummaryOfEvents: The account of events was drawn from the statements of witnesses and documents. The times referred to throughout the report are local. On September 10 2013, at approximately 20:00 hours, the fishing vessel (F/V) CHONA, left the port of A Corua with two crew members, a skipper and a seaman. The vessel was authorized to fish in the Cantabrian national fishery with minor arts and engaged in pot fishing. That evening, they were picking up and dropping pots by the Ria de A Corua.Moments before the accident, about 01:00 hours on the 11th, the sailors were in the stern lifting one of the swaths of pots. At one point, several successive waves embarked water over the stern, so that it was flush with water. Then the crew cut off rigging in order its weight did not submerged more the stern. The bilge pumps did not have sufficient capacity and crew tried unsuccessfully to bail out the water with buckets. The efforts made by the crew were in vain and the stern of the boat remanined completely submerged. The skipper had time enough to call the F/B FUXA OS VENTOS which operated very close. The F/B FUXA OS VENTOS came quickly and the two crew members of the E / P CHONA jumped to her. They tried towing the F/B CHONA but due to the large amount of water shipped and her heel they decided to cut off the rope. Once the towing rope was cut off the boat sank in position 4323,33'N / 00822,33'W and about 15 m deep. The seamen were able to retrieve some personal belongings, a tank of gasoline and some ropes and buoys that floated. CONCLUSIONS The F/B CHONA's fishing license was in force and the titles of the crew were valid for the fishing area. The last clearance resolution record was the day January 17 2013 and was valid until 17 July 2013. This clearance was expired at the time of the accident. This clearance resolution stated a limitation of the permitted area for fishing to this boat: "... navigation for LOCAL FISHING is authorized without having liferaft on board, in the waters of the Ria de A Corua inside the line between Punta Herminia to Punta del Seixo Blanco ". The boat was at the limit of the authorized area.The E / P CHONA was a boat without deck. This type of boat is not fitted with drain gates, thus shipped once the water has no way out, except through bilge pumps or manually. He was carrying two electric pumps that could bail out a flow rate of 13.2 m3 / hour each. They probably worked at first, but the batteries that were located at the stern of the boat become useless when the water ingress. Furthermore, bilge bailing is not sufficient if a massive flooding happens. The bailing capacity was calculated for a small amount of water, such as entering a bilge in usual conditions. The moulded depth of the E / P CHONA was 0.66 m. His draft was unknown. According to statements by the boat crew was already seated aft, besides being the two fishermen in the same area and at the same time they were heaving up the rig from this area. As a result, the freeboard of the boat astern was considerably reduced.Furthermore, the vessel was receiving the NE wind of about 16 knots (upper limit of force 4 Beaufort scale). According to meteorological report they suffered sea between rough and very rough seas and swell of N component with significant wave height of about 1.3 m and average period of 5 seconds.From the above it follows that the boat sank when facing weather conditions of excessive severity for the type of boat.
Consequences1: Ship rendered unfit to proceed,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents: SUMMARY On September 10, 2013 on 12:10 local time, the Navy Hydrographic Vessel N/V TOFIO departed from the military arsenal of La Carraca intending to work on updating mapping nautical coastal area of the Gulf of Almera.When browsing to the seaway, she was to leave for the "Cao de la Carraca" to access the channel of Cadiz, subject both to the control of Vessel Traffic Service (VTS) in the area of Cadiz Bay. At 13:11 hours the N/V TOFIO reported to the VTS having passed under the bridge Carranza and proceed to sea. At that time he was informed that a pilot was out to sea with a merchant vessel and subsequently enter the container vessel M/V WEC BRUEGHEL, bound for the container terminal of Cadiz. Moments later, crew in N/V TOFIO spoke directly to the pilot embarked on the B / M WEC BRUEGHEL and both vessels agreed to pass starboard to starboard; that is, the merchant would approach the red buoys of channel and B / H Tofino to the green buoys. Meanwhile, the fishing vessel F/V PLAYA YERBABUENA, was moored in the harbor of Cadiz, unloading her catch of the day. At 13:17 hours the fishing vessel finished downloading and pushed off to go to El Puerto de Santa Mara to stock ice. The skipper cruised in the port of Cadiz to the mouth of the harbor and, once exceeded, his intention was to go straight to El Puerto de Santa Mara (a port just in front of Cadiz, both inside the Cadiz Bay. At 13:30 hours the F/V PLAYA YERBABUENA collided with her port side bow against the port side of the N/V TOFIO in front of the entrance to the port of Cadiz. There were no injured or pollution damage but fishing vessel suffered severe material damage in all her bow area. After inspections and relevant communications took place between both vessels, as they were in the proximity of the port, the fishing vessel returned with slow speed to her berth in the fishing harbor of Cadiz, while the navy vessel continued her travel to destination. CONCLUSIONS The collision occurred because the lookout of F/V PLAYA YERBABUENA did not remain at all times an effective visual and auditory surveillance, also using all available means appropriate to the circumstances and conditions of the moment, to fully assess the situation and the risk of collision (excerpt from Rule 5 COLREG). In the N/V TOFIO such lookout existed. However, they could have taken additional measures of surveillance, behavioral ship and acoustic signals agreeing to navigate near the harbor entrance and following an unusual procedure, as it was navigating to the sea on the opposite end to dictated by Rule 9 of RIPA. The absence of AIS signal from the fishing vessel probably prevented the bridge team of N/V TOFIO to become aware of the movements of F/V PLAYA YERBABUENA. The use of two communication channels in a complex environment with multiple users such as the Bay of Cadiz, channels 14 (pilots) and 74 (VTS), plus Channel 16, not subject to the same requirements all of them, which could affect important information were lost or that it did not come to all parties. An important decision as the passing maneuver "starboard to starboard" of two important ships in front of the entrance to the Port of Cadiz should have been communicated by VHF channel 74, and not by the channel 14, so that all participants in the system, all ships and boats sailing inside the bay, were aware of it. However, in the case under review, the above action would not prevent collision course because the fishing vessel was not listening to this channel. This may indicate that the requirements of the STM are not fully adopted by its members.

SOLASStatus: BRAVE: Unknown/unspecified, FORTUNE CLOUD: SOLAS, KINDA: Unknown/unspecified, MYCENAE: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents: Sep 9 -- Bulk carrier Fortune Cloud (20432 gt, built 1983) was in contact with bulk carrier Abdullah (26070 gt, built 1996) at the Alpha Anchorage of Chittagong port, at around midnight of Sep 9. Both vessels incurred damage with the Fortune Cloud sustaining a ruptured bottom hull and water ingress to its engine-room. Crews of both vessels are safe. Authorities said that navigation at Chittagong port was not affected by the accident.
Consequences1: Ship rendered unfit to proceed,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents:
CAUGHT FIRE IN ACCOMMODATION BLOCK IN THE WESTERN MEDITERRANEAN SEA 50 MILES NORTHEAST OF JIJEL, ALGERIA IN LAT. 37 29N., LONG. 006 14E., AT 0825 HOURS LT ON 08/09/13. DAMAGED BEYOND ECONOMICAL REPAIR.
ALL 8 CREW ATTEMPTED TO ESCAPE BUT RESCUED AND DETAINED BY FRENCH NAVY FRIGATE 'COMMANDANT BIROT'. NO INJURIES REPORTED. ALGERIAN SAR FORCES ASSISTED IN DOUSING THE BLAZE. ARRIVED AT TOULON, FRANCE ON 12/09/13 IN TOW OF TUG 'ABEILLE FLANDRE' FOR INSPECTION. REPORTED CREW INTENTIONALLY SET FIRE TO VESSEL WHEN INTERCEPTED BY THE FRENCH AUTHORITIES. 20 TONS OF CANNABIS SUBSEQUENTLY DISCOVERED ON BOARD. SUSTAINED SEVERE FIRE DAMAGE.

Location: 20 MILES NORTH OF RAPA ISLAND, FRENCH POLYNESIA
SummaryOfEvents:
CAPSIZED AND SUBSEQUENTLY SANK IN THE SOUTH PACIFIC OCEAN 20 MILES NORTH OF RAPA ISLAND, FRENCH POLYNESIA IN LAT. 27 17S., LONG. 144 20W., AM ON 05/08/13 IN HEAVY WEATHER.
FRENCH NAVY HU-25 AIRCRAFT LOCATED THE VESSEL THE SAME EVENING AND DROPPED 2 LIFERAFTS. A NAVAL AS-365 HELICOPTER AIRLIFTED 5 CREW OFF THE SINKING VESSEL AND A 6TH CREW MEMBER WAS RESCUED FROM THE WATER SUFFERING FROM HYPOTHERMIA. ALL SURVIVORS TAKEN TO HOSPITAL IN RAPA. 4 DEAD BODIES SIGHTED IN WATER AND 4 CREW MISSING. VESSEL INITIALLY CAPSIZED ONTO STARBOARD SIDE AND SUBSEQUENTLY SANK IN THE EVENING OF THE FOLLOWING DAY.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents:
CAUGHT FIRE IN SUPERSTRUCTURE IN THE MEDITERRANEAN SEA 35 MILES NORTHEAST OF MALTA IN LAT. 36 20N., LONG. 014 50E., AT 1620 HOURS LT ON 06/09/13. SUBSEQUENTLY BEACHED AT ALIAGA, TURKEY ON 12/02/14 FOR BREAKING UP.
ALL 9 CREW JUMPED OVERBOARD AND WERE RESCUED BY ITALIAN COAST GUARD. NO INJURIES REPORTED. 3 MALTESE ARMED FORCES VESSELS ASSISTED WITH FIREFIGHTING. REPORTED THAT CREW INTENTIONALLY STARTED FIRE TO DESTROY CARGO OF 30 TONS OF CANNABIS TO AVOID ARREST BY AUTHORITIES FOR DRUG TRAFFICKING. BLAZE EXTINGUISHED AND TOWED TO POZZALLO, SICILY BY TUG 'NOS TAURUS' FOR INSPECTION. SUSTAINED SEVERE DAMAGE TO SUPERSTRUCTURE.

As the M/V FROMVEUR II was approaching the port of Molène Island with a poor visibility, she grounded near the entry of the fairway. A small flooding in the engine room was quickly controled by the ship’s bilge system. She was re-floated about 2 hours later by her own means, after the landing of all the passengers (361 persons).
The fishing boat "EL NENE" sank because of a fire ocurred inside the engine roo, while was towing.A person died as a consecuence of drowning during the abandon of the boat.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Pollution,Ship rendered unfit to proceed

InitialEvent: Hull failure / failure of watertight doors / ports, etc.
SummaryOfEvents:
SUSTAINED STEERING FAILURE IN THE EAST CHINA SEA 70 MILES EAST OF FUZHOU, CHINA IN LAT. 26 05N., LONG. 120 29E., AT 0830 HOURS LT ON 31/08/13. DAMAGED BEYOND ECONOMICAL REPAIR AND SUBSEQUENTLY SOLD FOR BREAKING UP.
TUGS 'DONG HAI JIU 112' AND '113' PROCEEDED TO ASSIST AND EFFECTED TOW TO DONGGANG, CHINA FOR CARGO DISCHARGE AND INSPECTION. SUBSEQUENTLY TOWED TO FUJIAN XINYUAN SHIPBUILDING YARD, NINGDE, CHINA WHERE ARRIVED ON 05/09/13 TO AWAIT SALE FOR DEMOLITION.

On 29 August 2013, at 12:00, a fire was detected in the fishing boat VALLE DE ELDA, while sailing to her port of registry, SANTA POLA. Initially, the fire was focused in the chimney located in the aft area on the port side, but quickly spread to the rest of the boat. After giving notice of the emergency through VHF Channel 16 to SASEMAR, its 11 crew members threw themselves into the water. Eleven of them managed to reach the liferaft and were picked up by a recreational sailingboat, another failed to reach it and floated with the help of a lifeboat, being rescued by the rescue helicopter HELIMER 207. One of the crew had burns and other, symtoms of hypotermia. The fishing boat sank. It was not possible to conclude on the basis of the information available the causes of the fire in the ship.
Consequences1: Serious injuries,Ship rendered unfit to proceed,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents: On August 28, 2013 around 23:00 (GMT + 2), the fishing vessel SCUDERIA of the armament Eouzan Travadon, on his way to reach his fishing grounds, stranded on the shores of theEnglish Cornwall. The ship has various cracks on the works, including a crack in the front diesel fuel tank which lets out about 10 000 liters of diesel fuel causing a marine pollution without any significant impact on the marine environment.No injuries are to be deplored.The ship remains aground five days, then returns to the ports of Falmouth then Boulogne-sur-Mer in tow for repairs. After expertise, it will finally be destroyed.

On August 25, 2013, M/V THISSEAS departed San Lorenzo and was Port bound for Rotterdam. At approximately 23:10 LT, PLATA FEEDER (Paraguay Flag, IMO No. 7822524), heading upstream the Parana River (Argentina), collided with THISSEAS as the vessel (THISSEAS) was heading downstream. THISSEAS sustained damage to bow, port and starboard side hull shell plating, and port side pilot’s combination ladder. PLATA FEEDER ran aground and sustained holes with ensuing water ingress. The collision neither produced personal injuries nor the environmental pollution.

On 24 August 2013, at about 1853, an able seaman (AB) was struck by a mooring rope during unberthing operations on board the Maltese registered container vessel CGM CMA Pegasus. The AB suffered a serious injury to the back of his head and was taken to a nearby hospital. He succumbed to his injury later during the night due to excessive bleeding.

The safety investigation was unable to determine as to how the mooring rope jumped off the roller guide and caused the accident. However, a number of safety factors were identified, including incorrect procedures, inadequate supervision and inadequate risk management during the mooring operations. The safety investigation also concluded that the ergonomics at the forward mooring station had contributed to the accident.

The MV Favorita had been discharging salt in China, and was en route to Japan for loading cement clinker when the accident happened.
Prior to commencement of work on the 24th August, a safety meeting including safe job analysis in connection with cleaning of the cargo holds was conducted.  Both the deck- and engine crew which was involved in the cleaning operation was participating. The meeting included a check of the personal protecting equipment as well as a discussion regarding the upcoming job, which method and equipment to be used, and risks involved in the cleaning operation.
The engine crew was responsible for the cleaning cargo hold number five, in accordance with the routines of the company. The crew entered the cargo hold via a protected, fixed ladder in the forward part of the cargo hold, and started the preparations for work. Two men were in the cargo hold, while one man was situated on deck by the hatch coaming to assist with lowering equipment, regulating the water supply to the high pressure machine etc. The crew had hand held radios for communications. 
During the cleaning process, the motorman was standing in a portable aluminum ladder operating the high pressure machine; one man was supporting the ladder and controlling the safety line, while the third crewmember was occupied with miscellaneous tasks. Shortly after nine o’clock, an additional man from the engine crew entered the cargo hold to assist with the cleaning procedure. He started to assemble scaffoldings for use when cleaning the forward and aft bulkheads.
After completion of cleaning one part of the bulkhead the motorman moved down the ladder in order to move the ladder to the next position. The engineer which supported the ladder had to move to the side in order to give way for the motorman on his way down. Just about one meter before he reached the tank top, the motorman raised and disconnected the safety line from the harness. The engineer shouted to him to inform him he should wait as he was not yet down in a safe position. At the same time the motorman suddenly fell backwards. His safety helmet fell of just before the back of his head hit the tank top. The accident happened at approximate 0920 local time.
The engineer noticed that the motorman was unconscious and was bleeding from the back of his head. He supported the head and shoulders of the motorman in his lap in order to try to stop the bleeding. At the same time the engineer called the rest of the crew in the cargo hold for attention, and to get assistance and inform the rest of the crew about the accident.
The master was out on deck at the time of the accident when he heard the call on the radio that one crew member fell and got injured in cargo hold number five. Together with one other crew member, he immediately climbed down in the cargo hold. Some of the crew brought down a resuscitator from the hospital and commenced first aid procedures. After a while a mobile stretcher with neck stabilizer was lowered down in the hold. The motorman was transferred to the stretcher, strapped and hoisted from the cargo hold. The crew used manpower, rope and blocks in order to hoist the injured motorman from the cargo hold, as the master decided not to use the ships cranes due to some swell.
After they brought the motorman up on deck, he was transferred to the ships hospital where he got oxygen supply and the crew monitored the pulse and blood pressure of the injured motorman.
In the meantime the master contacted the company’s emergency telephone number, and at 1001 the master contacted the nearest coastal radio station which was Keelung in Taiwan, China. Keelung CRS relayed the master to NRCC Taiwan, China were helicopter rescue was ordered. The master changed the ship’s course in order to shorten the distance for the helicopter.
The helicopter arrived at 1141, and 1157 the injured motorman was transferred to the helicopter by hoisting him in the ship’s stretcher. The helicopter headed for shore, and landed at the base at 1250. The motorman was transferred from the helicopter base to the hospital by ambulance. At 1529 the hospital reported the motorman was declared deceased.

Tug Master fell over board while crossing from MV Ocean Symphony to MV Ocean Elite which were double banked with one another. Immediately, two life bouys were thrown into water and search and rescue operation launched with the help of port crafts. However, the missing person could not be located. After 3 days, the mortal remains of the person were found floating in the port area.

On the 23rd August 2013 it was decided to enter the cargo tank to retrieve the broken sampler. The Chief Officer and Cadet entered the cargo tank after an Enclosed Space Work Permit and Risk Assessment had been completed. When the Chief Officer and Cadet reached the bottom of the cargo tank they felt debilitating effects of hydrocarbon vapour present at the lower level of the cargo tank. Both the Chief Officer and Cadet attempted to activate their Emergency Escape Breathing Devices and exit the cargo tank. The Master observed the Cadet in difficulty and quickly entered the tank ignoring the advice of a fellow crew member. The Chief Officer successfully exited the cargo tank but the Cadet had collapsed unconscious on the tank bottom. When the Master reached the tank bottom to aid the Cadet he was overcome by hydrocarbon vapour and collapsed.
The alarm was raised and a rescue was quickly initiated. The Master and Cadet were retrieved from the bottom of the cargo tank and brought to the main deck were first aid was administered.
The report concludes that the Master died and the Cadet was injured as a result of entering the cargo tank containing a concentration of hydrocarbon vapour at the bottom of the cargo tank. The ship’s safety procedures for enclosed space were not fully complied with and the risk posed by the hydrocarbon vapour measured in the cargo tank was not appreciated by those involved in the tank entry preparations.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Ship remains fit to proceed

SummaryOfEvents: On 23rd of August 2013, at PONTA DA MADEIRA anchorage - BRAZIL, the 3rd Engineer of M/V "CAPTAIN PETROS H", Philippine national, opened the manhole cover of waste oil tank No 2 in order to repair the tank's gauge. Hot oil from the tank splashed and covered his body resulting to second degree burns. By noon same day he was transferred to local hospital by helicopter where he remained hospitalized until 4th of September 2013 when he passed away.

SOLASStatus: La Pelle Admiral 2: Unknown/unspecified, Nidagas 3: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents: An inflatable pleasure boat, sailing at high speed in the wake of a small passenger ship, steered suddenly to starboard out of the wake and collided with another inflatable one sailing at the same course as the passenger ship. Two women passengers of the second ship were violently hit by the hull of the first one and thrown in the sea. They were evacuated by the rescue boat to the hospital. One of them died shortly after.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Serious injuries,Ship remains fit to proceed

SummaryOfEvents:
On 22 August 2013, at about 0410, one of the oilers on board the general cargo vessel BSLE Teresa suffered from serious burns in the chest area and thoracic cavity. 

The oiler was checking the status of the water level in the cascade tank soon after he arrived in the engine- room.  Unable to locate the meniscus on the sight glass, he eventually came to the conclusion that the cascade tank could have run dry.  He therefore decided to open slightly one of the three dome covers on the top of the cascade tank to determine the water level. 

As soon as he cracked open the dome cover, hot condensate water (at about 80°C) escaped from the opening and spilled over the oiler.

Because the tug " Modris " master was not on the tug board, and the production was a necessity, a drunken 1.34 pm. tug mechanical enginer without navigator certificate took the steering  and sail from floating crane " Astraxana " side overboard and maneuvering touched the starboard side midship in an angle of approx. 20 degrees making 2 tyremarks from its fenders nave ship MSF3.

During port departure maneuvers while the aft of the ship departed only 2-3 m from the dock and the tugboat continued to pull the ship by increasing boat’s speed gradually from slow to half speed, the rope used in towing suddenly broke from the middle part at 11:15 and snapped back to the dock struck and caused grave injury to the port’s personnel who was serving at the wharf as mooring staff.

La Nave de carga general "Isla Guar", de 60 metros de eslora y propiedad de Transportes Marítimos Kochifas S.A., fue modificada para el transporte de peces vivos mediante la instalación de 9 estanques de 45 metros cúbicos cada uno, ubicados en un nuevo entrepuente alto construído en la bodega. Zarpó de Chinquihue, al Estero de Reloncaví, con todos sus estanques cargados al 100% de agua y salmones smolt. Las condiciones de mar y viento eran favorables. Transcurrido un lapso cercano a una hora, el buque presentó una leve escora a estribor de app 5°, la cual fue corregida por medio de achicar el estanque doble fondo de lastre 3 Eb. Pocos minutos después la escora a estribor volvió a presentarse y continuó aumentando hasta alcanzar los 45°, donde comienza a inundarse la bodega u sala de máquina, todo lo cual produce el hundimiento por popa de la nave, la cual zozobró en aguas profundas.

La dotación compuesta por 13 personas abandonó ilesa la nave, utilizando para ello el bote auxiliar inflable de la propia nave, debido a que las balsas salvavidas no se activaron.

Se activó el MRCC CHILE. La lancha menor "Serranía", la cual se encontraba en las inmediaciones, asistió el salvamento, siendo posteriormente apoyada por lanchas patrulleras de la Armada. No se constató vertimiento de hidrocarburos producto del naufragio.

(Versión en Inglés)

“The General Cargo Vessel “Isla Guar”, 60 meters length and property of Kochifas Maritime Transportation S.A., specially adapted for the transportation of living fish on 9 tanks of 45 cubic meters, located on the upper between-deck , set sail from Chinquihue towards the Reloncaví Estuary, with all its tanks filled with water and Smolts Salmons. The sea and wind conditions were favorable. After approximately one hour, the ship had a lift to starboard that has been corrected by balling out ballast. Few minutes after that, the ship listed to starboard again and it have increased up to 90º. After that the ship has sunk its bow and finally has disappeared on deep waters.

The crew of 13 people has abandoned the vessel with no harm using an auxiliary inflatable boat which belonged to the vessel since the life rafts did not activate. The minor boat “Serranía”, which was on the proximities, assisted the rescue, being lately supported by patrol boats from the Navy.

The MRCCCHILE has been activated. Nor Oil spill neither oil leakage has been reported as a result of the wreckage.”

A fishing vessel crew member fell overboard LUCERO UNO, caught in the rigging. CONCLUSIONS OF THE INVESTIGATION: The causes that contributed to the accident are:1. Collective protection measures were not adopted in the area despite the workplace had clear risks. The CIAIM estimated that the work environment would improve by adopting procedures and a slight transformation of the maneuvering zone. For example, the following measures would be taken:a. Stow coves reels to prevent tangling during maneuvers . In addition, a spool brake provided would have increased the possibility of holding the tension of rigging.b. Providing cover these boats maneuver corridors between fish compartments or between them and the side to enter or leave the area aft bulkheads quickly and safely.c. Do not allow a single man to carry out the net run off ; should always be another crewmember nearby. In his absence, the skipper should be able to directly observe the maneuver area without difficulty.d. Make announcements during the maneuver by a button sound a buzzer on the bridge, with a sound audible and differentiated enough, or similar system.e. Reduce noise bridge devices as possible during maneuvers of hauling and run off as part of an established procedure.2. Procedural collective protection measures despite being an activity at risk were not adopted. For example:a. The fishing gear gone off procedure should occur more restraint, hoping that the ship actually aminorase speed.b. There was not enough staff to allow help immediately in case of an accident, or existing staff on board was not willing to help but attention to other works occur.c. Were not aids available in place to facilitate the monitoring and reporting.3. Inflatable life-vests, probably the best personal protective equipment that could be used in this case, were not used to mitigate the consequences of a fall to the sea. Vests were aboard. In the event that the crew would have put the work vest on, the thrust force generated by the firing of the device could have allowed his release or, in the worst case, the recovery of his body.4. The choice of the particular model of vest was made without taking into account the characteristics of work aboard the F/B LUCERO UNO. The crew was not in favor of putting on the work vests available to them on board because, in their opinion, were uncomfortable and likely to snag the fishing gear.5. The evaluation of occupational hazards of the ship was not well done.

CAUGHT FIRE AT VANINO, RUSSIA PM ON 21/08/13. DAMAGED BEYOND ECONOMICAL REPAIR AND TOWED TO SOVETSKAYA GAVAN, RUSSIA IN SEPTEMBER 2013 FOR BREAKING UP.
BLAZE EXTINGUISHED WITH ASSISTANCE FROM LOCAL FIRE SERVICES. NO INJURIES REPORTED. EXTENT OF DAMAGE UNKNOWN. INSPECTION EFFECTED.

On 27 July 2013 Cable Laying vessel “CS FU HAI” sailed from HONG KONG for south of AI-NAN TAO, about 360nm South West of HONG KONG. As per the client’s requirement this cable was to be laid south of HAI-NAN TAO, South China Sea which was loaded at port of Nan Tong on some earlier date. 
By midnight of 29 July the vessel arrived near the work site and then maintained her position at 18˚ 24.3´N 110˚ 04.3´E using DP mode. 
The cable laying operation including its burial by plough commenced on 30 July in morning hours. At 1800hrs the vessel was in position 18˚ 21.36´N 110˚ 08.38´E. 
On 31 July at 1800hrs the vessel was in position 18˚ 18.68´N 110˚ 11.99´E, continuing cable laying operation. The operation continued day and night using starboard side LCE system with some stoppages due to adverse weather or equipment break downs. Crew worked in 12hrs on 12hrs off in rotation and relieved each other for meals. 
On 20 August, at 0600hrs the vessel was in position17˚ 48.30´N 110˚ 44.1´E and maintained this position till noon. Crew was engaged in splicing the cable. 
Due to change of cable specification with larger diameter the master decided to lay it by DCE using port side equipments and chute. As per instructions of master at 1715hrs, the crew started preparing to shift the cable from starboard side system of LCE to port side on DCE which was of higher SWL. 
The cable shifting required good seamanship practice and experience. It was being performed for the first time on board and there was no laid down Cable Shifting Procedures. 
The shifting of cable was carried out under the supervision of Chief Officer. Communication was maintained with bridge. The weather experienced during this time was moderate sea and swell with good visibility. 
Deck crew prepared to shift the cable by initially taking the load of the cable, using Siemens stopper of 7 ton SWL. The stopper was secured to cable by wrapping it around with the gripping band fastened at open end of stopper. The super line was then passed through eye of Siemens stopper with its one end secured to bollard and other end taken to capstan for lowering or heaving up cable as required. 
After the stopper was well fastened around the cable, the weight was taken by super line. The cable from inboard side was then slackened and laid on port side. Incidentally around 1813 hours the cable 
slipped through the stopper with excessive force and 3 Crew members who were standing within the bight of the rope were hit by the moving cable. The impact of slipping out cable to sea was so sudden that one of the crew within the bight of the cable fell so severely that he died on the spot and other two were seriously injured. 
The vessel immediately suspended the cable laying operation and headed for medical aid towards port of refuge. On 21 August morning vessel reached port Sanya and the casualties were landed and taken to hospital.

The vessel has reported to have ran aground whilst maneuvering out of the Richards Bay Port break water.
Cracks were reported to have developed from 4 Port DB extending to the main deck and in the cross decks on main deck  between 
No. 7 and No. 8 cargo hold.
All the crew has been evacuated safely from the vessel  . No pollution has been reported so far.
We are checking possible options for salvage and oil pollution prevention companies .

On the afternoon of 17 August 2013 the 24m, 62gt, privately owned motor yacht Isamar struck the Grand écueil d’Olmeto shoal while on passage from Bonifacio, Corsica to Roccapina bay. The three crew were unable to halt the flooding, but were able to abandon the vessel with the eight passengers before Isamar foundered in 55m of water.
On 17 August 2013 at 12:13hrs (LT) the vessel H PIONEER was subject to an attack bombing at the port of Umm Qasar, Iraq.

STRANDED ON SEAWALL AFTER BREAKING MOORINGS AT GANSBAAI, SOUTH AFRICA ON 17/08/13 IN HEAVY WEATHER. DAMAGED BEYOND ECONOMICAL REPAIR.
SUSTAINED SERIOUS DAMAGE TO HULL AND TOOK WATER IN ENGINE ROOM. NO INJURIES OR POLLUTION REPORTED.

ShipsInvolved: ST. THOMAS OF AQUINAS (IMO 7304663), SULPICIO EXPRESS SIETE (IMO 7724344)
SOLASStatus: ST. THOMAS OF AQUINAS: Unknown/unspecified, SULPICIO EXPRESS SIETE: Unknown/unspecified
Location: Central City of Cebu - around 2km (1.2 miles) from the shore
SummaryOfEvents:
The Philippine passenger ST. THOMAS OF AQUINAS was officially carrying 644 passengers and 106 crew, when she sank after colliding with Philippine General Cargo Ship SULPICIO EXPRESS SIETE on Friday 16 August 2013 at approximately 21:00 hour, local time, near the central city of Cebu, around 2km (1.2 miles) from the shore.  
The collision happened when ST. THOMAS OF AQUINAS was approaching the port late on Friday.
SULPICIO EXPRESS SIETE had 36 crew members on board and she did not sink.
MRCC Manila (Philippine Coast Guard) confirmed that 71 bodies were recovered and 750 people were rescued, 49 people are still missing, some of them possibly trapped inside the vessel that sank in waters about 33 metres (100ft) deep.
3 Coast Guard and 2 Navy ships and divers helped with the rescue, but the operation has been hampered by rough seas.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

Location: APPROXIMATELY 200 MILES NORTHEAST OF TRINIDAD CIRCA
SummaryOfEvents:
CAUGHT FIRE IN ENGINE ROOM AND SUBSEQUENTLY SANK IN THE ATLANTIC OCEAN APPROXIMATELY 200 MILES NORTHEAST OF TRINIDAD CIRCA 16/08/13.
ALL 16 CREW ABANDONED SHIP TO LIFERAFT AND WERE RESCUED 4 DAYS LATER BY MT 'STENA SUNRISE'. NO SERIOUS INJURIES REPORTED. SUBSEQUENTLY TRANSFERRED TO FV 'SHINSHU MARU NO. 62' AND TAKEN TO TRINIDAD.

Location: 80 kilometres south-west of Hong Kong, China
SummaryOfEvents:
On 14 August 2013 at 10:33 hours (local time), Hong Kong, China MRCC received a DSC alert from the ship TRANS SUMMER.  She was listed about 20 degrees to port and the situation was worsening.  The Master was about to declare “abandon ship”.  The controller of Hong Kong, China MRCC informed Hong Kong Government Flying Services (GFS) of the incident and requested to render assistance.  GuangDong RCC was also informed of the case.

GFS tasked two rescue helicopters and one fixed wing plane, which arrived on scene at 11:37 hours. Nineteen crew members were picked up from the life raft  and at sea by the GFS helicopters and taken to Hong Kong, China.  The other two crew members were picked up by the Chinese rescue boat NAN HAIR RESCUE 116 and sent to Zhuhai, China.  All crew members were in sound condition.  The ship TRANS SUMMER finally capsized and sank.

Tropical cyclone, Utor was in the vicinity.  Winds were S to SE, at a forece of 9 – 10.  The sea was very rough with visibility less than 1000 meters due to heavy rain.

Location: South Berth B, Funabashi Chuo Wharf, Chiba Pref., Japan
InitialEvent: Fatal accident of a stevedore during unloading operation
SummaryOfEvents: While unloading operation on the cargo ship WELLINGTON STAR berthing at South Berth B, a stevedore was crushed by a container. He was taken to a hospital, but was confirmed dead at the hospital.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Ship remains fit to proceed

Location: 84 km from the coast of the Ceara State
SummaryOfEvents: The fire starts in the engine room without control and the ship sank.

Consequences1: Serious injuries,Ship rendered unfit to proceed

SummaryOfEvents: On the sailing trip from Rif to Keflavig / Iceland, the ship began to take on water. Pumps could not pump out the water, because there was too much water in the boat. The crew was rescued by the Coast Guard and a nearby fishing boat. The ship sank. Total loss, no injuries.
Consequences1: Pollution,Ship rendered unfit to proceed,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents: After waiting to anchor, the bulk carrier Dubai Faith, with the pilot on board was manoeuvring to go alongside in the Brest harbour (the n6 E/W pier). The ship, proceeding east had to swing to go portside alongside. While swinging, the ship didn't succeed checking and collided with the pier, damaging one crane. The ship was temporarily repaired in Brest. Definitive repairs were done later within 4 months. Later on, the master declared that he had not been sufficiently informed about local conditions. The pilot did not share his point of view. Nobody was injured. A shore crane was damaged. Despite numerous attempts, it has never been possible to communicate with the owner, nor use VDR for the investigation.

On 08-08-2013 at 0953 LT at Panama Canal (09°11.45’N, 79°37.30’W), the Seaman 2 together with other deck hands of Hong Kong, China Registered M.V. “Joyous Society” were preparing the combination ladder for canal line handlers and pilots disembarkation. When the Seaman 2 stepped on the lower perform of the ladder to fasten the safety rope of the ladder, he fell into the water and was found missing. Search and rescue operations were conducted by the vessel crew members as well as the local authority but the missing crew was found dead later.

Location: South African, Goukamma Estuary; Knysna/Mossel Bay Area
SummaryOfEvents:
The general cargo vessel Kiani Satu was engaged in worlwide unscheduled voyage charters
The vessel departed from Ho Chi Ming City (Vietnam) on 10 July 2013 and was bound for Ghana/West Africa. Kiani Satu was fully loaded with 15.000 tons of rice in bags.
The first 25 days of the sea voyage passed uneventful when on 3 August in the morning an engine room alarm indicated an dangerous overheating in the main engine.  As a first measure the revolutions of the main engine wer reduced and eventually stopped after a closer look revealed that the main engine was suffering a scavenge air fire.
The fire and  source of the overheating was successfully repelled,  but the main engine could not be restarted.
As the vessel was drifting towards the South African East Coast the situation needed solving.
 After drifting for almost 5 days the vessel finally ran aground in the morning hours on 8 August 2013 near Knysna, on a prestine beach in a nature reserve area. Earlier attemps of the master to keep the vessel in position about 30 miles off the coast with both anchors dropped failed after the vessel dragged both anchors as the weather rappidly deteriorated.
Already an earlier attempt to safe the vessel had failed. An offshore supply vessel (OSV) orderd by the company after an emergency call from the master, could not establish a connection. Heavy weather with strong winds and violent seas made it impossible to connet the tow. After several attemps to rig the towing gear failed and the working conditions for the crew on the forecastle of Kiani Satu became unsafe the attempts were aborted.

The Kiani Satu crew remained unharmed and were all airlifted to shore with first daylight on 8 August 2013. 
To avert an environmental catastrophy in the sensetive coastal region the South African Marine Safety Agency (SAMSA) ordered a suitable salvage tug on-scene, which was able to establish connection to the grounded Kiani Satu on 12 August 2013. 
On 17 August 2013 the structurally damaged Kiani Satu was refloated after an experienced salvage team in cooperation with helicopter support had invested ongoing efforts to free the vessel from the beach.
SAMSA directed the managers of Kiani Satu to remove the vessel from the South African Exclusive Economic Zone by the next day. Consequently, the salvage tug  towed the casualty away from the coast during the 17th and continued to do so on 18 till 20 August. On 21 August 2013 Kiani Satu sank in a position about 98 miles off the coast in a water depth of about 1000 meters.
Due to the lotal loss of the vessel this accident is a very serious marine caualty as per the Casualty Code for which consequently a marine safety investigation shall be conducted.The flag State of Kiani Satu has reached agreement with the substantially interested coastal State South Affrica to jointly conduct this investigation, whereby Antigua & Barbuda Investigation Unit  has taken the lead.

0430hrs 07/Aug : Duty AB saw OS was Iying in his bed.
0450hrs 07/Aug : Deck Cadet missing OS in his cabin.
0455hrs 07/Aug : Duty AB checked his cabin and found missing OS.
0505hrs 07/Aug : Call all crew for searching OS and continued searching him.

A collision between a small pleasure boat (5 meters) and a passenger ship occurred in Marseille's bay. As a result, a woman on board the passenger ship broke her arm and another one suffered pain in the head. Both of them were taken to hospital.
Consequences1: Serious injuries,Ship remains fit to proceed

SummaryOfEvents: At 18:38 hrs on 5 August 2013, the twin-rig stern trawler Prospect grounded on Skibby Baas Rocks in the north entrance to Lerwick Harbour while on passage towards its intended fishing grounds. The hull was penetrated, causing the fish hold to immediately flood. The pumps were unable to cope with the water ingress and, after Prospect floated free from the rocks on the rising tide; the ship adopted an angle of loll. The skipper and three crewmen transferred to the Lerwick all-weather lifeboat (ALB) as its crew prepared to take Prospect under tow with the aid of the Lerwick Port Authority's (LPA) tug Knab. A short time later Prospect foundered in 15m of water. There were no injuries or pollution. The ship was salvaged but declared a constructive total loss.

On 3 August, a fire started on board the trawler "Cygogne" engaged in fishing operations. The crew did not extinguish it. The crew abandoned the ship in its rescue boat. Later a helicopter evacuated everybody safely. Shortly after the rescue tugboat tried several times to control it without any result. On 4 August the ship sank.
Consequences1: Ship rendered unfit to proceed,Total loss of the ship

Location: ILE DES SERPENTS IN THE ATLANTIC OCEAN 3 MILES SOUTHWEST OF DAKAR, SENEGAL
SummaryOfEvents:
STRANDED ON THE ILE DES SERPENTS IN THE ATLANTIC OCEAN 3 MILES SOUTHWEST OF DAKAR, SENEGAL IN LAT. 14 39N., LONG. 017 28W., AT 0530 HOURS LT ON 02/08/13. WRECK ABANDONED IN SITU.
DEVELOPED LIST TO STARBOARD. ALL CREW RESCUED. NO INJURIES REPORTED. APPROXIMATELY 100 TONS OF BUNKER FUEL SPILLED INTO SEA. REFLOATING ATTEMPTS BY LOCAL TUGS UNSUCCESSFUL. FISHERIES PATROL VESSEL 'BAYE SOGUI' MONITORED THE INCIDENT. SUBSEQUENTLY CAUGHT FIRE IN ACCOMMODATION.
DART grounded because the wachkeeping mate had fallen to sleep just before a waypoint. Neither bridge watch alarm or ECDIS alarm sounded before the grounding.

Location: 80 MILES NORTH OF THE FAROE ISLANDS
SummaryOfEvents:
TOOK WATER IN ENGINE ROOM, LISTED AND SUBSEQUENTLY SANK WHILST FISHING IN THE ICELAND SEA 80 MILES NORTH OF THE FAROE ISLANDS IN LAT. 63 30N., LONG. 007 27W., AT 0815 HOURS LT ON 31/07/13.
ALL 9 CREW ABANDONED SHIP TO LIFERAFTS AND SUBSEQUENTLY RESCUED BY FV 'SJAGAKLETTUR' AND TAKEN TO VESTMANNA, FAROES. NO INJURIES REPORTED.

C ONCISE DESCRIPTION On July 31, 2013 , at 00:13 hours (local time), two miles off the port of Alcudia (Mallorca ) when in passage from Ciutadella ( Menorca), a deflagration (explosion) occurred in the starboard side Engine Room of the HSC JAUME I. The blast, not noticed by the crew at first, caused bulkhead destruction, two breaches in the hull and a fire that set off alarms of ship and forced the captain to activate fire fighting procedures . The situation was solved with the commitment of the crew and with the means available on board, but further assistance was sought from Alcudia s Pilot and also from SAR services, sending the port tug PUNTA TORRE and the rescue boat SALVAMAR SAIPH. These both boats accompanied HSC JAUME I and offered towing services and scorted the ship to her berth. The ship was docked in the port of Alcudia around three in the morning. No injured neither pollution of the marine environment was produced as a result during the accident. The vessel suffered serious damages that immobilised her for months. ORIGIN OF ACCIDENT Investigation soon pointed to a crack on the low pressure DO feeding pipe for cyl. n 16 of starboard inner main engine (SIME). It caused the DO to be spreaded out into the atmosphere of the E/R and allow the development of an explosive atmosphere. CAUSES 1) Material analysis of broken pipe showed that the immediate cause for the break was due to excessive vibration during an unknown period of time. 2) It was found also that an anti-vibration clip for named pipe was missing. This clip was part of the original setting of the motor. Its absence explains the increased number of cycles of the sectioned pipe. 3) It is the CIAIM s belief that this piece missing happened in an indefinite moment in the past, but not immediate to the accident. Inspection, control and maintenance works carried out in the engine room by crew and shore based workshop staff did not detected its absence and there were not procedures adopted to survey and or inspect thoroughly these clips. 4) The DO projection consequent to the breakage of the pipe could have been avoided if the motor would have been fitted with efficient containment means. OTHER CONSIDERATIONS 5) The shot of emergency fuel stop to affected areas was decisive to fight the fire, as well as the control by cooling with fire hoses of the adjacent spaces carried out by crew. 6) Despite it would be useless due to the openings burst out by the explosion in the E/R, it is convenient to point out that the control signal placed in the Bridge for the remote shot of the fixed fire-fighting system (CO2) was interrupted when the electric wires that should transmit the signal were destroyed by the explosion. Such wires were going back, once departed from the CO2 room, through a service trunk adjacent to the E/R, the space to be protected, among other controls instead of being set-up directly to Bridge. The explosion did not affect the CO2 room itself neither its parts.

STRUCK JETTY WHILST DISCHARGING FUEL OIL AT AN OIL TERMINAL AT TERNATE, INDONESIA AND SUBSEQUENTLY PARTIALLY SANK AFTER BEING HIT BY A LARGE WAVE AM ON 31/07/13.
UNKNOWN QUANTITY OF OIL LEAKED FROM DAMAGED NO. 5 CARGO TANK INTO SEA CREATING A 1 KILOMETRE OIL SLICK. ALL CREW EVACUATED THE VESSEL. NO INJURIES REPORTED. OIL DISPERSANT USED TO CONTROL POLLUTION. TEMPORARY REPAIRS EFFECTED BY DIVERS. VESSEL PARTIALLY SANK BY STERN. REMAINING CARGO OF OIL AND BUNKER FUEL REMOVED BY SALVORS SMIT SALVAGE. REFLOATED WITH ASSISTANCE FROM FLOATING CRANE 'SMIT CYCLONE' ON 20/12/13.
REPORTED CANCELLED FROM GHANA REGISTRY AS A 'CONSTRUCTIVE TOTAL LOSS' ON 30/07/13.

Short after departure Røst passenger ferry Værøy lost engine power. The ships speed at that time was 15 knots. After the speed had decreased the crew dropped both anchors. 15 minutes later main engine restarted and the vessel continued the voyage. The main engine stopped due to missed air overpressaure in the engineromm. This was caused by to doors opened at the same time. No damages or injuries.

The m/v " Perseus " on 28.07.2013 at approximately 05 am. european time sailled via Kiel Channel with pilot on board. At 05:18 am. saw a tug with pontoon loaded with cabel reels blocking the channel's fairway and approaching its' northern shore. The distance between the two vessels m/v " Perseus " and tug " Westsund " was approximately 100 meters. m/v "Perseus" commenced work whit main engine full speed astern, but m/v " Perseus " has a peculiarity: when ship is moving asrern, the fore moves to the right. At 05:21 am. the collision occurred. The collision was not accompanied by a strong hit due to the minimum forward inertia movement of vessel. The tug at that moment has reached the norther channel shore and was motionless. The towed object and a small tug behind it, unable to keep the pontoon on the fairway, have blocked almost the channels' entire motorway. The m/v " Perseus " stem has hit the tug's starboard side. The speed at the moment of collision was no more than 3 knots. As per  tug " Vestsund " master  information that tug no damage was done. At 06:15 am. m/v " Perseus " has moored in port Brunsbuttel the giving explanatio to the Germany water police.

A taxi boat and a pleasure craft collided outside the city of Kragerø during night time Saturday 27.july 2013. Three persons in the pleasure craft endured severe injuries, whereas two where later recovered drowned. None of the drivers spotted each other in time to avoid the collision within the 12-15 seconds there was clear sight between the boats. Lights ashore and on the boats could have had an impact on the drivers situational awareness. The taxi boat had a defect port side nav.light. At the same time the recreational vessel was hidden in a blind zone created by the taxi boats window frame. The driver of the pleasure craft had consumed some alcohol, later analysed with a blood level of 0.8.

Sometime after the fishing boat EL PEN arrived from sea, her crew was still o/b discharging the catches of the day. Suddenly, they realized that the boat was sinking. They tried to bail out the water using buckets, as the automatic pump the boat was fitted with was unable to pump out all the water. The boat spent between 20 and 30 minutes in sinking totally. Once the boat was put afloat the rubber colector from sea chest to GS pump suction was found disconnected from this suction and lying on the bottom of the boat. The GS pump is located at a higher position and, therefore the collector fell to the bottom of the boat and the water flew directly into the boat from the sea through the sea chest valve and the collector. No recommendations have been arised.

At 0219 on 25 July 2013, the tanker Apollo was rounding Tilburyness, River Thames, in a strong tidal flow when it left its intended track and made contact with the quayside at the Northfleet Hope Container Terminal. The vessel and the quayside both sustained significant damage as a result of the accident. Apollo was fully loaded with almost 22,000 tonnes of gas oil for discharge at the Vopak Terminal, West Thurrock. The vessel’s bridge team consisted of two Port of London Authority pilots, the master, who had returned to the bridge just before the accident, the officer of the watch and a helmsman.
At the time of the accident one of the pilots was undertaking a practical examination and, although he had the conduct of the vessel, he was not authorised to pilot a vessel of Apollo’s length and draught.
Apollo was fitted with a controllable pitch propeller, but neither pilot was aware of this before the accident. As Apollo rounded Tilburyness the propeller pitch was briefly set to zero, after which the vessel veered off course and made contact with the quayside.

Location: 0.7 NM North west  of the Big Sovereign Off Oysterhaven
SummaryOfEvents:
The vessel, a 42 metres Dutch registered sail training ship, of steel construction
and brig rigged, was anchored in Oysterhaven Anchorage, Co. Cork at about
14.00 hrs on the 23rd July 2013. On-board on arrival at Oysterhaven were the
Master and permanent crew of three, a temporary cook, a mentor and 24
trainees/passengers. The trainees ranged in age from 15 to 24 and eight were
Irish nationals. Of the remaining trainees four were Dutch nationals, three were
UK nationals, six were French nationals, two were Belgian nationals and one was
a Spanish national.
On the 24th July it was planned that the ship would be one of the flotilla of
boats taking part in a sailing festival between Oysterhaven and Kinsale.
The ship hauled anchor at 11.00 hrs and proceeded out of Oysterhaven, using
engine power. At about 11.35 hrs sails were being hauled and the course was
altered. Whilst hauling sails the engine was still being used and the ship
proceeded in a SW direction at a speed of approximately 3 knots.
At approximately 11.40 hrs the engine failed and the ship was unable to sail out
of the situation that grounded the ‘Astrid’ on the coast 0.7 NM North West of the
Big Sovereign.
Rescue services were alerted and all trainees and crew were safely evacuated
and landed into Kinsale, without any injuries being sustained. The ship sank but
was subsequently salvaged and deemed an economic write-off.

It was observed that the fresh water tank cleaning heater's temperature was rising, even though the main valve for the steam leading to heater was shut completely. So it was planned to check the condition of the valve. 
At the very first tool box meeting was carried out and a risk assessment for the same was done, and al! the members involved with the job were briefed. Before starting with the job the following steam valves were shut:
1. Deck steam main valve & warm up valve in the Engine Room
2. Main valve, return valve & bypass (warm up) of deck steam in the pump room
3. By pass valve of the fresh water heater.
Line drained for 40 minute making sure that there was no steam or water in the line. Then 2nd engineer, chief officer, pump man and fitter started to remove the main steam valve leading to fresh water heater. The valve was removed and there was no trace of steam and water, 2nd engineer was cleaning the gasket around the area suddenly a small gush of hot water around for 3-4 seconds ran into 2nd engineers body.
Cold water was ready at the site and he was completely flushed with water.

SOLASStatus: Fifi: Unknown/unspecified, FIFI: Unknown/unspecified, Perle Noire: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents:
Le 15 juillet 2013 deux touristes, une mère et sa fille, décident de louer une  embarcation de plaisance sans permis à une société de location installée sur le port de  Marseillan (étang de Thau), face à leur hôtel. 
 
Après présentation, par le loueur, des zones et des règles de navigation sur l’étang et  explication du mode d’utilisation du moteur électrique équipant les embarcations, les deux  femmes appareillent pour une matinée de balade sur l’étang et se dirigent vers l’entrée du canal  du midi, située au sud-ouest. 
Moins d’une heure après leur départ, elles appellent le loueur par téléphone portable  pour lui indiquer qu’elles ne parviennent pas à redémarrer le moteur. 
Quelques instants plus tard, alors que leur embarcation a dérivé aux abords du  chenal qui mène à la mer et qui jouxte l’entrée du canal du midi, celle-ci est violemment abordée  sur l’avant bâbord par la barge conchylicole PERLE NOIRE. Le patron de la barge ressent le choc,  se retourne et voit l’embarcation dans son sillage. Il fait marche arrière pour lui porter  assistance, mais la plus jeune des passagères a été mortellement blessée par une des hélices  de la barge. 
Le patron de la barge appelle les pompiers et entreprend un remorquage vers le port  de Marseillan, à la rencontre des pompiers. Le CROSS La Garde est prévenu par le CODIS 34.

On 15 July 2013  containership HANSA BRANDENBURG was headed from Singapore to Durban when an explosion in her cargo hold caused a fire at 07:30hrs (LT).  The fire spread rapidly and the crew was forced to abandon ship at 07:40hrs (LT).  The vessel DONAU TRADER rescued the crew at 09:08hrs (LT).

July 11, 2013 0738hrs – Vessel commence voyage from east of horsbourgh lighthouse to Chittagong, Bangledesh
July 14, 2013 1525hrs – Vessel passing Malaysia waters when fire in turbocharger exploded in engine room
July 14, 2013 1530hrs- Master dropped anchor and commenced boundary cooling, crew assemble port side, 4th Engineer not accounted for
July 14, 2013 1620hrs – Master received call from ECR, 4th Engineer trapped inside. Rescue party not able to enter due to immense heat and fire from ER.
July 14, 2013 1650hs – Master ordered port lifeboat to be ready at forward of vessel
July 14, 2013 1700hrs – Malaysia Marine Department approached vessel
July 14, 2013 1830hrs – All crew began disembark vessel
July 14, 2013 1930hrs – MMD boat began towing lifeboat to Kukup terminal, Malaysia
July 14, 2013 2030hrs – Crew arrived at Kukup Terminal, Malaysia
July 14, 2013 – Fire-fighting tug (AST ANCHORER) continued fire-fighting.
July 20, 2013 – MMD declared vessel safe to board. Body removed from vessel.
On 14 July 2013 at 01:00hrs (LT) while in berthing operations the vessel VEGA AQUILA made contact with the pier in Taranto, Italy.

Location: MALACCA STRAIT 19 MILES SOUTHWEST OF PULAU JARAK, MALAYSIA
SummaryOfEvents:
SANK AFTER COLLISION WITH UNKNOWN VESSEL IN THE MALACCA STRAIT 19 MILES SOUTHWEST OF PULAU JARAK, MALAYSIA IN LAT. 03 43N., LONG. 100 00E., AT 2240 HOURS LT ON 12/09/13.
ALL 30 CREW ABANDONED SHIP TO 2 LIFERAFTS AND WERE RESCUED BY MV 'APL ILLINOIS' WITHIN 3 HOURS. NO INJURIES REPORTED. SURVIVORS TRANSFERRED TO MALAYSIAN MARITIME AGENCY VESSEL AND TAKEN TO KAMPUNG ACEH, MALAYSIA FOR MEDICAL CHECKS.

Location: 46 MILES SOUTH OF NAMHAE ISLAND, SOUTH KOREA
SummaryOfEvents:
REPORTED AN EXPLOSION IN CARGO HOLD AND SUBSQUENTLY SANK IN THE KOREA STRAIT 46 MILES SOUTH OF NAMHAE ISLAND, SOUTH KOREA IN LAT. 33 59N., LONG. 128 07E., AT 1630 HOURS LT ON 12/07/13.
NEARBY MV 'FESCO DIOMID' CAME TO ASSIST AND RESCUED 9 CREW WHO WERE SUBSEQUENTLY TRANSPORTED TO YEOSU, SOUTH KOREA BY HELICOPTER. 1 CREW MEMBER REPORTED MISSING. KOREAN COAST GUARD DESPATCHED PATROL BOAT TO ASSIST WITH SAR OPERATION.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

ShipsInvolved: HARMONY RISE (IMO 9038074), PANAMAX BLESSING  (-), PANAMAX BLESSING (IMO 9085869)
SOLASStatus: HARMONY RISE: Unknown/unspecified, PANAMAX BLESSING : Unknown/unspecified, PANAMAX BLESSING: Unknown/unspecified
Location: COASTAL WATER (WITHIN 12 MILES) REPUBLIC OF KOREA
SummaryOfEvents: THE SUBJECT VESSEL MADE A COLLISION WITH THE MN PANAMAX BLESSING (GT ABT 40000MT) AT ULSAN SEA AREA OF KOREA ON 0504 L ,10TH JULY 2013 THAT M/V HARMONY RISE HAD TOTALLY SINKING. NOBODY INJURED AND MISSING.

CAUGHT FIRE IN ENGINE ROOM 13 MILES NORTH OF COLON, PANAMA IN LAT. 09 34N., LONG. 079 51W., AT 0300 HOURS LT ON 10/07/13. REPORTED DAMAGED BEYOND ECONOMICAL REPAIR.
CREW ATTEMPTED FIREFIGHTING BUT BLAZE SOON SPREAD TO THE MAIN DECK AND SUPERSTRUCTURE. CREW ABANDONED SHIP TO LIFERAFT AND WERE LATER RESCUED BY PATROL BOAT DESPATCHED BY THE AUTHORITIES. NO INJURIES REPORTED. TUG 'CAPO NOLI' STOOD BY TO ASSIST. BLAZE EXTINGUISHED AND SUBSEQUENTLY TOWED TO CARTAGENA, COLOMBIA FOR INSPECTION. SUSTAINED SEVERE DAMAGE TO ENGINE ROOM AND SUPERSTUCTURE.

SOLASStatus: BLUE MOON: SOLAS, ZHONG GUO YU ZHENG: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents: On 10 July 2013 the vessel BLUE MOON was transiting in the Zhou Shan District sea area and without knowing collided with a fishing vessel, ZHONG GOU YU ZHENG. BLUE MOON sustained two dents on the bow. The ZHONG GUO YU ZHENG sank following the collision.

On the 10th of July 2013, at the port of Igoumenitsa, Ro-Pax "Sorrento" (flag of Italy, IMO No:9264312), was about to depart for Patras, at about 02:00. When heaving of the anchor began at about 02:08 an accident at the ship's internal fixed car deck ramp was reported. According to statements the truck driver was passing through the accessible space between the front cabin of a tractor semi-trailer and the rear of a tractor semi -trailer that were parked in line when suddenly the latter shifted backwards into the casualty. The truck driver was cornered by the shifting tractor semi-trailer onto the front of the cabin of the truck tractor suffering fatal injuries. His death was almost immediate as he was actually violently pinned between the two trucks.

SUMMARY The fishing vessel (F/V) CISNE SEGUNDO ran aground at 16:20 local time on July 8, 2013 at a shoal stone north of the Dragonera Island (Mallorca). As a result of the coup broke the hull at the stem causing a leak that lead in sinking of the vessel while being towed to port. No personal injuries were reported. CONCLUSIONS The Commission has concludedthat theaccident occurreddue to thelack of effectivemonitoring of navigationby themaster of the fishing vessel.Other causesas triggersof the factsare not appreciated . Althoughthere is no assurance, it is possible that no one was exercising a proper navigational watch.The possibility that the vessel were navigating with a crew of three instead of four, without complying with the terms of Navigation Permit, could motivate the Skipper would focus his attention on other tasks on board, unable to pay due attention to navigation. S AFETY RECOMMENDATIONS No recommendations have been made up.
Consequences1: Ship rendered unfit to proceed,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents: On board the tuna fishing boat (fishing rod and seine) proceeding back to port of call, a Spanish scientist fell on arrows (those arrows are used to mark the tuna fish). The scientist was badly injured in the throat by 6 arrows and was taken to hospital. After some concern about his survival, he recovered.

SANK AFTER INGRESS OF WATER WHILST MOORED IN THE INDIAN OCEAN 60 MILES SOUTHWEST OF HOBYA, SOMALIA IN LAT. 04 36N., LONG. 048 05E., ON 07/07/13 IN HEAVY WEATHER.
VESSEL HAD BEEN ANCHORED UNDER CONTROL OF SOMALI PIRATES SINCE BEING HIJACKED ON 26/11/10. 11 CREW TRANSFERRED TO FV 'NAHAM 3'. 4 CREW MISSING. VESSEL HAD STARTED TAKING WATER A WEEK PREVIOUSLY AFTER SUSTAINING MECHANICAL PROBLEMS. WRECK RESTING ON SEABED WITH ACCOMMODATION BLOCK STILL ABOVE WATER.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents:
On 06 July 2013, at about 1100, the second engineer on board the oil tanker Seasong commenced the overhaul of one of the boiler’s main steam valves. 

The second engineer loosened each of the six bolts holding the valve bridge to the valve body and gradually lifted it to ensure that any entrapped steam and hot condensate is released gradually and safely. 

Seeing that the release of steam had died down, the second engineer moved closer to the main steam valve to lift the valve bridge clear from the valve body. 

Suddenly, hot water escaped from the valve housing and spilled over both legs of the second engineer.  As a result of the spill, the second engineer suffered burn injuries, which required hospitalisation. 

The safety investigation found that the immediate cause of the accident was the escape of steam and hot condensate water which had remained entrapped in the system.

SOLASStatus: BARU SATU: Unknown/unspecified, KATHERINE: Unknown/unspecified, KATHERINE: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents: Jul 4 -- Bulk carrier Katherine (17255 gt, built 1997) came in contact with bulk carrier Baru Satu (9978 gt, built 2001), in the Kafirea Strait, seven nautical miles south-west of Andros Island, at 0330 hrs, today. Due to the incident, Katherine sustained a breach and consequently experienced severe water ingress. Following the incident, 17 crew members abandoned the vessel and took onto life rafts, while six crew members remained on board the vessel. Greek Coast Guard vessels are currently at the incident location.

At about 0240 local time on 04 July 2013, a Great Barrier Reef coastal pilot was disembarking from the products tanker Golden Concord when he fell from the pilot ladder. The pilot landed on his feet on the deck of the pilot launch assisted by the deckhand. He sustained no serious injuries.
The fishermen were lifting the fishing gear when it hit a one of them.The fisherman was injured and was evacuated to the hospital byhelicopter. Theman was incapacitated more than 72 hours.

Location: MALACCA STRAIT 55 MILES SOUTH OF PHUKET, THAILAND
SummaryOfEvents:
THE BANGLADESHI-FLAGGED GENERAL CARGO SHIP 'HOPE' TOOK WATER AND DEVELOPED 40 DEGREE LIST IN THE MALACCA STRAIT 55 MILES SOUTH OF PHUKET, THAILAND IN LAT. 07 03N., LONG. 098 19E., AT 0020 HOURS LT ON 04/07/13 IN HEAVY WEATHER. SUBSEQUENTLY BROKEN UP IN 2014.

17 CREW ABANDONED SHIP. MV 'BUXMOON' PROCEEDED TO ASSIST AND RESCUED 5 CREW FROM A LIFEBOAT. 1 OTHER CREW MEMBER RESCUED BY THAI NAVY S-76 HELICOPTER AND TAKEN TO PHUKET WITH MINOR INJURIES. 3 MORE CREW SUBSEQUENTLY RESCUED AND 2 BODIES RECOVERED. 6 CREW MISSING. SAR OPERATION EFFECTED BY NAVAL SHIPS AND AIRCRAFT. ABANDONED DRIFTING VESSEL WAS TAKEN IN TOW OF TUG 'CONFIDENCE' ARRIVING AT LANGKAWI, MALAYSIA ON 10/07/13.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents: While boarding Atlantic Princess from a pilot launch a joining crewman fell from the pilot ladder to the deck of the launch below.  He was taken ashore for medical treatment but died of his injuries.

Bulk carrier, M.V. “FU SHENG HAI”, laden general cargoes of 41,521.066 M/T with  plywood & steel products, left from Lianyungang, China about 2300 hours on 30th  June 2013  bound for Busan, Korea in order to load some more steel cargo shipment. 
Subsequent dates, the vessel approached to southern out-harbor anchorage on 2nd  July 2013. 
As passing harbor limit of Busan, Master came into bridge at 2000 hours when 3/0, AB &  A/O were in duty in bridge and then proceed to Busan harbor anchorage to drop anchor under  Master’s command. 
At 2030 hours on same date, the vessel passed to Busan VTS limit with her course 356  degrees & her speed 11.5 knots, and reported to VTS center and then was instructed by VTS  to drop anchor at N-4 anchorage upon arrival. 
When the vessel approached to N-4 anchorage at 2100 hours with maneuvering speed &  course, it was found to be too crowded around the N-4 anchorage and Master requested VTS  to re-allocate another anchorage and in turn VTS instructed the vessel to drop anchor N-5  anchorage with keeping 4 cables distance to other vessels. 
Approaching to the N-5 anchorage, the Master ordered to stand by 4 crews, such as C/O,  Bosun, two AB, on forecastle deck for dropping anchor operation and reduced speed at 2103  hours. However when the vessel arrived at N-5 anchorage, the Master found the intended  anchoring position to be also crowded with nearby 4 vessels being too close and encountered  with rough sea, Beaufort scale 6-8b of wind & wave in S’ly direction & poor visibility with  less of 500 meters due to dense fog & drizzle. 
The vessel proceed to find another anchoring position at outer area in N-5 anchorage where is strong current from south, at 2131 hours the VTS urgently instructed the vessel to alter  starboard direction by VHF, however the vessel went aground on rocks of Saeng-Do(Island)  off Yong of Busan at 2137 hours on 2nd  July 2013 at position of Lat. 35-02.14 N & Long. 
129-05.54 E. Before the grounding, the vessel had a draft of 11.0 meters at fore and 11.6 meters at aft. 
At the time of grounding, wind direction was southerly with speed of Beaufort scale 8 and wave direction was southerly with speed of Beaufort scale 7 and visibility was very poor less  of 0.4 miles due to dense fog.   At 2145 hours on 2nd July 2013, the vessel dropped anchor chain to 2 shackles in water and  found double bottom ballast tank to be flood and consequently vessel listed to port side 2  degrees and then at 2155 hours on same date, listed to port side 5 degrees. 
 At 2200 hours on same date, Master reported the situation to VTS center and requested tug boat for rescuing. 
At 0400 hours on 3rd July, some crews except Master, C/E, C/O, 3/O, 1/E, 2/E, Electrician & Motor man (Total 8 crew) were left the vessel. 
At 1900-2000 hours on 4th July, above crews including Master on board were left the vessel. 
On 6th July, The vessel was broken in two (2) pieces in way of No.4 cargo hold and stern section remained aground at the same position and her fore section completely submerged in water.

SOLASStatus: ATLANTIC HERO: SOLAS, ORIENTAL PIONEER: Unknown/unspecified
Location: Approaches to the Singapore Pilot Station
SummaryOfEvents:
At 0530 LT on the 2nd July 2013, the bulk carrier Atlantic Hero collided with the bulk carrier Oriental Pioneer in the approaches to the Eastern Boarding Ground (EBG ‘B’) of the Singapore Pilot station. At the time of the collision, both vessels were in a loaded condition and were inward bound to Singapore to receive bunkers. 

The Atlantic Hero, on passage from Banjarmasin, Indonesia, was approaching the Pilot station from the East in the West bound traffic lane of the Traffic Separation Scheme (TSS). The Oriental Pioneer, on passage from Paranagua Port, Brazil, was approaching the Pilot station from the West and had lined up on a Northerly course that would take her across the West bound traffic lane and place her on the port bow of the Atlantic Hero. 
The collision occurred during the hours of darkness in moderate visibility of approximately 6nm. A light SW breeze was prevailing with a negligible tidal stream.

Although the collision resulted in structural damage to the bow of the Atlantic Hero, the vessel suffered only a minor breach in its watertight integrity. Repairs were conducted in the Singapore Eastern anchorage and the Atlantic Hero was cleared to proceed on passage to Ennore, India at 0500 LT on the 15th July 2013.

As a result of the impact, the Oriental Pioneer suffered a breach in the Starboard side hull plating in way of the Number 1 Fuel Oil tank. Consequently, a pollution incident occurred with approximately 100 MT of Heavy Fuel Oil (HFO) spilling into the sea. During the course of the investigation it became evident that a potentially hazardous situation did exist in that two vessels were planned to arrive at the same position at the same time with neither one aware of the others presence until the last moment. This situation was exacerbated with the distraction of a series of confusing multi-recipient VHF transmissions.

With no clear exchange of information in place, time was spent on clarifying these transmissions, in particular the order of Pilot embarkation rather than monitoring the collision situation that was developing and taking appropriate avoiding action.

Location: BANDA SEA 135 MILES EAST OF KENDARI, SULAWESI, INDONESIA
SummaryOfEvents:
THE INDONESIAN-FLAGGED CONTAINER SHIP 'PEMUDI' FOUNDERED IN THE BANDA SEA 135 MILES EAST OF KENDARI, SULAWESI, INDONESIA ON 02/07/13 IN HEAVY WEATHER.

EPIRB DISTRESS SIGNAL NOT RECEIVED UNTIL 04/07/13. NAVAL AND CIVILIAN SHIPS AND AIRCRAFT EFFECTED SAR OPERATION. 2 CREW RESCUED AND 19 MISSING. CAUSE OF SINKING NOT KNOWN.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

Location: South Pigging Platform, off Soyo Angola
SummaryOfEvents:
The MODU “Perro Negro 6” was moved onto a new location at the Southern Pigging Station jacket off-shore Soyo, at a water depth of approximately 35 metres, at the Congo river mouth canyon, on the 01st July, 2013. The towing supply vessel “Maersk Achiever” remained attached to the main towing bridle on the bow. The rig was elevated to an air gap of approximately 2.5 metres. The port and starboard quarter towing supply vessels were released after the initial elevation of the MODU “Perro Negro 6” from the water.

During preloading operations, the MODU PN6 starboard aft leg punched through the sea bed by approximately 9.0 metres, causing the barge deck to become submerged and sea water to flood the lower deck accommodation, starboard side. The rig was completely abandoned shortly after and later capsized. There were 103 persons onboard at the time of the incident, however during abandonment one (1) person, the deck foreman was unaccounted for and is now presumed ''missing at sea'' after search and rescue attempts by crew were unsuccessful.

On 1 July 2013 at 14:10hrs (LT) an explosion occurred in cargo hold No. 6 of the vessel HELLEIC WIND (IMO# 9132973) while the vessel was in the Bay of Bengal. The explosion happened due to the high dosage of Aluminum Phosphate in a fumigated container. As a result of the explosion, three of the HELLENIC WIND’s crew were injured.
A deck cadet fell overboard while rigging razor wire in preparation for transiting the high risk area off the East African Coast.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Ship remains fit to proceed

Location: IGUSHIK ESTUARY NEAR DILLINGHAM, AK, USA
SummaryOfEvents:
THE FISHING VESSEL 'LONE STAR' SUSTAINED TEAR IN HULL, CAPSIZED AND SANK IN THE IGUSHIK ESTUARY NEAR DILLINGHAM, AK, USA IN LAT. 58 44N., LONG. 158 53W., AT 0655 HOURS LT ON 30/06/13 IN HEAVY SWELL.

ALL 4 CREW WERE RESCUED BY NEARBY MV 'TRADITION' AND TRANSPORTED TO DILLINGHAM. OIL SHEEN OF 4 MILES IN LENGTH REPORTED IN WATER. REPORTED DAMAGE TO HULL OCCURRED WHEN ANCHOR CHAIN FOULED TRANSDUCER AND COOLANT LINES AND PULLED THEM LOOSE. RESOLVE MARINE AWARDED SALVAGE CONTRACT. WRECK REFLOATED AND DRAGGED TO SHORE BY CRANES ON 31/09/13. TEMPORARY REPAIRS EFFECTED AND TOWED TO DUTCH HARBOUR, AK BY TUG 'DOUBLE EAGLE' FOR DISPOSAL.

Location: GULF OF PARIA NEAR ISLA DE PATOS, VENEZUELA
SummaryOfEvents:
THE VENEZUELAN-FLAGGED FISHING VESSEL 'AVENCASA VI' STRANDED IN THE GULF OF PARIA NEAR ISLA DE PATOS, VENEZUELA IN LAT. 10 38N., LONG. 061 50W., AT 2115 HOURS LT ON 29/06/13.

SUSTAINED DAMAGE TO HULL, TOOK WATER AND DEVELOPED LIST. COASTGUARD PATROL BOAT 'PG-407' PROCEEDED TO ASSIST AND RESCUED ALL 7 CREW. SURVIVORS TAKEN TO GUIRIA, VENEZUELA WHERE 2 REQUIRED MEDICAL TREATMENT.

SOLASStatus: COL. H. CARTWRIGHT REID: Unknown/unspecified, STX ACE 7: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents:
MT STX ACE 7 was waiting for bunkers after discharging her cargo at the port of Vishakapatnam. On 26.06.2013, the vessel was advised that she will proceed to receive her bunkers. At 1515 LT, on the same day, the pilot boarded the vessel to take the vessel to a berth for bunkering operation. The vessel was maneuvered to the mooring buoys with the help of her engines and assisted by two tugs, namely, MV Sardar Patel being made fast on for'd bow and the tug  MV Col. H. Cart Reid assisted by pushing at aft section. At 1545 LT, for'd lines were sent to the mooring buoys and at 1555 LT, the for'd tug was cast off. At 1605 LT, the aft tug, Col. H. Cart Reid was released. At 1605, the pilot was away. At 1634 LT, Tug Col. H. Cart Wright Reid was observed to be heading towards the vessel. At 1635 LT, the tug collided with the vessel's starboard bow. The collision resulted in breach of hull at two places , between frame 103 - 105, in way of Fore Pk tank, on the vessel MT STX ACE 7. At the time of the collision, the vessel MT STX ACE 7 was partly moored.
Th primary cause of the collision was the failure of engines of the tug Col. H. Cart Reid.

The fishing vessel O MAR listed to port when she reduced her speed, immediately a blow from the sea made the ship capsized . The two crewmen were rescued by a Maritime Rescue helicopter. On the 3rd of July, the vessel was refloated but due to their significant hull damage was decided not to repair it. The initial listing was caused by flooding through a break of the wet-exhaust pipe.

A fatal accident happened on board at the Hong Kong, China registered bulk carrier Grand Ocean, when she was prepared to anchor at the pilot station of Recalada, Argentina. The anchors were found sticking in the hawse pipe. 1.2	A fitter’s head was injured due to the sudden move of an anchor chain while he was climbing down through the hawse pipe to inspect the anchor sticking.

On 25 June 2013, at 0335, the fire alarm sounded in the engine-room of the Maltese registered passenger ship Zenith.  Upon investigation, a fire was noticed on the starboard father main engine.
 
The seat of the fire was between the turbocharger and cylinder head no. 1.  Immediate actions were taken by the crew members to contain the fire and ensure the safety of all persons on board.
 
The safety investigation identified that the immediate cause of the fire was the fracture of a low carbon steel pipe on a fuel damping cylinder assembly on the starboard father main engine.
 
This fracture led to the release of gas oil, at a pressure of about 6 bars, which sprayed on an exposed high temperature area of the main engine exhaust gas manifold.

SOLASStatus: FLIPPER I: Unknown/unspecified, SAN BENITO: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents: On June 25, 2013 the fishing vessel SAN BENITO was sailing head to NW, towards the port in Arenas de Mar (Barcelona) while the recreational craft FLIPPER I was sailing, head to NE parallel to the cost to the port of Palams (Gerona). At 14:45 one collide to each other. As a consequence the fishing vessel sank and the recreational craft suffered small damages. The two people on board the fishing vessel were rescued by the recreational craft and carried to port.
Consequences1: Ship rendered unfit to proceed,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents: The KRONBORG was traveling on the River la Plata on 24 June 2013 when she came to a curve in the river at 18:12hrs (LT).  Due to the slow speed of the KRONBORG and the strength of the river’s current the ship could not turn in time to avoid colliding with the MEDI NAGASAKI which was headed in the opposite direction of the KRONBORG.

SOLASStatus: NOCC OCEANIC: SOLAS, YUJIN-MARU No.7: Unknown/unspecified
Location: In the southeast waters of Kinkazan, Miyagi Prefecture, Japan
SummaryOfEvents:
The Japanese fishing vessel YUJIN-MARU No.7 was found capsized and broke in two at about 300 km southeast off Kinkazan, Miyagi Pref., Japan. Although eight crew members who were in life raft were rescued, the skipper (Japanese) went missing.
　It was later confirmed that NOCC OCEANIC registered in Marshall Islands collided with YUJIN-MARU No.7.

Location: OFF THE COAST OF PORT OF FINIKE
InitialEvent: Hull failure / failure of watertight doors / ports, etc.
SummaryOfEvents: As a result of water ingress, crew abandoned vessel and the ship sank within hours.

Location: AT DAIKOKU BERTH PIER T-6, YOKOHAMA
SummaryOfEvents:
On 22nd June at 1515hrs L T.observed smoke on No. 4 deck in No. 2 Hold 5. 1516 Hrs LT Fire alarm raised, all heads accounted for emergency measures initiated. The Chief Officer rushed to the No. 4 Deck with the Boatswain for the purpose of checking the cause of smoke, when they reached the No. 4 Deck, the f1ames were found to have been waved on the after portio n of No. 4 Deck and the compartment of No. 4 Deck in No. 2 Hold had already been filled with a considerable quantity of smoke. Upon receiving the Chief Officer's aforementioned report, the Master of the vessel decided to close all the panels and covers of No. 2 Hold to extinguish the fire using the vessel's C02 system. on closing the covers and panels.
