Headcount was again taken to ensure all personnel are accounted foro The C02 was released into the No. 2 Hold at 1540 hrs. in the first instance and was then released three times at 1540hrs., 1646hrs. and 1804hrs and after releasing all the quantity of C02 kept on board, the releasing was stopped at 2000hrs.During the aboye periods, a nearest fire brigade attended aboard the vessel at 1555 hrs. and tire fighters of the tire brigade tried to measure the temperature of the No. 2 Hold repeatedly and as the result, highest temperature was 35 deg. C. at 1830 hrs., but the temperature dropped steeply until 23 deg. C. at 2038 hrs.
The area was closely monitored and on 23m June at 0720 hrs L T the shore tire brigade and two ship staff made entry to inspect the site and it was ascertained that fire is in control. At 0916 hrs L T all ship staff were allowed to board the vessel and normalcy restored. The fire resulted in 2 vehicles burnt and damage to other 6 vehicles. The Japanese coast guard and the Yokohoma port control was duly notitied of the incident These was no in'uN or pollullon due to the Incident.

The vessel was operating on its regular run between European ports. AS it entered the port limits of the arrival port, the bridge centre console indicator lamps were increased in brightness. Inadvertently, the starboard CPP back-up control button was also operated which overrode the normal CPP system. An identical warning light was noticed by the engineer's in the engine control room but they did not appreciate its signficance as the back-up system was not regularly tested. AS the vessel approached its berth, attempts to slow the vessel were ineffective as the starboard CPP pitch remained at its last setting prior to the back-up system's operation. THe vessel made heavy contact with the vehicle linkspan ashore causing considerable damage to the linkspan structure and the fore end of the vessel, including penetrations below the waterline. THe penetrations were eventually sealed and initial attempts to pull the vessel clear with the help of tugs were ineffective. About 2 hours after the incident, the pitch on the starboard CPP was noticed to be indicating about 60% ahead. The starboard engine was stopped and the back-up system switched off before further attempts to pull the vessel clear. THese were eventually successful and the vessel moved to a layby berth to disembark the passengers and vehicles.

SOLASStatus: Le Battant: Unknown/unspecified, LE BATTANT: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents: Après deux jours de pêche dans le secteur du plateau de Rochebonne, le chalutier Le Battant embarque malencontreusement un lourd et volumineux caillou dans son chalut bâbord. Lorsque l'équipage entreprend la procédure de largage à la mer de cette prise indésirable, la mer est agitée. Malgré les précautions prises pour cette manœuvre déjà pratiquée dans des circonstances analogues, un matelot est mortellement blessé à la suite de la rupture d'une amarre de retenue du chalut.
FIRE ON BOARD THE VESSEL RESULTED WITH THE TOTAL LOSS OF THE SHIP. ALL OF THE 12 CREW MEMBERS WERE RESCUED.

On 21-06-2013 at 0923 hrs. at Zhenjiang Port (32°12′N 119°25′E), China, the Bosun and a Ordinary Seaman of the Hong Kong, China Registered M.V. “Pacific Endeavor” went to inspect a water leakage problem on the foreword of the a cargo hold. The bosun opened the door of the cofferdam between the cargo holds. He instructed the Ordinary Seaman to standby outside and went into the cofferdam to look for the cause of leakage. After a moment, the Ordinary Seaman called out for the Bosun but there was no response.  A rescue team was formed to search for the Bosun. The Bosun was found unconscious inside the cofferdam and was transferred to the hospital immediately but was dead later in the hospital.

SOLASStatus: LEAP HEART: SOLAS, NPS OCEAN STAR: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents:
On the 21 st of June 2013 at 0405 hrs L T vessel was safely alongside at berth#2 Sriracha harbour, Sriracha, Thailand and while she is discharging her Aluminium Hydroxide cargo when other Ship named MV NPS OCEAN STAR of Bangkok, Thailand flag and registry a handy size bulk carrier type ship which is under pilot and with 2 tugs assistance was accidentally collided to our vessel side shell plating consisting of the following damage;
1. Stbd side shell plate & internal members from frame 80-97 heavily dented deformed & holed.
2. Strb side upper deck plates and internal members from frame 80-97 heavily deformed & teared off.
3. Stbd side bulwark from frame 78-97 heavily damaged & teared of.
4. Port side accommodation ladder twisted & extenladder stanchion broken.
5. Strbd bildge keel trailing edge and internal members from frame 87-93 heavily dented & flush inward.

InitialEvent: Hull failure / failure of watertight doors / ports, etc.
SummaryOfEvents: At about 1630 on 21 June 2013, heavy water ingress occurred on board the traditional vessel RAKEL when she was sailing from Bremerhaven to Heligoland. At about 1830, the rescue cruiser HERMAN MARWEDE was summoned to assist by radio. The vessel was kept drained by means of a bucket chain and headed for the port of Heligoland. Eight of the 11 people on board were given preventive medical care. One person suffered a laceration to the eye and another, contusions to the ribs.The vessel was run aground in Heligoland as a precaution and pumped out by the fire brigade.
Consequences1: Serious injuries,Ship rendered unfit to proceed

Location: INDIAN OCEAN 345 MILES NORTH OF THE SEYCHELLES
SummaryOfEvents:
THE FISHING VESSEL 'CHUN YING' CAUGHT FIRE IN CREW CABIN AND BURNT OUT IN THE INDIAN OCEAN 345 MILES NORTH OF THE SEYCHELLES IN LAT. 01 32N, LONG. 054 42E., AM ON 21/06/13.

OWNER DESPATCHED F/V 'CHUN YING NO. 777' WHICH FOUND THE VESSEL ABANDONED BY CREW AT 1500 HOURS LT ON 26/06/13. 14 CREW RESCUED FROM LIFERAFT LATER THE SAME DAY BY SAR HELICOPTER. ANOTHER LIFERAFT WAS FOUND ON 28/07/13 CONTAINING 2 BODIES. 15 CREW STILL MISSING. ARRIVED AT PORT VICTORIA, MAHE, SEYCHELLES IN TOW OF 'CHUN YING NO. 777' ON 05/07/13. REPORTED BLAZE STARTED DELIBERATELY BY FIRST OFFICER IN HIS OWN CABIN.

Location: Att Sea.. On routte from Stt Maartten tto Portt Canaverall
SummaryOfEvents: X was working to replace the shaft seal on the high temperature cooling water valve (3 way valve) to DG# 1 when hot water was expelled from the valve.

The spanish merchant ship LAUDIO loaded with 4,000 tons of soya beans, collided against the point of the eastern breakwater of the southern entrance of the port of Barcelona, with pilot on board, when she was entering the port for berthing. Bridge team was formed by, only, master (attending the navigation) and chief mate (steering the vessel). As a consequence, the vessel suffered a 10 list to starboard. Further examination found several indents, cracks and holes along her starboard side bilge plating, affecting several ballast tanks. As a result of that, the vessel was declared total constructive loss on oct/2013. Crew and pilot alleged strong currents at the mouth of the port that drifted the vessel out of the channel. They also alleged a strong visual pollution from port lighting and vessels alongside, that prevented the bridge team from duly observe the port signalling, specially the green light on the outer point of the eastern breakwater. After a full investigation, the report states that the immediate cause was one of the following: - an error in the orders given by the pilor, or - a communication failure between the pilot and the bridge team. Never mind if it was one or the other, the fact is that nobody checked thegivenorders . Disambiguation is not possible as the vessel was not fitted with a VDR, and declarations do not agree each other.

Location: TYRRHENIAN SEA 22 MILES NORTHEAST OF OLBIA, SARDINIA, ITALY
SummaryOfEvents:
THE ITALIAN-FLAGGED RO-RO CARGO SHIP 'MASSIMO M' CAUGHT FIRE IN ENGINE ROOM IN THE TYRRHENIAN SEA 22 MILES NORTHEAST OF OLBIA, SARDINIA, ITALY IN LAT. 41 12N., LONG. 009 45E., AT 0545 HOURS LT ON 19/06/13. ARRIVED IN TOW AT ALIAGA, TURKEY ON 07/10/13 FOR BREAKING UP.

NO INJURIES OR POLLUTION REPORTED. BLAZE EXTINGUISHED BY CREW. TUG 'ALESSANDRO ONORATO' EFFECTED TOW TO OLBIA, ITALY FOR INSPECTION AND REPAIRS.

Location: GULF OF OMAN 2 MILES NORTH OF PORT SULTAN QABOOS, OMAN
SummaryOfEvents:
THE ASPHALT/BITUMEN TANKER 'NESA R3' OF SAINT KITS AND NEVIS TOOK WATER AND SANK IN THE GULF OF OMAN 2 MILES NORTH OF PORT SULTAN QABOOS, OMAN ON 19/06/13.

2 TUGS, COASTGUARD AND NAVAL VESSELS PROCEEDED TO ASSIST AND RESCUED 9 OF THE 10 CREW. BODY OF THE CAPTAIN RECOVERED THE FOLLOWING DAY. SOME OF THE CARGO OF BITUMEN LEAKED INTO SEA AND POLLUTED LOCAL BEACHES. CLEAN UP OPERATION EFFECTED.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Pollution,Total loss of the ship

Location: No.15 Berth of No.1 Pier, Incheon
SummaryOfEvents:
At 1607 18th  June 2013(LT, UTC+9), Chinese bulk vessel MV.TONG SHUN exploded at NO.15 berth of NO.1 Pier, Incheon, Republic of Korea. The explosion occurred at 
fuel oil settling tank. There were 15 crew members on board and one of them died while four of them were injured.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Serious injuries,Ship rendered unfit to proceed

SummaryOfEvents: During zodiac cruising, craft flipped over by wave along the shore line causing all 12-15 passengers on board at the time to fall into the water. One (1) passenger died as a result, two(2) other injured and disembarked. Ship's doctor arrived on scene shortly after with all medical equipment required and assisted the injured. Shore side assistance and helicopter evacuation requested

The hull of the Bahamian container ship MOL COMFORT broke into two 1,556 km (840 nautical miles) from Mumbai, India in Yemen waters, on Monday, 17 June 2013 (time not reported).  The 316-metre long container ship was en route from Singapore to Jeddah and carrying 4,500 containers.  All 26 crew members were rescued and were taken to Colombo in Sri Lanka. The two sections of the MOL COMFORT are stably floating even under adverse weather. 

Cargo from the broken ship was scattered in the water and oil spilt into the sea.

The crew members abandoned the ship and boarded two life rafts and one lifeboat until they were rescued by MV YANTIAN EXPRESS (being the closest to the scene), which was part of an extensive rescue operation orchestrated by the Maritime Rescue Coordination Centre, Mumbai (who sent three ships MV HANJIN BEIJING, MV ZIM INDIA and MV YANTIAN EXPRESS) and the Indian Coast Guard. The rescue operation was conducted in rough weather, the wind force being 30-35 knots.

It is not known what caused the accident.

Update 22 June 2013

According to latest media reports, the majority of the containers are confirmed to be aboard the fore and aft parts of MOL COMFORT, that are drifting near 14”35N 64’50”E and 13’22”N 62’48”E in an east-northeast direction.  The other containers were either lost or damaged.  Still under adverse weather conditions, sections remain afloat and are being monitored by the MV SANDERLING ACE (another MOL managed ship).

A patrol boat, despatched from Jebel Ali is expected to arrive at the scene on Monday 24 June 2013, until the tugboats arrive to tow the two halves of the ship.

The crew members arrived safely in the port of Colombo, Sri Lanka.

A salvage company has been formally contracted to perform the salvage of MOL COMFORT

Investigations into the cause of the incident have commenced.  This is the first case in liner sector when a modern container vessel sank in the ocean after breaking in two parts.  Reports confirm that was no large volume of oil leakage from the accident.

InitialEvent: Hull failure / failure of watertight doors / ports, etc.
SummaryOfEvents: Vessel sank after major flooding due to hull rupture.

Location: In the NNE waters of Genkai-Jima, Fukuoka Prefecture, Japan
SummaryOfEvents:
The Japanese fishing vessel TSUNOMINE-MARU was found capsized at about 11 nautical miles NNE off the coast of Genkai-Jima at around 09:06 Japan Standard Time (UTC+0900hrs), 15 June 2013. Although the skipper was rescued from the capsized vessel and taken to a hospital, he was confirmed dead at the hospital.
　It was later confirmed that Cambodian general cargo ship FUKUKAWA collided with TSUNOMINE-MARU.

Location: ILOILO STRAIT OFF THE SIETE PICADOS ISLETS 7 MILES NE OF ILOILO CITY, PHILIPPINES
SummaryOfEvents:
THE FILIPINO-FLAGGED PASSENGER RO-RO SHIP 'ST. GREGORY THE GREAT' STRUCK SUBMERGED OBJECT IN THE ILOILO STRAIT OFF THE SIETE PICADOS ISLETS 7 MILES NE OF ILOILO CITY, PHILIPPINES IN LAT. 10 46N., LONG. 122 40E., AT 0300 HOURS LT ON 15/06/13. ARRIVED AT CHITTAGONG ON 21/01/15 FOR DEMOLITION.

NO INJURIES OR POLLUTION REPORTED. SUSTAINED DAMAGE TO STARBOARD SIDE OF HULL AND TOOK WATER IN ENGINE ROOM. PROCEEDED TO ILOILO CITY AT REDUCED SPEED UNDER ESCORT OF 2 TUGS FOR DIVERS INSPECTION AND PUMPING OUT. ALL PASSENGERS DISEMBARKED AND TRANSFERRED TO OTHER SERVICES.

SOLASStatus: Fri Ocean: SOLAS, FRI OCEAN: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents:
Bahamas registered cargo vessel 'FRI OCEAN' grounded on Mull, in the Sound of Mull approximately two (2) miles south of Tobermory. The vessel was on passage between Corpach Scotland, and Varberg Sweden. The ship had seven (7) crew on board and no injuries or pollution have been reported. At the time of the incident, the vessel was carrying 91 tonnes of diesel oil on board and a cargo of 2,074 tonnes of timber which were reported as stable and well secured. The Master had stated that although the vessel was ballasted down, she regained buoyancy on the evening rising tide. In fear of losing the ship he decided that the safest option for his crew was to allow the vessel to move clear of the shore. During the course of the day a number of salvage companies were mobilised to the area to carry out damage assessments. Class, MAIB and MCA were on scene. 

At this stage the vessel was reported as stable, with all engines fully operational. Temporary repairs were carried out by the crew in reducing water ingress. The ship later re-floated with minor assistance from Tobermory lifeboat and proceeded safely to anchorage at Salen Bay, Sound of Mull at 23:50 BST where the vessel remained overnight. The following morning (15/6), 'FRI OCEAN' proceeded to a second anchorage off Oban to undergo underwater inspection, Class Inspection and Port State Control. During Class inspection of the vessel it was revealed that the emergency fire pump piping had been damaged during the grounding. Damages also reported in the bow thruster compartment along with breaches in the void space and forepeak area. The breaches in the void space below the bow thrust and in the forepeak were controlled by bilge pumps and each compartment was sealed. On completion of temporary repairs that satisfied Class, the vessel sailed to Liverpool for docking and permanent repairs.

Location: 100 km north of the city Den Helder, the Netherlands
SummaryOfEvents:
An air hose snapped during pressure testing, killing two workers and seriously injuring a third, on board teh DANISH NORTH SEA L5A gas platform, located 100 kilometres north of the Dutch city of Den Helder, the Netherlands, at approximately 07:45 am, GMT, on Friday 14 June 2013.

No one employee was evacuated.  The other 13 employees remain on the platform.

The pressure tests, involving the injection of highly pressurized water were being conducted on a heat exchanger.  The L5A platform was out of production and depressurized; causing no leakage of hydrocarbon.

The incident is under investigation by the company and regulators.

On the 14th of June 2013, at about 16:00, Ro-Pax "Nisos Mykonos" was on route to the island of Samos, carrying 173 passengers and 74 crew, when a fire at the ship's funnel was reported by the ship's captain to the JRRC of Piraeus. The crew began the fire extinguishing procedure at once, while passenger mustering protocol was also carried out on the ship. Eventually the fire was put out by the crew about 2 hours later, burning the inside space of the ship's funnel and causing material damage to her. The engines had to be stopped and the passengers were taken to the nearby island of Samos (port of Karlovasi) by HCG patrol vessel 601 and passenger ship "Panagia Theotocos". No injury or pollution was noted .The ship was then towed to the port of Karlovasi by tug boats "Megalochari" and "Vasiliki", for temporary repairs and then to the port of Keratsini for full repairs. Investigation is carried out by HBMCI and by the evidence gathered so far, the fire started from a failure to the ship's thermal oil piping system.

THE TURKISH-FLAGGED PASSENGER RO-RO SHIP 'SALACAK' SUSTAINED TECHNICAL PROBLEMS AND STRUCK THE PIER WHILST BERTHING AT UCKUYULAR, IZMIR, TURKEY AT 2100 HOURS LT ON 10/06/13. SUBSEQUENTLY ARRIVED ALIAGA, TURKEY ON 28/08/14 FOR BREAKING UP.

3 PERSONS SUSTAINED MINOR INJURIES AND WERE TAKEN TO HOSPITAL. NO POLLUTION REPORTED. EXTENT OF DAMAGE UNKNOWN. INSPECTION EFFECTED.

MV 'UNICORN LOGGER" Depart from Sandakan, Malaysia on 11th June 2013 at 0800LT, laden with 1607 pcs / 8,367 m3 of round logs to Kisaru, Japan.

The voyage initially proceeded normally with passage plan passing the Visayas islands in the Philippines and exiting at San Bernardino strait before heading towards Japan. 
During navigation, the vessel encountered numerous fishing vessels and Unicorn Logger alter course to pass clear from the fishing vessels. Due to an evasive action, the vessel  drifted about 2Nm to the stbd of his course Passing shower sets in and visibility reduced to 2-3Nm with force 5 NE'ly winds when the vessel was about to pass Maripipi Islands.
After clearing from the fishing vessels, the OOW did not apply course leeway to return to her intended track but choose to maintain the course to steer anticipating that he will be altering to stbd after passing Maripipi Island. He did not consider that the safe passing distance to the shallow water is already about 1Nm and was too late and MV Unicorn Logger run aground in Sambauan Islets Lat 11-45.69N Long 124-15.71E at 1910LT 13th June 2013.
DURING DISCHARGING OPERATION, BOBCAT IN THE SHIP'S CARGO HOLD HIT A PORT WORKER. THE WORKER WAS INJURED AND LOST HIS LIFE DUE TO HIS INJURIES.

Location: In the vicinity of Brownstown Head, Co. Waterford
SummaryOfEvents:
The “MFV Dean Leanne”, a 5.91 metre (m) L.O.A. Irish registered, open fishing
vessel departed Dunmore East at 06.53 hrs on the 12th June 2013 with a crew
of three on-board with the intention of re-positioning pots laid in Tramore Bay.
1.2 The vessel was reported missing at 17.29 hrs at which time the emergency
services were tasked.
1.3 At 17.58 hrs first casualty was sighted in the water by Waterford based
helicopter R117.
1.4 The three casualties were recovered by 18.14 hrs, two by the Dunmore East
Lifeboat and one by the Waterford based helicopter R117.
1.5 The vessel was found capsized and partially sunken.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents: When casting a net a fisherman became trapped and fell overboard and was then pulled down into the water because of the net's weight.  He got twisted in it, taken by the armpit and the neck, about fifteen meters from the ship. The tension of the net pulled it to the bottom while the ship was drifting. The crew tried in vain to assist him. He was recovered dead shortly after.

On 11 July 2013 the vessel ALMI GALAXY was traveling outside the port limits of Singapore to Tanjun Pelepas for the discharge of part of her cargo load when she was struck by the vessel SAMUDERA at 20:10hrs (LT).  ALMI GALAXY and SAMUDERA were both eventually deemed fit to proceed following investigations subsequent to the collision.

On 11 June 2013, at about 1206(LT), a fire broke out in the engine-room of Mississippi Star, a Maltese registered tanker, during a ballast passage to Antwerp.  This resulted in the third engineer sustaining severe burn injuries.  The crew members were able to contain the fire using CO2.  The third engineer was airlifted by a UK Coastguard helicopter to a nearby hospital.  Despite receiving prompt medical attention, the crew member succumbed to his injuries. 
 
The safety investigation identified that the fuel oil filter housing was still pressurised when the crew member slackened the bolts of the housing cover.  This resulted in fuel oil spraying out under pressure on to a hot surface of the turbocharger and ignited.

SOLASStatus: North Tug: Unknown/unspecified, Ocean Princess: SOLAS
SummaryOfEvents:
On the evening of 10 June 2013, the Accident Investigation Board Norway (AIBN) was notified by
the Joint Rescue Coordination Centre Northern Norway (JRCC-NN) that the workboat North Tug
had capsized and sunk in Kirkenes. The accident had occurred in connection with North Tug
assisting the cruise ship Ocean Princess during departure from the deepwater quay. No persons
were physically injured in connection with the accident. The AIBN decided, in consultation with the
Bermudan accident investigation authority, to conduct a joint investigation of the accident.

Location: LACCADIVE SEA 130 MILES NORTHWEST OF MINICOY ISLAND, LAKSHADWEEP, INDIA
SummaryOfEvents:
THE MALDIVIAN-FLAGGED GENERAL CARGO SHIP 'ASIAN EXPRESS' SUSTAINED ENGINE FAILURE IN THE LACCADIVE SEA 130 MILES NORTHWEST OF MINICOY ISLAND, LAKSHADWEEP, INDIA IN LAT. 09 56N., LONG. 072 03E., AT 1120 HOURS LT ON 09/06/13 IN HEAVY WEATHER. SUBSEQUENTLY SANK ON 13/06/13.

TEMPORARY REPAIRS EFFECTED AND CONTINUED ON VOYAGE BUT ENGINE FAILED AGAIN IN LAT. 08 59N., LONG. 072 26E., AT 2340 HOURS LT ON 10/06/13. DEVELOPED 4 METRE CRACK IN STARBOARD SIDE OF HULL BELOW THE WATERLINE AND TOOK WATER. ICGS TRAINING VESSEL 'VARUNA' PROCEEDED TO ASSIST AND RESCUED ALL 22 PERSONS ON BOARD ON 12/06/13 AND TOOK THEM TO KOCHI, INDIA. SUBSEQUENTLY SANK AT 0457 HOURS LT ON 13/06/13 IN LAT. 09 07N., LONG. 073 19E.

On 8 June 2013 the vessel RHL FIDELITAS was traveling the traffic separation scheme of the Singapore Strait when it collided with the vessel NYK MINO at 16:20hrs (LT).  The ship was deemed fit to continue to the port of Singapore for repairs without substantial assistance required.

Location: 3 MILES SOUTH OF SAN PEDRO, IVORY COAST
SummaryOfEvents:
CAPSIZED IN THE GULF OF GUINEA 3 MILES SOUTH OF SAN PEDRO, IVORY COAST IN LAT. 04 14N., LONG. 006 37W., AM ON 06/07/13 IN HEAVY SWELL.
15 PERSONS RESCUED AND TAKEN TO SAN PEDRO. NO INJURIES REPORTED. 1 PERSON DEAD. UPTURNED HULL SUBSEQUENTLY DRIFTED ASHORE NEAR SAN PEDRO. 4000 LITRES OF BUNKER FUEL REMOVED AND WRECK DISMANTLED IN SITU. CAUSE OF CAPSIZE REPORTED TO BE PROBABLE SHIFT OF CARGO IN HEAVY SWELL.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

Location: Zatoka Pomorska, entrance channel to port of Swinoujscie
SummaryOfEvents:
M/v Godafoss after embarking port pilot on board headed toward entrance channel of port of Swinoujscie on 03rd July 2013. At 16:50 ship passed the head of central breakwater. Around 16:52 when the ship's bow was approaching buoy "B" ship's captain wanted to keep ship at the central line of fairway, therefore he performed few consecutive manoeuvers with the wheel and than with main engine and in the end  he used the bow thruster. Despite those manoeuers the ship deviated east from central line of the fairway. Finally at 16:54 ship grounded with her bow on the slope of the central breakwater between groins no. 4 and no.5.
Crew took soundings around the ship and of the bow ballast tanks. No leak was found so, it was decided to get back the ship floated independently. The result of main engine and wheel manoeuvers was positive. The ship was refloated at 17:41 and proceeded toward the berth. At 18:10 ship moored stb side at Nabrzeże Gornikow berth in port of Swinoujscie.

Location: NORTH ATLANTIC OCEAN 805 MILES WEST OF SAO MIGUEL ISLAND, AZORES, PORTUGAL
SummaryOfEvents:
THE PORTUGUESE-FLAGGED STERN TRAWLER 'HEMISFERIO SUL' CAUGHT FIRE AND SUBSEQUENTLY CAPSIZED IN THE NORTH ATLANTIC OCEAN 805 MILES WEST OF SAO MIGUEL ISLAND, AZORES, PORTUGAL IN LAT. 34 59N., LONG. 039 08W., AT 0744 HOURS LT ON 06/06/13.

NO POLLUTION OR INJURIES REPORTED. VESSEL REPORTED TO HAVE SANK AFTER FIRE WAS BURNT OUT. NEARBY FV 'MARDANI' RESCUED THE 12 CREW ON BOARD AND PROCEEDED TO HORTA, FAIAL ISLAND, AZORES, PORTUGAL.

At approximately 06:30 hours (LT) on 05 June 2013, Liberian flagged Oil/Chemical tanker ship M/V PERLA experienced a fire which started in the engine room. The fire was ultimately extinguished successfully via use of the CO2 system. There were no incidents of environmental pollution but there were damages to the vessel and serious injuries to four of the persons onboard.
Consequences1: Serious injuries,Ship rendered unfit to proceed

SummaryOfEvents: Fishermen set the fishing long lines and they fell asleep. Suddenly the skipper woke up because he smelt like smoke. He went to the engine room and realised that there was fire. Fishermen left the boat and were rescued by a Spanish fishing vessel. Later they were evacuated to the hospital by aFrench helicopter.
Consequences1: Pollution,Ship rendered unfit to proceed,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents: Passenger ferry  allided with quay at Sulesund. Some dolphins on quay damaged. Only cosmetic damage on the vessel. After an assessment made by the crew the vessel continued on route.

THE TANZANIAN-FLAGGED GENERAL CARGO SHIP 'MATTHEW I' SUSTAINED MAIN ENGINE PROBLEMS, CAUGHT FIRE AND SUBSEQUENTLY SANK IN THE CARIBBEAN SEA NORTH OF ARUBA ON 04/06/13 IN GOOD WEATHER.

ALL 10 CREW ABANDONED SHIP TO LIFERAFTS AND RESCUED BY OPV HNLMS 'HOLLAND'. NO INJURIES REPORTED. FIRE FIGHTING ATTEMPTS BY HNLMS 'HOLLAND' WERE UNSUCCESSFUL AND SUBSEQUENTLY SANK LATER THE SAME EVENING. RESCUED CREW TRANSFERRED TO USCG VESSEL.

By 13:15 of 03JUL2013, the vessel listed to starboard and  while was hauling trammel nets at 1.25 mn from the coast . It was still to be hauled about 384 m of a total of 5000 m. Eventually the vessel sank. 

6 crew members were shipwrecked, and 5 of them were rescued with the assistance of another fishing vessel while 1 was missing. This one could not swim. 

The crew wore no lifesaving equipment or any other emergency flotation vest. 

Later the vessel was recovered and put into the port of Aveiro.

It was detected a damaged tube (leaking water from its inside to the engine room) that makes part of the refrigeration system of the engine. According to the statements of the survivors , the vessel had an alarm of flooding in the engine room, which was not activated ( at least in the audible mode). 

The vessel was 2 years old and sailing at a speed of 2 kts .

M/T MANDOUDI lost control and hit the dock while manoeuvering in Piraeus port to get alongside to cruise ship SEABOURNE SPIRIT to deliver bunkers. M/T MANDOUDI sustained hull damages (holes ad plating deformations) to the bow and fore peak tank.
SEABOURNE SPIRIT suffered minor scratces to her side above SWL.

At 2230(UTC) on 31 May 2013, Wilson Leith arrived off Spurn Point, UK.  A pilot boat came alongside to pick up the pilot.  Soon after the pilot stepped on the pilot ladder, the side ropes parted.  The pilot fell on the pilot boat, injuring his right foot and ankle. 

Stereomicroscopy of rope filaments sampled from near the failed ends showed signs of abrasion damage.
Consequences1: Serious injuries,Ship remains fit to proceed

SOLASStatus: LINTAS BAHARI UTAMA: Unknown/unspecified, LINTAS BENGKULU: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents:
IN COLLISION WITH MV 'LINTAS BENGKULU', DEVELOPED LIST AND SUBSEQUENTLY SANK IN THE APPROACHES OF TANJUNG PRIOK, INDONESIA WHILST DEPARTING TERMINAL IN LAT. 06 03S., LONG. 106 52E., AT 2110 HOURS LT ON 31/05/13.

REPORTED 14 CREW RESCUED AND 1 CREW MEMBER MISSING. A NUMBER OF VESSELS FROM THE NAVY, MARINE POLICE AND LOCAL AUTHORITIES ASSISTED IN RESCUING OF CREW. OIL BOOMS LAID TO CONTAIN SPILLED OIL. WRECK REMOVAL TO BE SCHEDULED.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Pollution,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents: Chittagong, Jun 2 -- Coaster vessel Eureka, loaded with 320 metric tonnes of Urea from Chittagong Urea Fertilizer Limited, came in collion with combined chemical and oil tanker Green Field 1 (22607 gt, built 1988), while it was berthing at the CUFL Jetty, at 1700 hrs, May 31. The Master of Eureka immediately tried to move the vessel towards the nearest bank of the river, but the vessel sank with its cargo. No injuries or fatalities were reported. The owner of the sunken vessel tried to salvage the vessel along with the help of the Chittagong Port Authority. Currently, Green Field 1 is discharging its cargo at CUFL Jetty, which is expected to be completed by next week. Meanwhile, Eureka is presently lying at a shore near CUFL Jetty

Location: BALTIC SEA 27 MILES NORTH OF GDYNIA, POLAND
SummaryOfEvents:
THE GERMAN-FLAGGED TRAINING SHIP 'GEORG BUCHNER' TOOK WATER, DEVELOPED LIST AND SANK IN THE BALTIC SEA 27 MILES NORTH OF GDYNIA, POLAND IN LAT. 54 55N., LONG. 018 31E., AT 2025 HOURS LT ON 30/05/13.

NO INJURIES OR POLLUTION REPORTED. SHIP WAS UNDER TOW UNMANNED BY TUG 'AJAKS' BOUND KLAIPEDA, LITHUANIA FOR BREAKING UP AT THE TIME OF THE INCIDENT. ANTI POLLUTION VESSEL 'KAPITAN POINC' AND NAVAL PATROL VESSEL 'ARCTOWSKI' ATTENDED THE SCENE.

notification of the Panamanian flagged vessel the M/V IMPERIAL SPIRIT, IMO#9364801 was involved in an collision with the T/V PROFIT, IMO#9408683 approximately 20nm south of the Galveston, Texas Jetties in the contiguous zone of the United States in the Gulf of Mexico. We are currently conducting a preliminary investigation as the damage, stability and pollution threat of both vessels.

At 0443 on 2 July 2012, while on passage from Belfast to Greenock, the 89m feeder container vessel Coastal Isle ran aground on the Island of Bute.
The grounding resulted in significant  damage to the forward section of the vessel, including minor breaches to the forward ballast tanks. 
At about 0240 the chief officer, who was on watch at the time, had dismissed the ordinary seaman who was on lookout duties; shortly afterwards he left the bridge himself. 
The bridge was unmanned from that time until the vessel grounded at 0443. 
The chief officer was subsequently found in his cabin.

Le Matin du  Mai, le chalutier Toirette quitte le port de Grandcamp-Meisy pour se rendre sur ses lieux de pêche en Baie de Seine
En début de soirée, il croche  sur un ridain, chavire et coule
L’alerte est donnée par la balise de détresse
Les recherches permettent de sauver le matelot, récupéré par un navire de pêche, et évacué vers l’hôpital de Cherbourg revanche, le patron, aperçu pour la dernière fois dans la timonerie, disparait. Son corps sera retrouvé dans la passerelle du navire deux jours plus tard.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents:
En la mañana del día 27 de mayo del 2013, en momentos que el asistente del cocinero ingresa a 05:50 horas a la cocina para preparar el desayuno para la tripulación, observa que sale humo y fuego de una de las hornillas procediendo a hacer uso de los extintores disponibles, el cual tomaba dimensiones cada vez más grandes lo cual impedía el ingreso a la cocina.
Dado el estado en que quedó la nave, no se ha podido determinar las causas de la cocina de la nave.
La tripulación no sufrió daños personales y la nave quedó inoperativa.

Location: approx 10 miles west of Grand Bahama island
SummaryOfEvents:
On Monday, 27th May 2013 at 0250 hrs LT, a fire was detected on the third deck of the aft mooring area of the ship which spread to the fourth deck crew lounge area. Approximately two (2) hours later, the fire was quickly brought under control and safely extinguished by the ship's fire response crew. All 2,224 guests and 796 crew were accounted for, neither reporting any serious injury. 
The vessel was on a seven-night cruise that departed Baltimore, Maryland, on Friday 24th May, enroute to Coco Cay, Bahamas. Most public areas and staterooms were safe and power, propulsion and communication systems worked without interruption. Scheduled to call on Coco Cay on the 27th May, Grandeur of the Seas instead sailed to Freeport, Bahamas, where it is undergoing evaluations. The cause of the fire is yet to be determined and investigations have commenced by the Bahamas Maritime Authority in conjunction with the United States Coast Guard (USCG) and National Transportation Safety Board(NTSB).

On 26 May 2013 at 0437 (LT), the bow chain of ALEKSEY KOSYGIN parted during strong weather conditions.  The pulling tug attached to ALEKSEY KOSYGIN, tug JASCON 4, capsized. The capsizing resulted in the loss of eleven crew members aboard JASCON 4, ten deceased and 1 missing. The vessels were engaged in cargo loading operations at the time of the incident.
While starting the ship's steam turbine generator a valve in the steam system failed.  The 2/E was struck by the body of the valve and killed; the 1/E was burned by steam.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Serious injuries,Ship remains fit to proceed

InitialEvent: Fatal Accident with Parted Mooring rope
SummaryOfEvents: On 24-05-2013 at 1810 hrs. at east jetty of the China Light and Power Station at Tap Shek Kok, Hong Kong, China, when the Third Officer and the Ordinary Seaman of the Singapore Registered M.V. “Equator Peace” were adjusting the mooring ropes at the forecastle, a breast rope parted and the Ordinary Seaman was hit on the right side of his head. He was seriously injured and rushed to hospital. The Ordinary Seaman was dead later in the hospital.

En su proceso de finalización de amarre a muelle 1A de la instalación portuaria APM TERMINALS, el día 23 de mayo de 2013 en el puerto del Callao - Perú, el Capitán de la M/N “ELEGANT ACE” dispuso que se reforzaran las amarras y se colocaran las defensas como era habitual al término de cada maniobra.
El Segundo Oficial y dos tripulantes procedieron a reforzar las amarras de popa estribor.
Durante la maniobra, uno de los tripulantes le grita y hace señas de alerta al Segundo Oficial, quien inmediatamente para el funcionamiento del molinete, indicándole que el tripulante DEASIO JUSTIN ORTIZ había caído fuera del buque.
El Segundo Oficial comunicó lo ocurrido al Capitán y se tomaron las acciones de avisar a la instalación portuaria, quienes enviaron una ambulancia y el otro tripulante que se encontraba en la maniobra bajó al muelle y se lanzó al agua con un salvavidas para auxiliar a su compañero.

Se procedió a rescatar al tripulante, quien se encontraba con serios daños en la cara y lo trasladaron a una clínica para la atención correspondiente. Posteriormente se informó que había fallecido como consecuencia de la caída, tal como figura en el informe forense.
 El Capitán comunicó a las autoridades locales el hecho.

On 19 May 2013, the deckhand (Maltese national) on board the pilot boat Charlie 1 suffered serious injuries whilst the pilot boat was pulling away from alongside the Antigua & Barbuda registered container ship OS Bodrum.  At the time of the accident, the pilot boat had just transferred a pilot to the ship, inbound for Marsaxlokk port, Malta.
 
The safety investigation focused mainly on the operating procedures and practices on board the pilot boat and its personnel as well as the pilot boarding arrangement on OS Bodrum.  These findings were then analysed in the light of regulatory requirements and established industry safe practices in order to draw conclusions and to make safety recommendations. 

Amongst other factors, this safety investigation established that the pilot boarding arrangement provided by the ship was not compliant with the relevant SOLAS requirements due to its close proximity to the ship’s stern and overhang and therefore was intrinsically dangerous.  Moreover, the pilot and the deckhand did not follow the industry’s recommended practice to walk on the outboard side of the pilot boat.

The shipping company Torghatten Nord AS had just deployed MF Røst in the Svolær-Skutvik-Skrova ferry service. The crew had been given a verbal message from the shipping company not to sail through Fyrsundet sound until further notice, as the aft mast was assumed to be too high for MF Røst to pass under the overhead high-voltage cables. However, the captain and chief mate on duty at the time of the accident believed that it would be possible for MF Røst to pass under the cables. On 18 May 2013, they therefore intended to verify the distance between the vessel's aft mast and the overhead cables. The nautical chart showed a safe vertical clearance of 20 metres, while the signs ashore showed 22 metres. The shipboard management had measured the vessels air draft to be 20,7 metres from the water line to the top of the aft mast. On reaching Fyrsundet, the chief mate climbed up the foremast, that was slighly lower than the aft mast, to observe the passage and to check the margin between the mast and the cables using a fishingrod that he had taken with him. However, as the vessel passed under the least of the three high-voltage cables, the fishingrod came in contact with high-voltage, the chief mate received an electric shock and died as a consequence of falling down from the foremast.
The AIBN investigation found that the information flow in the shipping company was inadequate, that there was a lack of routines in the authorities reporting of chart data and continous updating of navigational charts, and that the crew was not familiar with the requirement for a safety margin in relation to overhead cables carrying high-voltage. The AIBN proposes forur safety reccomendations as a result of the investigation.

HRS said that they received at 05:21 notification that the vessel had run aground in position N71 03.19 E 028 16.00. The vessel had pob on 6 who dressed in a survival suits. Soon after, HRS was told that they had to leave the vessel. HRS said that they lost contact with the crew. After attempting to contact the company received HRS contact with one of the crew via mobile. He could tell that the crew had to swim ashore because of problems getting into the raft. It was good weather in the area but some heavy swell. The crew are picked up by a Seaking and flown to Mehamn. No information about pollution or personal injuries. 
  
The vessel was later pulled off ground and towed to Hammerfest.

On Friday, 17 May 2013, approximately at 01:00 LT, Ro-Pax NISSOS KEFALONIA had completed her daily schedule and arrived at Argos-toli port of Kefalonia island. At that time weather conditions in the port were wind NNE 7-8 Bf with gusts up to 40 Knots. Nissos Kefalonia en-tered the port, dropped the anchor and safely moored with her stern. At 01:45 all passenger had disembarked, vehicle unloading was com-pleted and crew started securing the ship with extra mooring lines from the bow and the stern. Moreover an old truck tire which was used as a fender was put at the stern to protect vessels port side stern sheer stake from coming in contact with the dock. The tire was hanged with a rope which was tied up to a rail on aft mooring deck. Bosun, who was standing on the stern ramp gave an order to an AB at the aft mooring deck to shift the fender to starboard and tie the hanging rope to another position.Following Bosuns order the AB attempted to pass the hanging rope from the inner side of a mooring line. During his attempt his thumb was caught between the mooring line and a fairlead due to vessels move-ment caused by the strong wind and got almost amputated. The AB was transferred to a local hospital where he received medical care and his thumb was successfully reattached.

Location: At the west pier of Tenpoku No.2 Wharf in the port of Wakkanai, Wakkanai City, Hokkaido, Japan
SummaryOfEvents: A fire broke out on the cargo ship TAIGAN which was moored alongside at No.2 Tenpoku wharf, Wakkanai Port. Three crew members were injured and six were found dead.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents:
At	1810	on	15	May	2013,	able	seaman	(AB)	William	Penafiel	was	crushed	between	two cargo containers on the main deck of the ro-ro cargo ship Tyrusland.  He did not survive the injuries sustained. Tyrusland was berthed in Tripoli and the crew were working with an embarked team	of	vehicle	drivers	to	discharge	a	cargo	of	containers.		AB	Penafiel’s	role	was	to release and remove twistlocks during the cargo discharge operation.  This task required him to work in close proximity to moving vehicles that were being used to handle the containers. At the time of the accident, a full container was being handled using a fork-lift truck.  The fork-lift truck driver was conducting a manoeuvre to avoid the container striking an adjacent stack of containers and to realign the container in preparation for loading	it	onto	a	waiting	trailer.		However,	the	driver	could	not	see	AB	Penafiel	and	was,	therefore,	unaware	of	his	movements.		As	AB	Penafiel	attempted	to	remove	a	twistlock from the deck, the moving container collided with a static container, fatally crushing him in between. The MAIB investigation found that the system of work employed by those involved in	the	cargo	handling	process	was	unsafe	and	that	AB	Penafiel	had	entered	a	hazardous	area	with	insufficient	safeguards	in	place.		The investigation also found that there were weaknesses in the implementation of the company’s safety management system (SMS) on board Tyrusland, particularly relating to risk assessments and SMS review processes.  Although a risk assessment relating to working on deck existed, it did not identify and address the specific	hazard	of	a	worker	being	crushed	by	a	moving	vehicle	or	container	during	cargo handling operations.  The lack of appropriate risk assessments was an issue	that	had	been	identified	previously	in	both	an	internal	company	audit	and	an	external audit conducted by the Maritime and Coastguard Agency (MCA).  However, follow-up action by the company and the MCA in response to this issue was insufficient	to	prevent	the	accident.	This was the fourth accident, two of which were fatal, in less than a year involving UK	flagged	ships	managed	by	Imperial	Ship	Management	AB.		The	company	has since conducted a safety management review and has developed a plan for improving	procedures	and	safety	culture	across	its	fleet.		The	MAIB	has	previously	made a recommendation1 to the MCA aimed at improving its processes for managing audits and follow-up action. In view of this recommendation and the action taken since by Imperial Ship Management, no recommendations are made in this report. 
1

When approaching Dønna harbour on it's fixed route Sandnessjøen-Dønna-Løkta, the passenger/car ferry Møysalen LGEV made contact with a underwater rock. No injuries to pax or crew and no environmental impact. The ferry was made afloat again under her own power and returned with pax and vehicles onboard to Sandnessjøen to conduct diving and hull inspection.

Location: ANCHORAGE 14 MILES NORTHWEST OF AL HAMRIYA, UAE
SummaryOfEvents:
THE PANAMANIAN-FLAGGED PRODUCTS TANKER 'AL KABEER' CAUGHT FIRE IN THE ANCHORAGE 14 MILES NORTHWEST OF AL HAMRIYA, UAE IN LAT. 25 35N., LONG. 055 19E., AT 2355 HOURS LT ON 14/05/13. DAMAGED BEYOND ECONOMICAL REPAIR AND ARRIVED AT GADANI BEACH ON 25/11/14 FOR BREAKING UP.

ALL 16 CREW RESCUED BY COASTGUARD. NO INJURIES OR POLLUTION REPORTED. BLAZE EXTINGUISHED WITH ASSISTANCE FROM LOCAL VESSELS. SUSTAINED SEVERE DAMAGE.

SOLASStatus: GRANDE SENEGAL: Unknown/unspecified, NILEDUTCH SPRINGBOK: SOLAS
SummaryOfEvents: While under pilotage and maneuvering with tug assistance, NILEDUTCH SPRINGBOK was involved in a collision with Italian flagged vessel GRANDE SENEGAL. No injuries or pollution incident was reported, however, GRANDE SENEGAL sustained hull damage.
Two crew members have apparently been overcome by toxic gases, when entering the cargo hold.
The vessel reported that had main engine problem in lat37°43.46N,long23°44.34E, about 0130, UTC, May 13.

SOLASStatus: AI FENG YUAN: Unknown/unspecified, SETTSU: Unknown/unspecified
Location: KOREA STRAITS 50 MILES SOUTHEAST OF NAMHAE, REPUBLIC OF KOREA
SummaryOfEvents:
THE CAMBODIAN-FLAGGED GENERAL CARGO SHIP 'AI FENG YUAN' SANK AFTER COLLISION WITH MV 'SETTSU' IN THE KOREA STRAITS 50 MILES SOUTHEAST OF NAMHAE, REPUBLIC OF KOREA IN LAT. 33 59N., LONG. 128 20E., AT 2240 HOURS LT ON 12/05/13.

ALL 10 CREW RESCUED BUT 1 SUBSEQUENTLY DIED. COASTGUARD VESSELS ATTENDED THE SCENE.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

SOLASStatus: SANKO ELEGANCE: SOLAS, SANKO ENERGY: SOLAS, SOUTHERNPEC 5: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents:
Vessel COXON TIDE was SANKO ELEGANCE at time of incident and was registered with Liberia.

On the night of 11 May 2013 the SANKO ELEGANCE was involved in a collision with SOUTHERN PEC 5. The SOUTHERN PEC 5 also collided with nearby vessel SANKO ENERGY during this event. The SANKO ELEGANCE sustained damage to her bow.

SOLASStatus: ARCTIC LIFT I: Unknown/unspecified, WESTERN TUGGER: Unknown/unspecified
InitialEvent: Accidental Death and Loss of Tow
SummaryOfEvents: On 10 May 2013, at approximately 0625 Newfoundland and Labrador Daylight Time, the barge Arctic Lift I, which was carrying a cargo of steel rebar, capsized while under tow by the tug Western Tugger in moderate weather about 33 nautical miles southwest of Burgeo, Newfoundland and Labrador. The subsequent strain on the tow wire caused an auxiliary brake drum on the tow winch to shatter, and parts of it struck a crew member, who sustained fatal injuries
Consequences1: Loss of life,Ship remains fit to proceed

SummaryOfEvents: The Bosun died as a result of injuries sustained following the failure of the wire for the provision crane.  At the time he was working aloft in a basket suspended by the crane.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Ship remains fit to proceed

SOLASStatus: Jolly Nero: Unknown/unspecified, JOLLY NERO: SOLAS
SummaryOfEvents:
The Italian-flagged container ship JOLLY NERO had contact with a 50-metre control tower in the Italian port of Genoa, leaving seven people dead and up to three missing.  The accident occurred at about 23:00 (local time) on Tuesday 7 May 2013, when a shift change was taking place in the control tower.
The JOLLY NERO, almost 240 metres (787 feet) in length was manoeuvring out of the port with the help of tugboats in calm conditions, on its way to Naples and the Middle East.  The impact of the accident caused an entire building to collapse and left the port’s control tower listing at an angle of 45 degrees.
Search & Rescue teams worked assiduously throughout the night in the waters around the tower.
The cause of the accident, whether human error or mechanical fault, has yet to be confirmed
The JOLLY NERO has been impounded and the captain is being questioned

SOLASStatus: CONMAR AVENUE: SOLAS, MAERSK KALMAR: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents:
At 15:55 hrs, on 7 May 2013, the Antiguan flagged container ship Conmar Avenue collided with the container ship Maersk Kalmar, which is registered in Holland, on the Outer Weser between fairway buoys 29 and 31 in the Fedderwarder Fairway.
The sea was calm and visibility good. Both ships were heading for Bremerhaven and had previously followed the course of the fairway under pilotage.
The collision happened during an overtaking manoeuvre by the Conmar Avenue, during which technical problems occurred with the supply of lubricating oil to the course of the day. However, this time it was not possible to remedy the difficulties at short notice. Therefore, the engine shut down automatically to prevent serious damage. As a result, the Conmar Avenue lost manoeuvrability and was drawn into the wake of much larger Maersk Kalmar. Despite contra-rudder, she then turned towards the Maersk Kalmar due to hydrodynamic interactions. The Conmar Avenue’s forecastle rammed into the Starboard side of the Maersk Kalmar’s aft section at an angle of about 60 degrees. The force of the collision caused 15 containers on the Conmar Avenue to fall overboard. Both ships sustained material damage above the waterline. The accident did not result in any injuries and there was no pollution of any significance. The fairway had to be temporarily closed to transiting shipping.
The Maersk Kalmar was able to continue her voyage to Bremerhaven under her own steam. Due to the ebb current and her loss of manoeuvrability, the Conmar Avenue ran aground outside the fairway level with buoy 30 after the collision. She anchored there and was pulled back into the fairway at about 18:30 with the help of five tugs. After that, this ship initially continued her own steam, too. At about 19:41 hrs, technical problems with the supply of lubricating oil were experienced again shortly before reaching the port boundary in the area of buoy 45, however. Following that, the precaution was taken to designate the Conmar Avenue a ship not under command. She was towed to the berth by tugs and made fast there at 21:05 hrs.

At about 0008LT on 07 May 2013, while the loading at port of Kakinada was in progress in cargo hold No. 4, NO.4 crane cabin viewing panel fell down, hit one stevedore and caused serious injury to his arm and head, then led to the death of the stevedore.

Location: GULF OF GUINEA 135 MILES SOUTHWEST OF PORT HARCOURT, NIGERIA
SummaryOfEvents:
THE COMORIAN-FLAGGED BUNKERING TANKER CAUGHT FIRE IN THE GULF OF GUINEA 135 MILES SOUTHWEST OF PORT HARCOURT, NIGERIA IN LAT. 03 10N., LONG. 005 55E., AM ON 07/05/13.

CREW ABANDONED THE TANKER. 13 CREW WERE RESCUED BY FSV 'ABRAHAM', 1 CREW MEMBER MISSING. MV 'AL-KAT' ALSO ATTENDED THE SCENE AND ENGAGED IN FIREFIGHTING OPERATIONS. THE RESCUED CREW WERE TAKEN TO THE OIL RIG 'SEDCO EXPRESS' AND WERE SUBSEQUENTLY TAKEN BY 2 HELICOPTERS TO A MEDICAL FACILITY IN NIGERIA.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Ship remains fit to proceed

SummaryOfEvents: On 5 May 2013, all six occupants of the 8.0m rigid inflatable boat Milly were ejected from the boat into the water as it was making a turn in the Camel Estuary, Cornwall. The engine cut-out ‘kill cord’ mechanism was not activated as it had not been attached to the driver. Consequently, the boat continued to circle with no-one at the helm, at full power, striking some of those in the water, fatally injuring two and seriously injuring two others.

Location: BAY OF BENGAL 2 MILES SOUTHWEST OF PREPARIS ISLAND, MYNAMAR
SummaryOfEvents:
THE MALTESE-FLAGGED BULK CARRIER 'RIO GOLD' STRANDED IN THE BAY OF BENGAL 2 MILES SOUTHWEST OF PREPARIS ISLAND, MYNAMAR IN LAT. 14 49N., LONG. 093 36E., ON 05/05/13. SUBSEQUENTLY ARRIVED IN TOW AT CHITTAGONG, BANGLADESH ON 17/11/13 FOR BREAKING UP.

NO INJURIES OR POLLUTION REPORTED. SUSTAINED DAMAGE TO HULL, PROPELLER AND RUDDER. MYNAMAR NAVAL VESSEL ATTENDED THE SCENE. REFLOATED ON 13/05/13 WITH ASSISTANCE FROM TUG 'TSAVLIRIS UNITY'. SUBSEQUENTLY TAKEN IN TOW OF TUG 'CONFIDENCE' BOUND LUMUT, MALAYSIA. TOW TRANSFERRED TO 'TSAVLIRIS UNITY' ON 20/05/13 AND CONVOY ARRIVED AT LUMUT ON 27/05/13 FOR INSPECTION.

Location: Chevron Terminal at Escravos, Delta  State, Nigeria.
SummaryOfEvents:
At about 0443 hours on May 26th 2013, MV Jascon 4, a vessel belonging to a Chevron Contractor, West African Ventures (WAV) including the persons on board capsized and sank while supporting an export Tanker MT Aleksey Kosygin 
belonging to Holman Freeman William (HFW), that was loading at Single Buoy Mooring (SBM) #3, at one of Chevron Nigeria Limited (CNL) loading points 30km offshore in the Escravos area of Delta State, Nigeria. Incident Response was activated immediately the incident occurred including search and rescue operations with surface vessels, helicopters and certified divers. Between the time of occurrence and May 28th 2013, ten bodies were recovered from the capsized vessel and certified dead. However, on May 28th 2013, one of the victims, a cook on the ill-fated vessel was rescued, found to be alive and was medivaced to a hospital where he received medical attention, got stabilized and later discharged. At time of this report, one member of the crew is reportedly still missing.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Serious injuries,Total loss of the ship

Location: GULF OF TONKIN, 6.9 MILES SOUTH OF COTO ISLAND QUANG NINH PROVINCE, VIETNAM
SummaryOfEvents:
THE VIETNAMESE-FLAGGED GENERAL CARGO SHIP 'LAM HONG 26' SUSTAINED FOULED PROPELLER, DEVELOPED 20 DEGREE LIST AND SANK IN THE GULF OF TONKIN, 6.9 MILES SOUTH OF COTO ISLAND QUANG NINH PROVINCE, VIETNAM IN LAT. 20 50N., LONG. 107 45E., AT 0138 HOURS LT ON 03/05/13 IN HEAVY WEATHER.

NO INJURIES OR POLLUTION REPORTED. REQUESTED SAR ASSISTANCE. ALL 8 CREW WERE RESCUED BY PASSING MV 'HOANG HUY 36'.

ShipsInvolved: HHL NEW YORK (IMO 9448372), MFV Ocean Dawn (-)
SOLASStatus: HHL NEW YORK: Unknown/unspecified, MFV Ocean Dawn: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents: The MV HHL New York completed berthing operations at the port of Fenit at 17:15 hrs on 1st November 2013. The ship was berthed on its starboard side and head out. During the night, a mooring ring on the quayside failed. The ship fell astern and to port, causing its bow ropers to part. As the ship fell astern it caused damage when it made contact with the fishing ship MFV Ocean Dawn. The ship used its own power to secure itself to the berth.

On Monday 1 April 2013, the emergency services attended the motor cruiser Arniston on Windermere, Cumbria, where a mother and her daughter had been found unconscious. The two females were taken by air ambulance to Lancaster Royal Infirmary where they were pronounced deceased. A postmortem concluded that the cause of death was carbon monoxide poisoning. The carbon monoxide poisoning had resulted from the inhalation of fumes emitted from a portable generator installed in the boat’s engine bay. The external exhaust system fitted to the portable generator had been modified to incorporate a silencer that had become detached from both the generator and the outlet pipe to the vessel’s side. The portable generator’s engine exhaust fumes filled the engine bay and spread through gaps in an internal bulkhead into the aft cabin where the mother and daughter were asleep.

Location: Shiomi Berth 4, Sakaisenboku-ku, Hanshin Port, Japan
SummaryOfEvents: The general cargo ship FAVOR SAILING listed to starboard in the waters off Izumiotsu city, and was towed to Hanshin port. The crew members tried to stabilize the ship at Shiomi Berth 4, but the ship listed to port and sank. All crew members evacuated to the berth and no one was injured.

The 127 m long Consouth was en route from Tuzla (Turkey) to Marsaxlokk (Malta). The vessel was in ballast. On 29 April 2013, while the chief mate was standing the 04-08 navigational watch, the vessel collided with the 133 m long general cargo vessel Pirireis approaching on a nearly reciprocal course but clear on her starboard side. At the time of the collision it was still dark, the weather was calm and clear with little variable winds of force 2 and a seastate 1.
On M/V Consouth both radars were in operation and the vessel’s steering was in autopilot mode. No lookout was posted. The OOW had noticed the approaching Pirireis well in advance. After he evaluated ARPA readings, the CPA showed to being not less than 0,8 nm on starboard side, thus both vessels should have passed green to green in a safe distance. Once having almost reached the CPA the OOW on Consouth suddenly saw Pirireis turning to starboard showing her port side with the red light rapidly approaching in a crossing situation. The collision could not be avoided.

Consouth penetrated heavily into Pirireis’ aft port quarter.
Pirireis sunk rapidly. Seven of her 17 crew survived, two dead seafarers could be retrieved and eight remained missing.

Other than the obligation of a flag State to conduct a marine safety investigation into a very serious marine casualty it is the aim of the flag State to identify why a standard traffic situation at sea with two vessels encountering each other in darkness in good weather conditions could escalate into a deadly collision.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Ship remains fit to proceed
Cargo1: General cargo, break-bulk, containers, may include IMDG cargo

SummaryOfEvents: Myanmar coastal tanker Myan Aung and Car carrier Malacca Highway collided on 23rd April 2013 in Yangon river. MT. Myan Aung was total loss after capsizing and all 17 crew were rescued.

SOLASStatus: MALACCA HIGHWAY: SOLAS, MYAN- AUNG: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents:
RECENT NEWSTanker Myan-Aung sank after collision with car carrier Malacca Highway 
Myanmar coastal tanker Myan-Aung collided on Apr 28 13 with car carrier Malacca Highway on Yangon river at around 15:00 LT near Thilawa port. Myan-Aung was on the way to Yangon. Tanker sank, reportedly after capsizing, 17 crew rescued by Myanmar navy ship. Malacca Highway reportedly detained in Yangon for investigation.

SummaryOfEvents:
During the early morning of 27 April 2013, the master of the chemical tanker YM Pluto was on the forecastle deck in adverse weather conditions, attempting to stop water from leaking through the forecastle store hatch into the forecastle and bowthruster space. 

Unexpectedly, the ship slammed into a very large wave.  For a short moment, the seas that were shipped and the dense sea spray obscured the bow from the bridge.  The master was exposed to the violent impact of the breaking wave.  As the water washed over the bow, the master was tossed away from the forecastle deck to the catwalk. 

It is highly probable that in so doing, the master hit violently against the hydraulic manifold block of the port windlass and sustained fatal injuries. 

The investigation concluded that the decision-making structure, the risk assessment and mitigation processes leading to the attempted operation were amongst the main contributors to this fatal accident.

A crewman set fire to his cabin from a lighted cigarette when he fell asleep on his bunk after drinking several cans of beer. The crew began fire fighting and the fire was brought under control. The accommodation was subsequently opened and the fire re-started. The fire became out of control for the crew and the coastal state navy and coastguard attended and quenched the fire. Three cabins were badly damaged and the rest of the accommodation area was smoke and heat damaged. The vessel was towed to port for repairs.
Ship mooring alongside the berth No. 122B without a crew, at 22:00 hrs. on 25.04.2013 throught the port control video cameras noticed that the vessel lurched and the bottom lying on the ground.

InitialEvent: Hull failure / failure of watertight doors / ports, etc.
SummaryOfEvents: The 8.7m fishing vessel Speedwell foundered in a depth of 83m. Shortly before the vessel's loss, its skipper contacted persons ashore and advised that the vessel was taking in water through deck hatch(es). The body of the skipper has not been found.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

On 23 April 2013, at approximately 0818 Pacific Daylight Saving Time, the fishing vessel American Dynasty experienced a complete loss of electrical power (blackout) while approaching the graving dock in Esquimalt, British Columbia. The vessel was under the conduct of a docking pilot and was being assisted by 2 tugs at the time. Following the blackout, the American Dynasty gained speed to an estimated 5 knots, veered to starboard, and struck the HMCS Winnipeg, which was berthed nearby at the Canadian Forces Base Esquimalt. There was extensive damage to both vessels and minor injuries were sustained by 6 shipyard workers on the HMCS Winnipeg.
Self-ignition of a vehicle on a cargo deck. Cause to have been a car battery. Fire could be extinguished quickly.

The two fishermen of HERMANOS POLA were hauling the fishing gear when a blow from the sea capsized the fishing vessel. Crew members were working on deck but they didn't wear life-jackets, both fell down into the sea and were rescued but one of the seaman died days later from the consequences of drowning.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Ship rendered unfit to proceed,Total loss of the ship

SOLASStatus: Norfolk Express: Unknown/unspecified, NORFOLK EXPRESS: SOLAS
SummaryOfEvents:
In the morning of 18 April 2013, the container ship Norfolk Express left the Stromkaje at Bremerhaven to begin her voyage to Le Havre, France. The usual tests on the main engine and steering gear carried out beforehand revealed no faults.
The rudder unexpectedly remained at hard to port just a few minutes after casting off the lines. Immediate use of the tiller made it possible to regain control of the ship.
The chief and the electrician searched extensively for the fault for several minutes, but did not find it.
The steering gear suddenly returned to normal and the voyage was continued . The two individuals remained in the steering gear compartment as a precaution. The Norfolk Express accelerated to 18kts and proceeded down the River Weser. At 09:31 hrs failed again and the rudder remained and sailed towards the Landgütjen breakwater in a wide arc. The engine was stopped and the port anchor dropped. Despite that, the ship continued to move forward with her bulbous bow ramming against the dam and only came to a standstill there. The damage to the Norfolk express was so severe that she laid up for repairs in dry dock for weeks. Fortunately, there were neither injuries nor environmental damage.

SummaryOfEvents: On 17 April 2013, 08:30 hrs,  Chinese fishing  ship which belonged to the Shanghai Kaichuang Distant Water Fishing Company undertook krill  fishing operation in the Antarctic waters with the approval of CCAMLR. At around 8:30 am if 17th April (Chilean local time), the ship Kaixin unfortunately caught fire  at the position of 63°07'S, 58°57'W, which endangered life safety of all the 97 crews on board. With the rescue of nearby Norwegian ship Juvel, Greek Ship Sky Frost and Chinese ship Furonghai, all 97 crew on board were safely transferred and finally returned to China on 3rd May. Chilean navy also dispatched a professional rescue ship to the incident area to carry out rescue work. In the morning on 21st April, Kaixin sank at the position of 62°27.3'S, 57°24.5'W.

The spanish flagged tug IBAIZABAL DIEZ was engaged in a towing service for a wind farm thats was being built up in german waters. IBAIZABAL DIEZ was the leading tug of a composed tow of three: two tugs, one at each end, and the towed barge. The barge was carrying several huge pieces for the wind farm. The composed tow was arriving the wind farm, so they started the procedures to connect the barge to two standing anchors, fora and aft, that were in place. On board "I10", a superintendent contracted by the builders of the wind farm was inspecting the works and taking photographs. In one moment, crew were having some difficulties to release the marking buoy that was connected to a heavy anchor cable. The marking buoy had been heaved up to the fcs'le level, but outside the vessel, with a heaving line, and this line was in tension on the warping end of the winch. The superintendent beat the line in tension with his foot to check it; then the line released and catched the other leg of the superintendent, throwing him down and being dragged along the ground until his body was stopped by a vessel's fitting. The line in tension then pulled out the leg off the person. The superintendent became seriously injured andwas subsequently evacuated by helicopter to a hospital.

London, Apr 15 -- A press report, dated today, states: General cargo Tian Yun (3911 gt, built 1981) sank in the Republic of Korea waters, on Sunday afternoon. The 17 crew members on-board the vessel were rescued, according to the Chinese Consulate General in Busan. Following the incident, Republic of Korea Police sent helicopters and patrol boats to rescue the crews, said sources with the Consulate General.

A pay loader fell after the pad eye on the pay loader that the lifting sling was attached to failed while being lowered into cargo hold No. 3 using a ship’s crane.  The pay loader landed on top of a pay loader already in the hold.  The flag State’s preliminary investigation has identified that the pay loaders and sling were supplied by the stevedores.  It was also determined that the stevedores rigged the sling.

Vessel was struck by a large wave at the stern.  A large amount of water washed into and then out of both the streamer and gua decks.  Three crew members (two from Malaysia and one from Ivory Coast) were injured and one crew member from Colombia was lost overboard.
The vessel VICTORIA VII   reported on April 10 of 2013 at 23:10 that a crew member was hit by the crane´s hook that swing dangerously from right to left as a result of this accident he died.

The recreational craft "Meri Tuuli" have registration in Germany and it usually operates in Portugal being rented to crews who embark at Algarve, sailing on the Portuguese coast of the continent up to north, or vice versa.
On April 10th of 2013, this boat with 5 crew members on board, departed from the marina of Peniche at 08:00 heading Leixões (Leça da Palmeira marina). According to a statement from the skipper, they had planned to go to Figueira da Foz, or alternatively, to Leixões. But according to the registration system “Latitude 32”, the sailboat effectively had Leixões as a final destination. On this trip, the vessel was already coming from Lagos having overcome Cascais marina.
When it was navigating the surroundings of Figueira da Foz entrance, there was a larger wave that with a stroke caused the listing and projected overboard 4 of its 5 crew members.
The sea conditions that day were increasingly being worse with a very fresh wind (with gusts up to 14 m / s) and very rough (wave 4/5 meters) at the time and place of the accident.
The entrance of the harbour of Figueira da Foz was closed to vessels with a length less than 35 meters.
The crew members of the sailboat were assisted by the lifeboat "Patrão Macatrão" and a boat from the Maritime Police.
One of the crew members and an agent of the Local command of Maritime Police of Figueira da Foz lost their life. The wounded were collected and assisted at the hospital of Figueira da Foz.

SOLASStatus: Ambassadeur: SOLAS, AMBASSADEUR: Unknown/unspecified, Loic-Lucas: Unknown/unspecified
Location: Entrance of the Dover North-East Bound Lane
SummaryOfEvents:
During the 7 April 2013 night, the French scallop dredger LOÏC-LUCAS was fishing in  the south of the Greenwich Racon Buoy, at the entrance of the Dover TSS north-east bound  lane. The sailor on watch was on his own on the bridge, steering manually. The heading was  varying from 070° to 075° and the speed was around 3 knots. The two all-round red lights of a  vessel not under command were exhibited, as well as the underway vessel lights, the fishing  lights and the ship’s deck lights.  
The sailor on watch aboard LOÏC-LUCAS saw on the radar display a vessel in the  vicinity and thought she would alter course.  At the same time, and in the same area, the Dutch cargo vessel AMBASSADEUR was  heading 074° at about 9 knots. The master was on his own on the bridge and the vessels in the vicinity (except for LOÏC-LUCAS) were processed by the Radar anti-collision system (range 12  miles) and by the AIS. A TV program (or a DVD film) was being played on the bridge. 
 Soon after midnight LOÏC-LUCAS made an DSC distress call received by Jobourg and  Gris-Nez MRCC. However, during the first minutes of the operation, only Gris-Nez MRCC could  manage to communicate (by VHF on channel 16) with the LOÏC-LUCAS’s skipper. The latter  explained that she had just been collided by a cargo vessel; within one minute, she precised that  she was the cargo vessel AMBASSADEUR and transmitted her position. A major water leak in the  steering room was observed by LOÏC-LUCAS’ engineer.  
Less than five minutes after LOÏC-LUCAS’ first call, the master of AMBASSADEUR  modified the radar range (6 miles) for a while, then he has been plotting the blip of a small  vessel located 1 mile on his stern. This operation had been repeated several times, while  AMBASSADEUR was sailing away without reducing speed or altering course. The radar drop down  menu shows that the operator had done an identification search. 

 Fifteen minutes after the presumed collision between these two vessels, Gris-Nez  Traffic contacted AMBASSADEUR and informed her of the situation. The master declared that he  was surprised, then AMBASSADEUR made a U-turn and headed to LOÏC-LUCAS’ position. Two  fishing vessels had been also called up by Jobourg MRCC. 
 
When the LOÏC-LUCAS’ crew was out of danger, AMBASSADEUR resumed her voyage to  Moerdijk (Pays-Bas). LOÏC-LUCAS would sink soon after in 56 meters deep waters.

On April 4th, 2013, by 01:45h, an employee of Laborsines - Empresa de Trabalho Portuário, Unipessoal, Ltd (company subcontracted by PSA Sines), hereinafter referred to as "victim", was performing his duties onboard the container ship “MSC Irene” (Terminal XXI of Sines Port). 
During loading operations onboard the container ship “MSC Irene”, the victim was performing the functions of Ship Operations Supervisor (SOS), supporting the crane operator. 
At the time of the accident, the crane operator began operating a 20' (feet) cargo container in the ship's hold, following the instructions given by radio by the victim. 
The crane operator realized that his fellow (SOS) had fallen into the hold of the ship, and immediately interrupted the continuity of the loading operation. 
After given the warning and the arrival of the rescue teams, the victim was pronounced dead at 02:12h.

A mother and her daughter suffered fatal carbon monoxide poisoning while on board a privately owned 8.7m motor cruiser on an inland waterway. The source of the CO was from a petrol driven generator installed in the boats engine bay which had been attached to an improvised exhaust system which subsequently failed. The boats factory fitted carbon monoxide sensors failed to operate because they were not connected to a power supply. UK MAIB Location Description: Bowness-on-Windemere
Consequences1: Loss of life,Serious injuries,Ship remains fit to proceed

On March 30, 2013 the vessel ATLANTIK CONFIDENCE suffered a fire in the engine room. The vessel began to take on water and the crew safely abandoned ship. The crew was rescued by vessel ALPINE MARIE and the vessel continued to take on water until it sank on April 3, 2013.

29th March 2013 at 20.20 pm. pilot on board m/v " Valentin Pikul ". In this time the ship encounter with heavy weather SE winds of near gale force and very strong current. The tugboat for assistance in maneuvering has been ordered. At 20.35 pm. a tugboats " Stumbras " and " Klasco-1 " has approached to a vessel. From tugboarts on a vessel the tow lines are taken in and made fast in fore and aft. At 20.40 pm. all mooring lines are gone and a vessel clear left the berth. At 20.45 pm. have begun a turn of the vessel in the channel with help of tugs. In period of turn the vessel not working m/v " Valentin Pikul " main engine and bow thruster. At 20.50 pm. the aft tugboat " Klasco-1 " has been pressed to starboard of a vessel, in consequence of which m/v " Valentin Pikul " has been  serious damage by tense tow line.

Location: NORTH ATLANTIC OCEAN 730 MILES EAST OF ST. JOHNS, NL, CANADA
SummaryOfEvents:
THE CANADIAN-STERN TRAWLER 'CAPE BEAVER' FOUNDERED IN THE NORTH ATLANTIC OCEAN 730 MILES EAST OF ST. JOHNS, NL, CANADA IN LAT. 48 37N., LONG. 038 08W., PM ON 29/03/13 IN HEAVY WEATHER.

NO INJURIES OR POLLUTION REPORTED. ALL CREW RESCUED BY FV 'CAPE BALLARD' AND TAKEN TO HAFNARFJORDUR, ICELAND. AT THE TIME OF THE INCIDENT THE VESSEL WAS BEING TOWED BY 'CAPE BALLARD' TO A DEMOLITION FACILITY IN BELGIUM FOR BREAKING UP.

Fishing boat SIEMPRE REINAR departed from Avils with two crewmembers bound to fishing grounds at 09:00 h. When she was still in passage, 3 miles off coast, crew felt a strong beat at the bottom of the boat, around the keel area starboard side. Immediately, they realised that a heavy flooding was in progress and spreading out everywhere, including the E/R, as the boat was not compartmented. Crew tried to start the G/S pump and pump out the water, and also to steer to shore but it was not possible as the boat was"dead", without power neither propulsion. Then, before the boat became foundered , the skipper called the SAR services by Ch 16 VHF and deployed the liferaft. Crew was rescued in short by a helicopter from the liferaft. Further investigation showed that there were not any evidence (sights or advices) for floating debris, logs or missing containers in the area. The rescue helicopter did not see anything abnormal in the area, neither the supporting boats from SASEMAR that inspected the location after the accident.
Consequences1: Ship rendered unfit to proceed,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents: Vessel grounded while en route to Turkey, pilot was onboard.

VERSIÓN EN ESPAÑOL:
El 27 de Marzo a las 14:28 horas con buenas condiciones meteorológicas y de visibilidad el Bulk Carrier liberiano, "Vega Taurus", de 33.044 TRG, 190 metros de eslora, 11,6 metros de calado y cargado con 34.174 toneladas de mineral de cobre, navegaba de Norte a Sur el Canal Gray, con destino a India.
Por circunstancias que se investigan, la nave se desvió de la ruta de navegación previamente fijada, golpeando su casco en el "Bajo Connor", lo cual le produjo la rotura del timón, la hélice, vías de agua en un estanque y deformaciones en el casco por la banda de estribor. La nave fondeó en las cercanías del área del siniestro, quedando imposibilitada de navegar por sus propios medios. Producto de la varada no se registraron personas lesionadas, ni contaminación al medio marino.

ENGLISH VERSION:
On 27 March, at 2:28 PM, under good visibility and weather conditions, the Liberian bulk carrier "Vega Taurus", of 33,044 GRT, 190 meters length and 11.6 meters draft, loaded with 34,174 tons of copper, was navigating from North to South through the Gray channel, bound to India.
Due to circumstances that are currently under investigation, the ship altered its course and hit bottom at Bajo Connor. As a result, the rudder and the propeller were damaged, a tank started leaking, and the hull resulted deformed on the starboard side. The ship anchored on a nearby site, and remained unable to navigate under its own power. 
There were no injuries to the crew, nor damage to the marine environment caused by the grounding.

On 24 March 2013 the luxury catamaran Mousetrap sailed from Saint-Martin, Caribbean Sea, to cross the Atlantic Ocean bound to La Ciotat, France, with a stop in the Azores. The crew was made of eight sailors and one engineer from the LORIMA Company, which built the mast.

On 27 March the passage of a weak squall line was forecast. During the watch from noon to 1.30 pm, the weather worsened with showers. Mousetrap was sailing then at about 13 knots with one reef in the mainsail and solent, at 70° from the apparent wind.

Soon after the end of the squall, the female lookout on watch went down to the accommodation deck to inform the captain that the wind was blowing at more than 30 knots. She had just resumed her task when the mast broke out in three parts; she had barely had time to lay down on the flybridge to protect herself. But the helmsman had been crushed by the main shroud against the steering console. All the efforts of the crew to revive him had been in vain.

 The complete rigging comprising the mast, the cables and the sails had been abandoned to sea and sank. After some checking and repairs, she sailed back under power to her port of departure where she arrived on 30 March.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Ship remains fit to proceed

SummaryOfEvents:
As usually on Thursdays, m/v Silja Europa had a safety drill for the crew while staying at quayside in Tallinn, Estonia. After the Captain had given orders for evacuation, and the crew had gone to the evacuation stations, a subcontractor got stuck between a watertight door. He was working onboard in the galley department while the ship was at harbour and was on his way to the Aux. Engine Room to get an additional tool needed for his work.
While moving from one watertight section to another alone he got caught between the watertight door no. 1.6 which had been closed for the drill. The injured subcontractor died in the hospital at the same day.

THE INDONESIAN-FLAGGED TUG 'SANLE 18' CAUGHT FIRE WHILST MOORED AT THE TANOTO SHIPYARD, JALAN SAMULUN, SINGAPORE AT 2130 HOURS LT ON 26/03/13.

FIRE STARTED IN ADJACENT MOORED WOODEN TUG 'CHUMPHON' AND SPREAD TO 'SANLE 18' AND 2 OTHER TUGS, 'SANLE 19' AND 'VANIDA'. SOME OIL LEAKED INTO SEA AND CAUGHT FIRE. BLAZE FINALLY EXTINGUISHED AT 0430 HOURS LT THE FOLLOWING MORNING WITH ASSISTANCE FROM LOCAL FIRE SERVICES AND FIRE FIGHTING TUGS 'FIREFIGHTER I' AND 'II'. 1 CREW MEMBER DEAD, 2 MISSING AND 4 INJURED. SUSTAINED SERIOUS DAMAGE. INVESTIGATION EFFECTED.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Pollution,Ship remains fit to proceed

SummaryOfEvents:
THE SPANISH-FLAGGED STERN TRAWLER 'ALDAN' SUSTAINED MAIN ENGINE FAILURE WHILST DEPARTING KILLYBEGS, IRELAND IN LAT. 54 38N., LONG. 008 26W., ON 22/03/13. SUBSEQUENTLY REPORTED SOLD TO UNDISCLOSED INTERESTS FOR BREAKING UP.

PILOT TUG PROCEEDED TO ASSIST AND EFFECTED TOW BACK TO BERTH FOR INSPECTION. SUBSEQUENTLY TOWED BY OCEAN GOING TUG TO CANGAS DEL MORRAZO, SPAIN WHERE ARRIVED ON 07/04/13.

On car deck 5 on board the ferry boat "Pascal Paoli" calling in at Marseilles (so without any passenger on board), a shore AB (3 years before - and graduated as "sea going" AB), involved in the loading operations of the trailers, believing the positioning of a trailer was complete, went between a bulkhead and the trailer to secure the lashing chains. The trailer was not fully placed. It moved back and trapped the AB. Deeply injured and shocked, he was taken to hospital. His sick leave lasted almost one year. This accident was taken to the knowledge of the BEAmer in a personal way (because it had occurred in a port) and 3 months later. The owner took immediate corrective actions, so the BEAmer did not have to make recommendations.

3 days after departure, from Abidjan, the seiner Via Euros was fishing in the Gulf of Guinea. An engineer officer decided to clean the heat exchanger units belonging to the cargo cooling system. After cleaning the port side one he put back that device. He began to operate the starboard side exchanger. He noticed a small steam leakage coming from the port one associated with an abnormal temperature. In order to manage the pressure, he tried to open a valve to evacuate the water towards the bilge. The pressure pushed the bonnet of this valve out of position, freeing steam. The engineer was heavily burnt on the right arm. French MRCC Boulogne was informed. In the early evening, the ship began sailing towards Abidjan whilst a French warship (with a doctor on board) approached its position. The doctor went on board the next night to check the injured man. He disembarked in the port of Abidjan and transferred to a hospital in Paris. Consequences: 30 days off for the engineer.

Whilst heaving up the trawl, on board the Alf, an AB was injured in the face by an iron block (shortly after a repair of a chain belonging to this fishing gear). The Master called the French MRCC who communicated with the British MRCC. Evacuation of the AB was decided and done by helicopter to a British hospital. Consequences: facial trauma 30 days off.
