SummaryOfEvents: On 20 March 2013, an engineer on board the bulk carrier Nireas was fatally injured after being struck by flying debris when the observation window of a main air receiver drainage pot exploded. At the time of the explosion, the ship was at anchor off Gladstone, Queensland, and the engineer was carrying out the routine task of draining water from the pressurised air receiver.

Location: TONKIN GULF 30 MILES NORTHEAST OF VUNG ANG, VIETNAM
SummaryOfEvents:
THE VIETNAMESE-FLAGGED BULK CARRIER 'VINACOMIN 03' SANK AFTER COLLISION WITH MV 'VINACOMIN 02' IN THE TONKIN GULF 30 MILES NORTHEAST OF VUNG ANG, VIETNAM IN LAT. 18 29N., LONG. 106 41E., AT 0157 HOURS LT ON 20/03/13.

13 CREW RESCUED IMMEDIATELY BY 'VINACOMIN 02' AND THE 14TH CREW MEMBER WAS RESCUED 3 HOURS LATER. NO INJURIES REPORTED.
On 19 March 2013 at 12:10hrs (LT) the vessel JPO GEMINI made contact with berth at the Port of Onne Seaport, Nigeria. As a result 40 metric tons of diesel fuel were spilled.

A fire incident happened on board the general cargo vessel “Yong Sheng” (the Vessel) while berthing alongside Berth No.6 of Zhang Hua Bang of Shanghai. The cause of the fire incident was probably due to ignition of the flammable geotextile material inside the lower deck aft cargo compartment by sparks generated from the welding process. A fire watchman could not escape from the lower deck of compartment. The rescue team found his body but was later certified dead.

SummaryOfEvents: Collision between the bulk carrier Chou Shan and  MV CMA CGM FLORIDA, both ships are seriously damage.

“M/V CS AZALEA” laden with 42,010MT of coal in bulk left Muara Satui, Indonesia bound for Taizhou, China on March 14, 2013 with drawing draft F’cle 10.55 and Poop 10.80. There was no particular abnormality at the time of the departure. 
On 19:45 hrs March 17 2013, while sailing at sea of Philippines, the third officer took over the bridge watch with quarter master when sailing 12 Knots. 
Around 19:55 hrs March 17 2013 duty officer(3/O) identified some fishing boats on her head side also some fishing boats around her course line. Therefore 3/O changed her course to starboard side, however he identified again some fishing boats around 20:05 hours. He altered course again to starboard side to avoid some fishing boats, but the vessel got stranded at Queen of Sea bank at the moment around 20:18 hours on March 17, 2013 
The vessel was damaged as below 
1.	 Ballast Tank from Fore Peak Tank to No. 5 Ballast Tank. 
2.	 Engine room Sea & Overboard valve 

The vessel arrived at Zhoushan shipyard for damage repair on March 28, 2013. 
The damaged parts were repaired permanently as below. 
1) Replaced plate Fore Peak & No.1 Port & Stbd Ballast Tank 
2) Replaced plate No.2 Port & Stbd Ballast Tank 
3) Replaced plate No.3 & 4 Port & Stbd Ballast Tank 
4) Replaced plate No.5 Port & Stbd Ballast Tank 
5) Repaired Sea & Overboard Valve
 Class surveyor inspected and confirmed the permanent repair of damage parts at Zhoushan Ship Yard

DURING LOADING OPERATION, CARGO SLING HIT A PERSON WHO WAS RESPONSIBLE FOR COORDINATING THE LOADING OPERATION. THE MAN FELL ONTO THE BERTH AND WAS HEAVILY INJURED, HIS HEAD HITTING THE HARD SURFACE. HE LOST HIS LIFE AS A CONSEQUENCE.

The general cargo ship Danio grounded at Longstone, one of the Farne Islands off the coast 12 of Northumberland, England. The Farne Islands are a nature reserve and one of the 32 marine environmental high-risk areas (MEHRA) around the UK coast. They are also a European special protection area and support a signification tourism industry. The main lighthouse on Inner Farne Island has a range of 24 nautical miles.
The visibility at the time of the accident was good.
Danio made ten calls in the 6 weeks preceding the accident. At the time of grounding, it was on passage from Perth, Scotland to Genk, Belgium and had 1500 tonnes of timber cargo on board along with 27 tonnes of gas oil and 2 tonnes of lubricating oils.
The master and chief officer shared the navigation watches on a 6 hours off basis. In port, the chief officer was responsible from cargo work. The master did not share the cargo work with the chief officer; he dealt with matters on the ship including surveys, inspection and communication with the owners and charterers.

The vessel will likely re enter Zeebrugge this morning (16/03/13).  Pls can you arrange attendance to inspect the damage.  The hull has been penetrated around 6M above water line on port side forward in way of focsle.

Istanbul, Mar 15 -- General cargo Nova D. (1716 gt, built 1981), undergoing cargo operations at Eregli port, during unberthing manoeuvres, drifted to shore and ran aground in shallow water area in the port at 1400 today due to prevailing strong south-westerly winds and heavy swells. A tug from Eregli port attended the incident scene in order to provide further assistance. No leaks, pollution and injury was reported due to incident. The vessel remains stationary at the grounding position and the crew are working on in order to attempt refloating under its own power.

More problems for Miami-based Carnival Cruise Lines after another of the ships develops engine problems mid cruise.
The Carnival Dream, which was on the return leg of a seven day excursion, is now docked in St. Maarten.
U.S. Coast Guard spokeswoman Sabrina Laberdesque said Thursday that Carnival Dream's captain notified the agency of trouble with the ship's propulsion system. The ship's emergency generator, which powers propulsion for ship, has reportedly failed. The Coast Guard said they have been reassured by the ship's captain that their main generator and sewage systems are unaffected by the failure.

A statement from the company acknowledged the problem but emphasized that at no time did it completely lose power.

SummaryOfEvents:
THE FILIPINO-FLAGGED PASSENGER SHIP 'MA. ANGELICA GRACE' CAPSIZED AND SANK WHILST LOADING CARGO AT CABAHUG WHARF, MANDAUE CITY, PHILIPPINES AT 2145 HOURS LT ON 11/03/13.

ALL 7 PASSENGERS AND 18 CREW EVACUATED SAFELY. NO INJURIES REPORTED. SOME OIL POLLUTION OBSERVED IN WATER. COASTGUARD VESSEL ASSISTED WITH DEPLOYMENT OF ANTI POLLUTION MEASURES. REPORTED CAUSE OF CAPSIZE WAS EXCESSIVE WAVES CAUSED BY A PASSING VESSEL.

While transferring a cargo consisting of three steel sheet coils using the derrick crane of the ocean going vessel Forest Arrow from the cargo hold of the Vessel, the starboard slewing wire of the derrick crane of the vessel was suddenly parted, causing the cargo lower to swing to port side violently and descending at the same time, moved towards the stevedore waiting inside the cargo hold.  The stevedore was hit by the steel wire during dodging. He fell down on the bottom of cargo hold. He was sent to the hospital by helicopter and was certified dead later in the hospital.

Location: CARIBBEAN SEA 5 MILES NORTHEAST OF BOCAS DE CENIZA, BARRANQUILLA, COLOMBIA
SummaryOfEvents:
THE GENERAL CARGO SHIP 'FM EXPRESS' OF SAO TOME AND PRINCIPE CAUGHT FIRE IN ENGINE ROOM IN THE CARIBBEAN SEA 5 MILES NORTHEAST OF BOCAS DE CENIZA, BARRANQUILLA, COLOMBIA IN LAT. 11 10N., LONG. 074 49W., AT 0900 HOURS LT ON 10/03/13 IN GOOD VISIBILITY.

ALL 8 CREW ABANDONED SHIP TO LIFERAFT, RESCUED BY COASTGUARD VESSEL AND TAKEN TO BARRANQUILLA. 4 CREW RECEIVED HOSPITAL TREATMENT FOR MINOR INJURIES. MV 'UBC SACRAMENTO' ATTENDED THE SCENE. BLAZE STARTED AFTER SHORT CIRCUIT IN ENGINE ROOM. VESSEL COMPLETELY BURNT OUT. A LARGE NUMBER OF SMALL CARGO ITEMS SPILLED INTO THE SEA. WRECK SUBSEQUENTLY DRIFTED ASHORE NEAR PUERTO COLOMBIA.

On the 8th of March 2013, passenger ship "Norwegian Jade", which was on a cruise, reached the port of Katakolo, from Civitavecchia at about 08:00. 
The ship was in the mooring process and the crew had given out all the mooring lines. Due mostly to the swell in the port area, the vessel was about 1m ahead of the proper position for the passenger gangway to be connected to the dock, so she had to be moved aftwards. The engines were already stopped, so the move was to be carried out by heaving one of the two bow spring lines (the second one had been connected to the bind but not heaved) and slacking the stern lines. 
After the ship moved in this way aftwards and was in the right position, the stern lines were also heaved and preparations began so the second bow spring line would be heaved too. The whole procedure was to be carried out by the bow mooring deck crew, which comprised of 6 A/Bs and a second officer. The second officer with an A/B were standing on a convertible mooring platform when the first (tightened) spring line broke, hitting the A/B on the platform and throwing him on the platform's rail and then overboard.
Hellenic Coast Guard members on the dock saw the accident and dived in the sea to help the A/B. However he sank at once and could not be retrieved by the HCGs. The ship moored with another line and about two hours later, divers from the HCG came to the port and found the body of the A/B in the sea bed below the ship. 
Investigation was carried out by HBMCI.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Ship remains fit to proceed

SOLASStatus: LADY GUL: Unknown/unspecified, ST. CATRIEN: Unknown/unspecified
Location: BLACK SEA 23 MILES EAST OF VARNA, BULGARIA
SummaryOfEvents:
THE COMORIAN-FLAGGED GENERAL CARGO SHIP 'ST. CATRIEN' IN COLLISION WITH MV 'LADY GUL' IN THE BLACK SEA 23 MILES EAST OF VARNA, BULGARIA IN LAT. 43 14N., LONG. 028 23E., AT 1730 HOURS LT ON 07/03/13. SUBSEQUENTLY BROKEN UP AT BOURGAS, BULGARIA ON 21/03/13.

NO INJURIES OR POLLUTION REPORTED. EXTENT OF DAMAGE UNKNOWN. PROCEEDED TO VARNA FOR INSPECTION. SUBSEQUENTLY ARRIVED AT BOURGAS, BULGARIA ON 21/03/13 FOR BREAKING UP.

Location: 2 MILES OFF THE DANUBE DELTA NEAR SULINA, ROMANIA
SummaryOfEvents:
THE MOLDOVAN-FLAGGED GENERAL CARGO SHIP 'MIKOLAY BAUMAN' SANK AFTER DEVELOPING WATER INGRESS 2 MILES OFF THE DANUBE DELTA NEAR SULINA, ROMANIA IN LAT. 45 12N., LONG. 29 48E., AT 1000 HOURS LT ON 06/03/13.

DEVELOPED WATER INGRESS TO FORWARD BALLAST TANKS WHILST ON VOYAGE AT 0140 HOURS LT ON 06/03/13. ALL 11 CREW ABANDONED SHIP TO LIFEBOAT AND SUBSEQUENTLY RESCUED BY UKRAINIAN SAR VESSEL 'UST-DANUBE' AND TAKEN ASHORE TO VYLKOVE, UKRAINE. NO INJURIES REPORTED. 5 SQUARE KILOMETRE OIL SLICK REPORTED IN SEA.

The ship suffered explosion and fire in the forecastle area, whilst enroute from Lavera to Amsterdam. The fire was extinguished some time after, however one person(bosun) was reported missing. A SAR operation was launched by the Portuguese Coastguard however his body was never found.

THE PASSENGER RO/RO SHIP 'SPIRIT OF FIJI ISLANDS' STRANDED ON A REEF AT MUANIVANUA POINT, KORO ISLAND, FIJI IN LAT. 17 24S., LONG. 179 22E., AT 0300 HOURS LT ON 06/03/13. REFLOATED AND SUBSEQUENTLY INVOLVED IN ANOTHER INCIDENT WHEN ON VOYAGE TO CHINA FOR BREAKING UP.

THE NATIONAL POLICE DIVISIONAL COMMAND ATTENDED THE SCENE. VESSEL REFLOATED ON THE AFTERNOON HIGH TIDE AND ANCHORED FOR DIVERS INSPECTION. SUSTAINED DAMAGE TO HULL. NO INJURIES OR POLLUTION REPORTED. ALL PASSENGERS DISEMBARKED AND TRANSPORTED ONWARDS TO SUVA, FIJI BY MV 'WESTERLAND' LATER THE SAME DAY. VESSEL DEPARTED KOVO BOUND SUVA AM ON 08/03/13 FOR FURTHER INSPECTION.

On 6 March 2013, the vessel ANDINO was approaching berth “Muelle Juan Carlos I Norte” in Algeciras, Spain with a pilot on board and with the assistance of two tugs. At 00:51(LT), the master ordered the pilot actions from the tugs. A conversation between the tugs and the pilot were held in Spanish, and the master could not understand. As a result, the ship collided with the pier. The result was damage to ANDINO’s bulbous bow and the pier.

After fishing operations, when the crew was putting the fishing gear on standby position (in order to be fit for the next day), an AB got his foot trapped in a warp. His tibia was broken. The ship went back to the port of Granville. The AB was taken by the shore medical service and evacuated to the Granville hospital. He was out for 3 months.

Manila, Mar 5 -- Bulk carrier Tai An (16582 gt, built 1985), Singapore to Tagbilaran port, with a cargo of 5,900 tons of limestone, sustained an engine breakdown while sailing south-west of the Sulu Sea in lat 07 07N, long 118 19E, yesterday. Reports from the distressed vessel indicate that it was in danger of running aground as it was being hammered by large waves and strong winds which was dragging it towards the shallows. The Philippine Coast Guard has dispatched the search and rescue vessel, Pampanga to render assistance. A salvage tug has also been sent by the ship’s agent to tow the vessel to safety.

Vessel SL NIDA, hereafter called SMIT NIDA, vessel name at the time of the incident, lost control of her starboard bow thruster and made serious contact with CSL ATLAS the vessel she (tugboat) was supporting during an unmooring operation at the port of Buchanan, Liberia. This event resulted in damages to SMIT NIDA’s structure and flooding of her engine room. There were no incidents of environmental pollution or serious injuries to persons onboard.

Aproximadamente a las 01:30 horas del día 5 marzo 2013, se para la descarga para proceder al relevo de los estibadores y proceden a hacerse cargo de la maniobra los estibadores Guillermo Guerra Zender y Juan Carlos Reyes Flores, estando previsto descargar 1 contenedor de 40 pies y 8 contenedores de 20 pies.

Al relevar el turno, el operador de la grúa Sr. Jorge Echevarría Juárez maniobra con el spreader y lo coloca sobre la cubierta de la bodega, instantes después los estibadores proceden a rotar los puestos dentro de la bodega, en ese momento el Sr Guillermo Guerra y el operador de la grúa se percatan de la ausencia del Sr. Juan Carlos Reyes Flores.

Simultáneamente, el 2do Oficial del buque Sr. Dejan Ivanovic, quien se encontraba de guardia aprecia desde la brazola de la bodega cómo cae el Sr Reyes del pontón al fondo de bodega desde una altura de aproximadamente 7.2 metros.

El estibador Juan Carlos Reyes Flores queda gravemente herido, es auxiliado inmediatamente y llevado a un hospital de la localidad para las atenciones médicas correspondientes.

Días después el estibador Juan Carlos Reyes Flores, fallece a consecuencia de los diversos traumatismos sufridos.

Location: LANDING WHARF, CAPE TOWN, SOUTH AFRICA
SummaryOfEvents:
THE FISHING VESSEL 'HWA TSAN NO. 202' CAUGHT FIRE WHILST MOORED AT LANDING WHARF, CAPE TOWN, SOUTH AFRICA PM ON 05/03/13.

BLAZE EXTINGUISED BY LOCAL FIRE SERVICES AFTER 4 HOURS. 25 CREW RESCUED. THE BODY OF THE 26TH CREW MEMBER LATER RECOVERED FROM THE BURNT OUT VESSEL WHICH SUSTAINED VERY SEVERE DAMAGE. REPORTED FIRE WAS INTENTIONALLY STARTED BY ONE OF THE CREW AFTER A DISPUTE ON BOARD.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

Location: FLOATING DOCK 'MOSSDOK 2000' AT THE SPI SHIPYARD, PUERTO PLATA, ARGENTINA
SummaryOfEvents:
THE ARGENTINE-FLAGGED STERN TRAWLER 'MARA II' CAUGHT FIRE AFTER EXPLOSION IN HOLD WHILST UNDERGOING REPAIRS IN FLOATING DOCK 'MOSSDOK 2000' AT THE SPI SHIPYARD, PUERTO PLATA, ARGENTINA AT 1345 HOURS LT ON 04/02/13. REPORTED DAMAGED BEYOND ECONOMICAL REPAIR.

2 WORKERS ON BOARD EVACUATED SAFELY AND TREATED FOR MILD SMOKE INHALATION. BLAZE EXTINGUSIHED BY LOCAL FIRE SERVICES AND FIRE FIGHTING TUGS. ANTI POLLUTION MEASURES DEPLOYED AS A PRECAUTION. SUSTAINED VERY SEVERE DAMAGE.

At the moment she was hoisting the port dredge for its third line in the legal fishing duration of 45 minutes, the ship listed suddenly reducing greatly its speed and sank. Seamen were quickly rescued. After refloating and checks by expert, the ship was recognized as a total loss.
Consequences1: Ship rendered unfit to proceed,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents: On March 3rd of 2013, the High Speed Craft BENCHIJIGUA EXPRESS was in working condition, ready to attend several routes with passengers and cargo among ports of Canary Islands for her Company FRED OLSEN, S.A. That morning, at 7 o'clock, the vessel commenced a voyage between SAN SEBASTIAN (GOMERA) and LOS CRISTIANOS (Tenerife). Hereafter, Company had scheduled more voyages among previous ports and some others like LA ESTACA (HIERRO) and SANTA CRUZ (LA PALMA). The vessel was completing the scheduled voyages without any setback despite the fact that weather and sea conditions were worsening as day drew on. Weather forecasts had anticipated such conditions, and local Government authorities had even declared special warnings for heavy weather conditions, based in the National Agency of Meteorology (AEMET) reports. On 14:28 h, after finishing cargo operations the HSC BENCHIJIGUA EXPRESS departed from LOS CRISTIANOS (TENERIFE) bound to SANTA CRUZ (LA PALMA), with a layover in SAN SEBASTIAN (GOMERA). The craft was carrying 511 passengers, 61 vehicles and 101 mT of cargo for SAN SEBASTIAN, and 157 passengers, 43 vehicles and 103 mT of cargo for SANTACRUZ. According log-book records, the craft arrived to SAN SEBASTIAN at 15:19 h. Here additional 20 passengers, 7 vehicles and 8 mT of cargo were embarked. Vessel departed at 15:40 h. Later on, at 15:55 h the vessel slowed her speed due to adverse sea conditions. At 17:30 h the craft stopped 7 miles off SANTA CRUZ , awaiting instructins, due to adverse conditions inside the port. 15' later, the Master was advised by the Pilot of SANTA CRUZ (LA PALMA) that the port was closed. Then, the Company instructed the vessel to proceed to SAN SEBASTIAN (GOMERA). At 20:03 h, vessel slowed down her engines to approach the port. Nevertheless, the vessel could not initiate any manoeuver until 20:35 h as visibility was poor. At 20:45 h the craft could make fast to the pier but the ramps could not be opened due to the rough water breaking against the it. So, the craft did not get to operate in this port. At 21:05 h the craft departed from this port and, following instructions fron the Company, went to SANTA CRUZ DE TENERIFE, reaching this por next day (March 4th) at 00:24h. During related journeys, and specially since the craft departed from SAN SEBASTIAN (GOMERA) at 15:40 h up to her berthing in SANTA CRUZ DE TENERIFE next day at 00:24 h (8 hours and 44 minutes) the vessel supported the pounding and battering of waves as well as heavy rolling and pitching movements that even forced crew to slow down engines and/or alter her course in order to avoid or diminish posible damages. Several passengers considered that they were put into a risk/danger position and have expressed their uneasiness with claims and sues against all parts concerned. CIAIM has received a formal claim and has decided to complete a full investigation on that. Current report exclusively keeps within safety issues regarding the voyages made by the HSC BENCHIJIGUA EXPRESS such day, and it do not evaluate any lack of comfort suffered by the passengers during those near 9 hours because of heavy weather. CONCLUSIONS OF INVESTIGATION 1) The ship EXPRESS BENCHIJIGUA was not subject to unacceptable risks for sailings that made the day March 3, 2013. 2) The ship's crew BENCHIJIGUA EXPRESS took appropriate from the point of view of safety of navigation decisions. 3) Difficulties encountered the ship from leaving the port of San Sebastin de La Gomera were because: a. Limitations to operate the port of Santa Cruz de La Palma found to be lower than the limitations of the ship to sail as a result the ship was found in nearby weather its boundary conditions without access to port. b. The closure of the port of Santa Cruz de La Palma was not foresaw in good time so that the master Benchijigua Express could suspend service. RECOMMENDATIONS To the Port authorities of Canary Islands 1) To adopt procedures documented in coordination with the Directorate General of Security and Emergency of Canarias on closing ports of their competence in general and inter-island passenger traffic in particular when the unfavorable weather forecasts along with the accumulated experience of the impact of these predictions in each port parties advise total or partial closure of the port. These procedures should take into account the type of vessels in these trades, their schedules and their operational limitations. The procedures should provide for the closure in good time so that they can inform shippers that these vessels do not depart to sea without a clear anticipation to such closure of their destination ports. To the shipping company 2) Improve matters relating to the information transmitted to the passage when bad weather is expected during the passage. 3) Include in the process of trip cancellation of Companys Safety Management System, as a main reference, the approved Exploitation Permit for Ship. It would also include a convenient tool aid to decision making.
The passage plan routed the ship over the Varne Bank when the ship grounded on a rising tide.  Ship re-floated without external assistance approximately 1 hour later

At 1049[1] <#_ftn1> on 2 March 2013, the westbound container ship HERM KIEPE, which was sailing under the flag of Antigua & Barbuda, and the eastbound container ship EMPIRE, which was sailing under the flag of the Netherlands, collided in dense fog in the Kiel Canal's inland port of Brunsbüttel. The HERM KIEPE waited in the siding to enter the Große Nordschleuse (large north lock). The eastbound CREMONA and behind her the EMPIRE were located in the Große Nordschleuse. The KLENODEN, also eastbound, was located in the Kleine Nordschleuse (small north lock). The CREMONA left the locks first, then the KLENODEN, and finally the EMPIRE. The CREMONA passed the HERM KIEPE at an estimated distance of 30 m, while the KLENODEN proceeded further to the south. It is likely that hydrodynamic interaction occurred between the ships during both encounters. The HERM KIEPE made turning movements towards the middle of the canal. The EMPIRE, which was following, proceeded from the guiding racks to the siding's berth about 500 m away just north of the middle of the fairway. In the process, her port side collided with the bow of the HERM KIEPE and she lost four containers. One container landed on the forecastle of the HERM KIEPE. A pilot and two canal helmsmen manned each ship. There were no injuries and no pollutants escaped during the accident. The canal was closed and floating/submerged containers were located and secured.

[1] <#_ftnref1> Unless stated otherwise all times shown in this report are local 
= Central European Time = UTC + 1

On Saturday, 02 March 2013, at approximately 07:30am AGIOS DIONISIOS sailed from Kitros fishing shelter heading to the mussel cultivation plant. On board the barge were the skipper and another three persons. Two of them were workers of the mussel plant. After a 30 minute voyage AGIOS DIONISIOS arrived at the mussel plant area and begun heaving the mussels for cleaning and replacing the protective net. At approximately 11:00am AGIOS DIONISIOS suddenly begun to list on her port and aft side. In response to the dangerous situation, skipper and the workers attempted to shift the mussel cargo which was on deck to the fore and starboard side but their effort was unfruitful. The list kept increasing until AGIOS DIONISIOS capsized and sunk. Skipper and the three persons fell overboard and managed to hang on to the mussel plants buoys until they were recovered by a fishing boat sailing near the area. AGIOS DIONISIOS was refloated the following day and after necessary repairs continued to be operational. Safety issues and contributing factors identified by HBMCIs safety investigation are summarized below: 1. Openings at the aft part of the deck and flat part of the stern, allowed sea water to enter and accumulate inside the engine room space. 2. Water accumulation was not observed by the skipper. 3. Skipper lacked the knowledge of the barges permitted weight of cargo. 4. Barges buoyant device and lifebuoy rings were secured in a way that prevented them to float freely after sinking of the barge. 5. Openings to the deck which comprised barges watertightness were not observed during periodic surveys.
ShipType1: Other Dry Cargo (livestock, barge, heavy cargo, etc.) Carrier

Location: SEA OF JAPAN OFF IWASKAI, AOMORI, JAPAN
SummaryOfEvents:
THE CHINESE-FLAGGED GENERAL CARGO SHIP 'AN FENG 8' STRANDED AFTER DRAGGING ANCHOR IN THE SEA OF JAPAN OFF IWASKAI, AOMORI, JAPAN IN LAT. 40 34N., LONG. 139 55E., AT 2300 HOURS LT ON 01/03/13 IN HEAVY WEATHER. THE ABANDONED WRECK SUBSEQUENTLY BROKE IN TWO ON 26/11/13.

ALL 12 CREW RESCUED BY LOCAL EMERGENCY SERVICES. NO INJURIES REPORTED. SUSTAINED DAMAGE TO HULL. UNKNOWN QUANTITY OF OIL SPILLED INTO SEA. SOME OIL OBSERVED ON LOCAL BEACHES. ANTI POLLUTION MEASURES DEPLOYED. REMAINING BUNKER FUEL REMOVED BY SALVORS. FURTHER SALVAGE OPERATIONS DELAYED BY OWNERS AND ABANDONED WRECK BROKE IN TWO ON 26/11/13 IN HEAVY WEATHER.

THE IRANIAN-FLAGGED GENERAL CARGO SHIP 'MANI' FOUNDERED IN THE PERSIAN GULF 30 MILES SOUTH OF BUSHEHR, IRAN IN LAT. 28 27N., LONG. 050 51E., AM ON 01/03/13.

NO INJURIES OR POLLUTION REPORTED.

A fire happened in the engine room of fising boat BAHA DE CARBONERAS that cause whole destruction of the boat. The four crew members were recued and managed abandon the boat by other fishing boat there was around it and leaded to Carboneras dock.

At about 16:30 hrs (LT) on the 26 February 2013, there was a contact between NOBLE DUCHESS a Liberian flagged rig and ALBATROSS 07 (ex-CAPTAIN FM JUVALE). After cargo operations, the supply ship started maneuvering away from the drilling rig but initiated the turning action too soon and eventually made contact with the drilling rig. NOBLE DUCHESS sustained damages to the life boat and her Yokohama fender tore off. There were no loos of life nor damage to the environment.

Location: Indian Ocean NW of Western Australia
SummaryOfEvents: Cargo moved in heavy weather leading to the ship developing a 35° port list.  Australian RCC contacted for help.  RCC tasked an aircraft and ships in the area to provide assistance. The ship adjusted ballast to reduce the list to about 15° and altered course to move away from the weather.  An offshore support vessel arrived and stood by to offer whatever assistance was needed.  The ship's owners engaged towing and salvage company assistance.
Cargo1: General cargo - casing for oil well development

SummaryOfEvents: A general cargo ship grounded on a marked shallow bank in the North Sea. The vessel refloated about 1 hour later but had lost her rudder and therefore was anchored. The vessel required tug assistance to reach a port of repair. The watchkeeper was alone on the bridge and it was dark. The vessel was in autopilot at a speed of 6.5kts. The primary means of navigation in use was a GPS receiver with the track to the next waypoint input onto the radar. The ship's position was not plotted on the paper charts available. The watchkeeper selected the wrong waypoint and followed the track displayed until the vessel grounded. It is possible the watchkeeper also fell asleep during his watch. A watch alarm was fitted but was not in use.

On 26 th February, about 06:00 pm, the fishing vessel J KALAMENDIs boatswain had an operational accident and he died when received a hard blow onhis head with the fiching gear, while he was taking part in the manoeuvre for lower the fishing arts.

Loss of life of the cook of M/T "EVIAPETROL I", after falling overboard passenger launch  "VAGGELIO", in Elefsis Gulf, on the 25th of February 2013. The Cook embarked the launch from her bow and after receiving two suit cases from the M/T, he tried to move towards her stern. However he lost his balance and fell in the water. Cook's death was due to heart problem, according to postmortem examination report.

ShipsInvolved: Seinan Maru No.7 (-), Seinan Maru No.8 (-), WAN HAI 162 (IMO 9132909)

SummaryOfEvents:
Container ship WAN HAI 162 was in collision with fishing vessel Seinan Maru No.7 and fishing vessel Seinan Maru No.8, and both fishing vessels capsized. 
　Consequently, a crew of Seinan Maru No.7 was missing and a crew of Seinan Maru No.8 was dead.

Location: YELLOW SEA 20 MILES OFF CHAOLIAN DAO, QINGDAO, CHINA
SummaryOfEvents:
THE PANAMANIAN-FLAGGED GENERAL CARGO SHIP 'HUA SHAN' CAUGHT FIRE IN ENGINE ROOM IN THE YELLOW SEA 20 MILES OFF CHAOLIAN DAO, QINGDAO, CHINA IN LAT. 36 00N., LONG. 121 13E., AT 1910 HOURS LT ON 24/02/13 IN GOOD VISIBILITY. SUBSEQUENTLY REPAIRED AND RETURNED TO SERVICE.

15 CREW MEMBERS ABANDONED SHIP TO LIFEBOAT AND WERE RESCUED BY PASSING VESSEL MV 'TAIYO 6'. LOCAL CHINESE AUTHORITIES DESPATCHED SAR VESSELS 'HAI XUN 11', 'BEI HAI JIU 115' AND PILOT TUG 'GUI BIN' TO THE SCENE. BLAZE WAS EXTINGUISHED ON 25/02/13. BEI HAI JIU 115' EFFECTED TOW TO AN ANCHORAGE IN QINGDAO, CHINA FOR INSPECTIONS ON 26/02/13. AND LATER TO SHIDAO FOR REPAIRS. 1 CREW MEMBER WAS FOUND DEAD. NO POLLUTION REPORTTED.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Ship remains fit to proceed

Location: Yellow Sea area, near Qingdao, China
SummaryOfEvents: A press report, dated today, states: General cargo with container capacity Hua Shan (3843 gt, built 1985) with 4,000 tonnes of Coal and 16 crew members on-board, experienced a fire in the engine room, about 18 miles off Chaolian Island at 1957 hrs, today. The Quingdao Maritime Rescue Center reported that 15 crew members were rescued by a passing vessel at 2243 hrs, while one was still stranded on the vessel. All the crew members are from the Democratic People’s Republic of Korea, and none of those rescued were injured.

THE MALAYSIAN-FLAGGED PASSENGER RO/RO SHIP 'FAJAR SAMUDERA' CAPSIZED AND SANK IN THE ANCHORAGE AT PORT KLANG, MALAYSIA AT 0730 HOURS LT ON 23/02/13.

NO INJURIES REPORTED. LIGHT OIL SHEEN OBSERVED IN WATER. WRECK LYING ON PORT SIDE IN 12 METRES OF WATER AND IS PARTIALLY VISIBLE AT LOW TIDE. VESSEL HAD BEEN LAID UP UNMANNED SINCE 2009 WITH MECHANICAL PROBLEMS. MARINE DEPARTMENT PATROL BOATS ATTENDED THE SCENE AND DEPLOYED WARNING BUOYS TO MARK THE SITE.

1 dead, 14 missing as ship sinks off Pangasinan
At least one person was reported dead while seven were injured after a ship sank off Pangasinan province, the Philippine Coast Guard Feb. 16, 2013. Coast Guard spokesman Lt. Cmdr. x said at least 14 were reported missing and are now the subjects of a search operation, radio dzBB's Glen Juego reported. Balilo was quoted in the report as saying they received the report of the Myanmar ship "Harita Bauxite" sinking off Bolinao town in Pangasinan at about 9 a.m. He said their initial reports indicated the ship encountered engine trouble, and was battered by big waves until it started to sink. Some of the ship's crewmembers were reported injured, the Coast Guard added.

At about 15:00 hrs on 21 February 2013, the fishing ship Achieve foundered 6nm north-west of the Island of Taransay. Although all three of the ship's .crew were rescued, one of them died later in hospital due to hypothermia.

Location: SEA OF JAPAN 340 MILES NORTHEAST OF ULLUNG ISLAND, REPUBLIC OF KOREA
SummaryOfEvents:
THE CAMBODIAN-FLAGGED FISHING CARRIER 'DONG HAI NO. 1' LOST HATCH COVER, TOOK WATER AND SANK IN THE SEA OF JAPAN 340 MILES NORTHEAST OF ULLUNG ISLAND, REPUBLIC OF KOREA AT 0704 HOURS LT ON 21/02/13 IN HEAVY WEATHER.

2 JAPANESE COASTGUARD PATROL VESSELS AND 2 HELICOPTERS EFFECTED SAR OPERATIONS. 12 CREW RESCUED AND TAKEN TO HOSPITAL IN NIIGATA, JAPAN. 3 CREW SUBSEQUENTLY DIED.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents: The skipper was fishing near the cliffs when a long-line was tangled on the propeller. The boat crashed. The only crew member swam to the shore. No safety recommendations has been given.
Consequences1: Ship rendered unfit to proceed,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents: On 20-02-2013 at 2105 hrs. at Richards Bay (28 °50.8’S, 32 °12.1’E), when the crewmembers of the Hong Kong, China Registered M.V. “Ocean Amber” were picking up the port anchor, the hydraulic motor of the windlass ruptured. A piece of flying debris hit an AB on his neck. The AB was seriously injured and the ship contracted the Port Control for emergency helicopter evacuation. A helicopter with paramedics arrived the ship and the paramedics declared the AB dead.

At 15:30 on 20 February 2013, M/V JSM while berthed starboard side alongside at the dock of Kiato Port departing procedures were commenced. The weather conditions were good and the procedure would be assisted by T/B ARTEMIS V which received a towing line from the aft port quarter of JSM. No Port pilot was available and as a result the whole procedure was planned exclusively by the Master of the ship. JSM cast off her starboard bow from the pier handling her aft spring line and according to the plan stern would be cleared by the towing (pulling) of the T/B. However, according to the master of JSM, tug's maneuver was carried out with engine power applied more than expected and as a result the distance between JSM4s stern and the dock became greater than the distance between her bow and the dock rendering ship's heading towards port exit hazardous and posing a risk of grounding or impacting on the breakwater of the fishing shelter inside Kiato Port. The maneuvering of JSM in order to avoid the dangerous situation and since ARTEMIS V did not release the towline, resulted in the progressive heeling over of the tug to starboard and in rapid foundering. JSM continued her maneuver and exited the port entrance after receiving her towline which was released from the hook of ARTEMIS V due to buoyancy. Two crew members of the Tug out of three abandoned her (Engineer and deck rating) while she was heeling over to starboard and were rescued. Following the foundering the Skipper was emerged on sea surface but lost his consciousness and shortly after it was determined he had died. According to the postmortem examination conducted on 05 April 2013 by the Forensic Service of Patras it was determined that the cause of his death was due to drowning by seawater.

The M/T CHANTACO was approaching Le Havre road when the F/V L'ECLIPSE, arrived to the east limit of her fishing area, made a U-turn to take a new track. Despite a last minute change of her course, the CHANTACO collided gently with the stern gantry of L'ECLIPSE.
After an assessment of the damages, it has been possible for both vessels to resume their routes.

Location: CANAKKALE STRAIT 5 MILES SOUTHWEST OF KIZILCATERZI, TURKEY
SummaryOfEvents:
THE TURKISH-FLAGGED GENERAL CAROG SHIP 'BOCA' CAUGHT FIRE IN THE CANAKKALE STRAIT 5 MILES SOUTHWEST OF KIZILCATERZI, TURKEY IN LAT. 40 32N., LONG. 026 57E., AT 0825 HOURS ON 17/02/13. DAMAGED BEYOND ECONOMICAL REPAIR AND ARRIVED AT ALIAGA, TURKEY ON 10/04/13 FOR BREAKING UP.

ALL 14 CREW RESCUED BY RESCUE BOAT 'KEGM-6'. NO INJURIES REPORTED. TUGS 'KURTARMA 9' AND 'SONDUREN 7' ASSISTED WITH FIRE FIGHTING OPERATIONS. SUSTAINED DAMAGE TO ENGINE ROOM, ACCOMMODATION AND BRIDGE.
Liberian flagged vessel SIS SERVICE came in contact with Malta flagged AMAPOLA at the end of STS operations. Minor damages reported on AMAPOLA's starboard side.

On 16 February 2013, the Maltese registered general cargo vessel Hopa was berthing at the Port of Caronte, France when one of the forward mooring team crew members was severely injured in both legs and his left arm after the starboard headline jumped off the bitts whilst under strain.  At the time of the accident, the injured crew member was trying to fix a ‘stopper line’ arrangement, in order to shift and fasten the headline in way of the vessel’s double bitts. 

Soon after the accident, the injured crew member was given initial medical treatment on board although the first diagnosis of his injuries was made by a first aid shore team.  The diagnosis confirmed that the crew member had sustained serious fractures to both his legs and his left arm and had to be disembarked and treated in a hospital ashore. 

The safety investigation identified a number of issues related to the mooring operation, including the experience and training of the injured crew member, supervision, and the implementation of the safety management system vis-à-vis the dissemination of safety lessons on board.

At 05:56 hrs, on 16 February 2013, the port fin stabiliser of the passenger / ro-ro cargo ferry Finnarrow made contact with the berth as she arrived at Holyhead, UK.
The fin stabiliser subsequently punctured the hull, which led to the pump room flooding. All passengers were disembarked, cargo was unloaded and the vessel's onboard services crew were sent ashore. Once divers had plugged the hole in the hull and the shore fire service had employed a high-volume pump, the water level in the pump room was reduced to below the floor plates and a cement box was constructed to seal the leak.

Location: MARSHALL REEF 19 MILES NORTHWEST OF LUDERITZ, NAMIBIA
SummaryOfEvents:
THE BRAZILIAN-FLAGGED BULK CARRIER 'FROTAMERICA' STRANDED ON A SANDBAR NEAR MARSHALL REEF 19 MILES NORTHWEST OF LUDERITZ, NAMIBIA IN LAT. 26 22S., LONG. 015 02E., ON 15/02/13 IN HEAVY WEATHER. WRECK ABANDONED IN SITU.

NO INJURIES OR POLLUTION REPORTED. INITIAL REFLOATING ATTEMPTS ABANDONED DUE TO ADVERSE WEATHER CONDITIONS. SHIP WAS UNMANNED AT THE TIME OF THE INCIDENT AND WAS AWAITING CONTINUATION OF A TOW FROM BRAZIL TO ALANG, INDIA FOR DEMOLITION. SUBSEQUENTLY ABANDONED BY OWNERS. 139 TONS OF BUNKER OIL REMOVED BY SALVORS.

WHILE THE VESSEL WAS DISCHARGING CARGO, THE CHIEF ENGINEER WHO WAS OBSERVING THE OPERATION ON DECK WAS STUCK BETWEEN THE PORTABLE CRANE'S BODY AND THE HATCH COAMING. THE PORTABLE CRANE WAS DOING THE DISCHARGE OPERATION AND IT WAS REVOLVING CONTINUOUSLY BETWEEN THE HOLD AND THE BERTH DURING THE OPERATION. THE CHIEF ENGINEER WAS SEVERELY INJURED AND LOST HIS LIFE AS A CONSEQUENCE.

Whilst heaving up the fishing gear, on board the Madison, an AB trapped his left hand between a cable and a winch. After a communication between MRCC, medical center and the ship he was evacuated by helicopter. Consequences: he lost two phalanges (cut by the cable). Four days in the hospital and seven home at home.

Location: MEDITERRANEAN SEA 20 NAUTICAL MILES WEST OF ORAN, ALGERIA
SummaryOfEvents:
THE HONDURAN-FLAGGED GENERAL CARGO SHIP 'AG. EKATERINI' REPORTED TO HAVE FOUNDERED IN THE MEDITERRANEAN SEA 20 NAUTICAL MILES WEST OF ORAN, ALGERIA ON 14/02/13.

NO INJURIES OR POLLUTION REPORTED.

Fire broke out on board the vessel MV Coastal Leopard, while the vessel lay secured, alongside another laid up vessel. The smoke was initially sighted coming out from the main deck store of the vessel. The ship's staff fought the fire with on-board fire fighting equipment. Subsequently, the fire spread to other parts of the vessel also. The port fire tenders were called and fire was eventually extinguished.
There was no loss of life and no damage to environment.
Bosun was reported to fall overboard while recovering pilot ladder.  He was not wearing a lifejacket at the time.

During its fishing operations, the French trawler Delta Doc (trawl in the water) suffered a fire in the engine due to a failure in the lubrification system of the turbocharger. The master succeeded alone in extinguishing the fire with a powder extinguisher. The engine started back shortly and stopped again because of lube oil low pressure. The trawler was towed to the harbour "Port Saint Louis du Rhone"

THE MALTESE-FLAGGED RO-RO CARGO SHIP 'SETUBAL EXPRESS' CAUGHT FIRE IN ENGINE ROOM WHILST MOORED IN THE ANCHORAGE 8 MILES EAST OF HOMS, LIBYA IN LAT. 32 40N., LONG. 014 23E., AM ON 07/02/13. SUBSEQUENTLY BROKEN UP AT ALIAGA, TURKEY ON 01/06/13.

TUG 'TAGHREFT' AND 4 OTHER TUGS ASSISTED WITH FIRE FIGHTING OPERATIONS. BLAZE EXTINGUISHED BY 1255 HOURS LT THE SAME DAY. NO INJURIES REPORTED. EXTENT OF DAMAGE UNKNOWN. INSPECTION EFFECTED. SUBSEQUENTLY TOWED TO VALLETTA, MALTA BY TUG 'ST ELMO' AND ENTERED PALUMBO SHIPYARD ON 21/02/13.

Location: Santa Cruz port, on the Canary Island of La Palma
SummaryOfEvents: A lifeboat from the Maltese passenger ship Thomson Magesty fell upside down into the sea at the pier of Santa Cruz in La Palma, Canary Islands, during a safety drill, killing five crew members and injuring three others.  The accident occurred around 12:00 (GMT) on Sunday, 10 February 2013.  Around 1,4000 passengers were aboard at the time of the Thomson Majesty ship, but were not in any way involved in the accident.

The RORO-ferry RODIN was moored at the drydock N°6 in Dunkirk, after a maintenance period. The 2 portside lifeboats (n° 6 and n° 8) were proceeding to be lifted on the boat deck. The same operation had been made before with the 2 starboard lifeboats. The operation was supported by the rescue boat and controlled from the bridge by the chief officer. The manning for each lifeboat was two AB seamen and a skipper.
As the aft seaman of the n°6 experienced some difficulties to secure the hook, he took off his lifejacket to exit more easily from the lifeboat, through the aft manhole. Embarrassed by the swinging movement of the fall, he has been unsteady and fall overboard (1.50 m) into the water.
As a consequence of the swinging movement, the aft fall of the n°6 get tangled with the fore fall of the n°8. The skipper of the n°8, who was worried on the man overboard, didn’t see the fall in movement and was hit by it. Despite the fact that he wore safety gloves, he was injured to the right hand.
The man overboard was quickly picked up by the rescue boat. After he had embarked into the rescue boat, he felt coastal pain.
The two men were conducted to the hospital. The man of the n°8 needed surgery on his right hand.

Location: approximately 150 miles off the coast of the Yucatan Peninsula
SummaryOfEvents:
The Bahamas registered vessel ''CARNIVAL TRIUMPH'' experienced an engine room fire while sailing approximately 150 miles off the coast of the Yucatan Peninsula. At the time of the incident, the ship was carrying 3,143 guests and 1,086 cre on board. There are no reported injuries to either crew or passenger nor is there any report of pollution from the vessel.
The fire originated in the vessel’s machinery space and although extinguished by the onboard fire system, the vessel suffered a loss of power and as a consequence completed its voyage to Mobile, Alabama under tow.

Location: PETROPAVLOVSKAJA SHIPYARD AT PETROPAVLOVSK-KAMCHATSKIY, RUSSIAN FEDERATION
SummaryOfEvents:
THE RUSSIAN-FLAGGED FISHING VESSEL 'TUNETS' SANK AT BERTH NO. 2 WHILST LAID UP AT THE PETROPAVLOVSKAJA SHIPYARD AT PETROPAVLOVSK-KAMCHATSKIY, RUSSIAN FEDERATION ON 10/02/13.

NO POLLUTION REPORTED. NO CREW WERE ABOARD AT THE TIME OF THE INCIDENT.
WHICH REPORTED A CREW MEMBER MISSING  ON FEBRUARY 08 AT MIZUSHIMA ANCHORAGE, JAPAN.

On 8 February 2013 the Cayman Island registered private motor yacht Calliope was departing the Sydney Superyacht Marina in Rozelle Bay, Sydney for a voyage to Broken Bay, to the north. At about 1345 hrs (LT = UTC +11 hrs), as the yacht passed through the Glebe Island Bridge its starboard side came close to the eastern stone pylon. Yacht crew had deployed fenders for its departure and attempted to reposition the fenders to protect the yacht's side from contact with the bridge.

During this operation, one of the yacht's deckhands was moving a fender aft coinciding with the contact between the yacht and the bridge. As he moved it aft he was caught by one of the fenders mounted on the bridge pylon. He was trapped between the bridge fender and the yacht's side. As he was dragged overboard and crushed between the bridge fender and the yacht. He was recovered from the water but died of his injuries.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Ship remains fit to proceed

SummaryOfEvents:
TOOK WATER IN HOLD AND SANK AT BERTH WHILST DISCHARGING CARGO AT BATU AMPAR, INDONESIA PM ON 08/02/13. WRECK STILL IN SITU IN JUNE 2013.

NO INJURIES OR POLLUTION REPORTED. ANTI POLLUTION BOOM DEPLOYED AS A PRECAUTION. PATIALLY SUBMERGED ON BOTTOM OF BERTH WITH SUPERSTRUCTURE STILL ABOVE WATER. WRECK STILL PRESENT IN JUNE 2013.
While the ship was berthing at Tsuruga port, the mooring line broke and hit the chief officer, resulting in his death.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Ship remains fit to proceed

SummaryOfEvents: During berthing and maneouvering at Freetown, Sierra Leone, CONTI GUINEA contacted the corner of Koy Jetty and sustained damage to the 4P ballast tank. The crew observed water ingress and immediately pumped it out. No injuies or incidents of pollution were reported.

At about 0955 (UTC+2), a fire broke out in the auxiliary engine compartment of the ro-ro cargo ship Setubal Express.  At the time, the vessel was on anchor, about three nautical miles off the Port of Al-Khums. 

The navigational officer of the watch noticed the activation of the engine-room fire alarm and immediately phoned the engine control room to alert the engineering officer of the watch.  The engineers took immediate action and confirmed that auxiliary engine no. 1 was on fire. 

Due to the intensity of the fire and the dense smoke, attempts to extinguish the fire with two portable fire extinguishers proved futile. 

Consequently, the engine-room had to be abandoned. 

The fire was eventually brought under control and extinguished after the activation of the fixed CO2 installation. 

The safety investigation concluded that the immediate cause of the fire was the spray of gas oil on a hot surface, following the failure of the supply and delivery fuel pipes on auxiliary engine no. 1.

THE MOLDOVAN-FLAGGED GENERAL CARGO SHIP 'KORSTEN' CAUGHT FIRE IN ACCOMMODATION WHILST UNDERGOING REPAIRS ON SLIPWAY AT KHERSON, UKRAINE AT 0200 HOURS LT ON 06/02/13.

6 CREW EVACUATED. 1 CREW MEMBER DEAD. BLAZE BROUGHT UNDER CONTROL BY LOCAL FIRE SERVICES 6 HOURS LATER. SUSTAINED DAMAGE TO 400 SQUARE METRES OF SUPERSTRUCTURE INCLUDING CREW MESS AND CAPTAINS CABIN.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Ship remains fit to proceed

SummaryOfEvents: The fishing boat "COSTERO SEGUNDO" was sealing when crash with an abandoned unidentified object, what produced it a leakage,with the result of a foundering.

SOLASStatus: EVER SHINING: SOLAS, YIN YUAN : Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents:
Please kindly be advised that the captioned vessel Ever Shining (IMO No. 9209312), she was hit by another ship (MV Yin Yuan) while she was discharging her cargo Iron Ore (B/L figure 72600 mt) at No. 4 Berth of HUANG HUA port China at 1640 Hours on 5 Feb 2013. 
 
Consequently, the captioned vessel mv Ever Shining touched with the stern of the other ship (MV Heng Shan Hai) who was berthed ahead.
 
The P&I, Underwriter and NKK Class surveyor were informed immediately via Head Office, and ship's Superintendent also was arranged to attend the subject vessel to assist the ship's Master.
Loss of a crewman

SOLASStatus: SITEAM NEPTUN: SOLAS, YANGTZE BRILLIANCE: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents: On 3 February 2013 at 04:46hrs (LT), while unloading her cargo, the SITEAM NEPTUN was struck by vessel YANGTZE BRILLIANCE. As a result, fuel oil spilled into the water.

Location: Port of Bremerhaven, NTB Terminal Fender 4880
SummaryOfEvents: On February 2, 2013 at approximately 21:05 (LT), Liberian flagged container ship, FLOTTBEK, was involved in an allision with a fender at the Port of Bremerhaven, Germany while attempting to berth. The weather conditions were very windy and the seas were very heavy. While under pilotage, the vessel was approaching the pier too quickly in the pilot's effort to align the vessel with the pier and bring the vessel parallel to the pier. The Main Engine was not responsive to orders given in attempt to slow the vessel down and, as a result of this, the vessel struck the pier. Although the damage to vessel's hull was considerable, there were injuries or incidents of pollution.

On 02 February 2013, at about 1000, the Marine Safety Investigation Unit (MSIU) was notified by the managers of the Maltese registered motor vessel Katre, that on 01 February 2013, at about 2325 (UTC), their vessel, while on a ballast voyage from Helsingborg, Sweden to Stralsund, Germany, was involved in a collision with the Dutch registered motor vessel Statengracht in position 54° 53.7’N  013° 13.2’E.  The position was close to the Northwest entrance of the TSS North of Rugen in the Baltic Sea. 

Preliminary information indicated that the collision occurred when Katre was proceeding on a South-easterly course close to the Northwest entrance of the TSS North of Rugen.  Statengracht was proceeding towards the entrance of the TSS North of Rugen on a Westerly course. 

Statengracht sustained damages to her port side in way of cargo hold no. 2.  As a result of the damage, she developed a port list of about 10°.  Statengracht was instructed to proceed to the port of Rostock, Germany, which was her original destination.  Katre, which sustained damages to her bow area, was instructed to proceed to the port of Mukran, Germany.  No injuries and no pollution were reported from both vessels. 

The safety investigation concluded that in a typical crossing situation and in good visibility, neither vessel followed basic bridge procedures and COLREGs requirements.

Location: Port Said, entrance of the Suez Canal
SummaryOfEvents:
On the evening of 1 February 2013, a severe leakage occurred in the container ship EMMA MÆRSK while the ship, loaded with general cargo in about 14,000 containers, was about to pass southbound through the Suez Canal. 

The leakage was caused by a mechanical break-down of a stern thruster situated at the aft part of the ship’s shaft tunnel whereby the shaft tunnel was flooded. The bulkhead between the shaft tunnel and the main engine room could not withstand the hydrostatic water pressure and eventually the main engine room was also flooded.
 
The situation became complicated because the ship had just initiated a passage in a convoy through the Suez Canal. Loss of the ship’s own propulsion, electric power, steerage and ma-noeuvrability could be foreseen and eventually occurred.

The main technical sequence of events were a break-down of the forward stern thruster causing a major leakage into the shaft tunnel, a collapse of the watertight integrity of the bulkhead between the shaft tunnel and the engine room, primarily caused by non-effective cable penetration sealings and some undesirable properties of the bilge system and the emergency bilge suction from the engine room. Throughout the course of events, all officers and crew members were constantly disturbed and highly stressed by the sound of countless alarms, which made it extremely difficult to concentrate on the many challenges that ap-peared.

Despite a series of technical breakdowns and system weaknesses, the shipboard organization remained resilient, and despite the breakdown of the structural barriers, the ship’s officers and crew managed to contain the emergency situation and bring the ship alongside at the Suez Canal Container Terminal without any personal injury or pollution to the environment.
 
The report contains information about the preventive measures taken by the shipping com-pany, the classification society and other parties involved. The report contains no safety rec-ommendations from the Danish Maritime Accident Investigation Board.

Location: MOZAMBIQUE CHANNEL 3 MILES NORTH OF PONTA ZAVORA, MOZAMBIQUE
SummaryOfEvents:
THE MOZAMBICAN-FLAGGED STERN TRAWLER 'RIO SAINAS' SUSTAINED ENGINE FAILURE AND STRANDED IN THE MOZAMBIQUE CHANNEL 3 MILES NORTH OF PONTA ZAVORA, MOZAMBIQUE IN LAT. 24 28S., LONG. 035 13E., IN FEBRUARY 2013. REFLOATED ON 10/03/13 BUT THEN SUBSEQUENTLY SANK ON 11/03/13.

NO INJURIES OR POLLUTION REPORTED. ALL BUNKERS AND POLLUTANTS REMOVED BY SALVORS SUBTECH. REFLOATED WITH ASSISTANCE FROM TUG 'TERAS HYDRA' ON 10/03/13 BUT SUBSEQUENTLY SANK IN 35 METRES OF WATER AM ON 11/03/13.

During the ebb tide, around 20:20 on January 31st of 2013 was given the warning by the Administration of the port to the Peniche Maritime Police (Local Command of Peniche) for a stranding of the ship called "DENEB" with eight crew on board at the entrance area of the harbour, nearby the western protection pier, on sandy bottom.
With the rising tide, by 3:30 on February 1st of 2013, the ship was able to leave the site by its own means.
There were no apparent injuries or damage to equipment or material.

THE FILIPINO-FLAGGED PASSENGER SHIP 'BALENO 168' SUSTAINED DAMAGE TO STARBOARD PROPELLER SHAFT, TOOK WATER IN ENGINE ROOM AND PARTIALLY CAPSIZED WHILST BERTHING AT CALAPAN, PHILIPPINES AT 0930 HOURS LT ON 31/01/13. WRECK ABANDONED IN SITU.

55 PASSENGERS AND 29 CREW RESCUED BY COASTGUARD. NO INJURIES REPORTED. INITIAL ATTEMPTS TO KEEP VESSEL UPRIGHT FAILED AND SUBSEQUENTLY SETTLED ON STARBOARD SIDE HALF SUBMERGED BY BERTH. 5300 LITRES OF OIL LEAKED INTO WATER. ANTI POLLUTION BOOMS DEPLOYED. PARTIALLY SUBMERGED WRECK STILL PRESENT JUNE 2013.

SOLASStatus: CORAL ACE: Unknown/unspecified, LISA SCHULTE: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents:
Early in the morning of 31 January 2013, two ships laid up at anchor collided in heavy weather in the Neue Weser Nord-roadstead. The Panama-flagged bulk carrier Coral Ace had discharged coal in the port of Nordenham on the previous day and then set her anchor in the roadstead. The Cyprus-flagged container ship Lisa Schulte had already been laid up there at anchor for almost a week in ballast. The Coral Ace anchored at a distance of about 7 cbl to the west of the Lisa Schulte.
In the area of the German Bight, the wind picked up from midday of 30 January 2013 and was generally strong to gale force from the south-west. The gusts increased slightly in the evening and the wing veered towards the west. At 18:00 hrs, the navigational warnings included a gale warning for the German Bight predicting 8 to 9 Bft.
After midnight, the Coral Ace started to drift towards the Lisa Schulte. Gusts of between 41 and 54 kts, equivalent to 9 ot 10 Bfts, were registered in the area of the roadstead. Significant wave height stood at 4 to 5 m with single waves possibly reaching g 7 m. Visibility was between 5 and 10 km.
The officer on watch on the Lisa Schulte called his counterpart on the Coral Ace on VHF when he noticed that her anchor was not holding her in position any more. The OOW on the Coral Ace promised to arrange for the engine to be started. As opposed to that of the Lisa Schulte, the Coral Ace’s engine was not on standby. The distance between the two ships had already dropped to 3 cbl. The Coral Ace was parallel to the sea, about 90° to the wind, and rolling heavily. The collision occurred shortly afterwards.
Nobody came to physical harm. Water ingress occurred on both ships. Buoyancy was not adversely affected by this and there was no water pollution. The water pollution control ship Mellum was ordered to proceed to the casualty ships. It was not possible to take action at the scene because of the weather. As events unfolded, the German Central Command for Maritime Emergencies assumed overall control of the operation.
Escorted by the Mellum, the Coral Ace moved to the Südwestkai in Wilhelmshaven. The Lisa Schulte moved to the Voslapp-roadstead.

Location: East of the Port of Mostyn - Wales
SummaryOfEvents:
On January 2013, Ciudad de Cadiz was on call at Mostyn (Wales) for loading Airbus A380 components. She was moored portside alongside to the Ro-Ro berth.
At the end of the morning she was wind aft – 10 to 15° from the centerline on the port stern. The wind freshened suddenly and strongly while the cargo work was to begin after a short situation assessment by the master, the first officer and the ship’s agent (Dee Marine).
As the stern of the ship was moving increasingly, the master called to manoeuvring stations. Soon after the stern lines gave way, then the fore lines a couple of minutes after the main engines and bow have begun to operate.
Then began a real battle against the elements, wind and tide, to control the drift of the ship and to try to move her upwind. In vain, the ship eventually grounded on the sand and mud shoal located in the north-ease of the turning area.
Taking advantage of a high spring tide ten days later, she has been refloated without any hull damage.

On 28 January 2013, the 6.45m single handed fishing boat JCK failed to return to port, prompting a major search to be mounted by the coastguard. The RNLI recovered the skipper’s body from the sea several hours later. Although some flotsam from JCK was found, the boat was not located and is believed to have foundered in rough seas and winds gusting in excess of 50 knots at around 1750 UTC.

Location: 3 nm South of Saint Ann's Head, Milford Haven, Wales
SummaryOfEvents: At 15:36 UTC on 28 January 2013, a deckhand was washed overboard from the Belgium registered beam trawler Vidar in very rough seas. The deckhand was recovered from the water about 11 minutes later but he could not be revived.

The Danny Rose was experiencing swells of approximately 5m and wind between 40-45 kts. The containers that were lost were on the #2 hatchcover. The lashings were broken and they rolled of the ship while it was rolling and pitching. Two of the containers were empty and one container carried the ships' stores.

On January 28th the ship Cape Baltic arrived to the anchorage areanear the port of Gijon. Being anchored in that area, the anchor started to drag due to the ground swell and strong wind. Eventually the ship was taken to an area of shallow waters where it grounded.

Location: STRAIT OF TARTARY 160 MILES SOUTHWEST OF KHOLMSK, RUSSIAN FEDERATION
SummaryOfEvents:
THE RUSSIAN-FLAGGED FISHING VESSEL 'SHANS 101' TOOK WATER IN FISH PROCESSING HOLD AND CAPSIZED IN THE STRAIT OF TARTARY 160 MILES SOUTHWEST OF KHOLMSK, RUSSIAN FEDERATION IN LAT. 46 22N., LONG. 138 51E., AT 1530 HOURS LT ON 27/01/13 IN HEAVY WEATHER.

10 CREW RESCUED FROM LIFERAFT BY MV 'ANATOLIY TORCHINOV' AND TAKEN TO KHOLMSK. 5 CREW RESCUED FROM ANOTHER LIFERAFT BY FV 'TALAN' AND TRANSFERRED TO MV 'TAMARA' AND TAKEN TO PLASTUN, RUSSIA. 1 OF THE SURVIVORS DIED DURING THE VOYAGE AND ALL THE RESCUED CREW SUFFERED FROM FROSTBITE AND HYPOTHERMIA AND REQUIRED MEDICAL ATTENTION. 8 OTHER CREW DEAD AND 7 MISSING. TUG 'ATLAS', OTHER VESSELS AND 5 AIRCRAFT EFFECTED SAR OPERATION.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents: The ship was doing emergency drills in the life boat when sudently broken down the wire thatcarry the burden of this, falling the life boat down to water and turning out the cheef engineer seriouslyinjured.

Location: On passage between Portocel, Brazil and Baltimore, United States
SummaryOfEvents:
On the afternoon of the 26th January 2013, whilst on passage between Portocel, Brazil and Baltimore, USA, the bosun on board the forest products carrier Mozu Arrow fell some eleven metres to the bottom of the number 4 port ballast tank, sustaining fatal injuries. 

At the time of the accident, the ship's crew were participating in a routine drill and exercise entailing the simulated rescue of a crew member from within an enclosed space. As part of the exercise, the Bosun and Third officer were assigned duties inside No 4 port ballast tank to prepare the simulated casualty, in this case a dummy, for stretcher evacuation. 

Once the drill briefing had been conducted with the Chief Officer, the Bosun and Third officer entered the tank and successfully managed to locate the simulated casualty on the first stringer platform. 

With a number of openings in the deck plating and no guard rails or fall barriers in place to protect the crew members involved, this platform presented a serious risk to the planned operation. 

Whilst attempting to secure the dummy on to the ship's stretcher, the Bosun fell backwards into an opening in the platform plating. 

The investigation found that the tank had been prepared and well ventilated, both naturally and forced, to enable an internal inspection of the space earlier that morning. The atmosphere had also been tested by the Chief Officer using a calibrated test meter both before and during the course of the exercise and was found to be suitable for entry. 

A risk assessment had been completed for the planned entry into the ballast tank which identified that the height of the tank stringer platforms posed a hazard to safety. the use of a safety harness was therefore implemented as the most appropriate control measure to prevent injury. At the time of the accident, during the enclosed space rescue exercise however, neither the Bosun or Third Officer was wearing a safety harness. 

The ordinary practice on board for enclosed space rescue exercises was to conduct them within a juice tank void where working platforms are much larger. A secondary risk assessment had therefore not been completed for the planned emergency drill within this ballast tank space.

SummaryOfEvents:
THE GENERAL CARGO SHIP 'HELENA STAR I' DEVELOPED LIST AND SANK WHILST MOORED AT MASON MARINE SHIPYARD, TACAOMA, WA, USA IN LAT. 47 16N., LONG. 122 21W., AM ON 25/01/13. REFLOATED AND TOWED TO SEATTLE, WA IN JULY 2014 FOR BREAKING UP.

SOLASStatus: CHARLENE HUNT: SOLAS, LYUBOV ORLOVA: SOLAS
Location: 700 nautical mile east of St John's, Newfoundland
SummaryOfEvents: On 24 January 2013 at approximately 1345 Newfoundland and Labrador Standard Time, the United States flagged tug Charlene Hunt lost its tow off Cape Race, Newfoundland and Labrador, when the towing arrangement failed in heavy weather. The lost tow, the decommissioned passenger vessel Lyubov Orlova, drifted in international waters and was presumed sunk. No pollution or injuries were reported.

The fishing boat NOVA ANTONIA, with 2 POB, was getting back to port after picking up near 135 creels. The skipper was fixing their position with a plotter. The night was clear and visibility good. He realised that a lateral sector light (green and yellow) that was fitted on a a shoal called As Carrallas, was shut. But he remained sailing with the information given by the plotter. Unexpectedly they felt a hit. The boat run aground and they could not release the boat starting the motor ahead and astern. The skipper realised that the boat was 50 m closer to shoal than the expected position.The skipper requested assistance by VHF ch. 16 and both crew were rescued by a helicopter.Maritime authorities decided to put salvage operations off till next day with daylight. During the night the vessel sunk close to the aground point. The next days efforts were made to recover the shipwreck, with no result.CONCLUSIONS The skipper based navigation in only one positioning means, the plotter, without apparently concern when he didn't see, where should be, the green light of Punta Castrelius beacon. This should make him suspicious and force him to make sure his position by other means.At no time navigation was contrasted with a second positioning method among those which were available for a traditional coastal shipping, as it had been monitoring bearings and markings to the relevant lights of the coast or the more accessible ble and immediate, the search for the leading line offered by the lights of Punta Arroyo, which would have allowed him to pass safely through the beacon of Punta Castrelius, nevermind if it was switched on or off.The plotter had an error in the position accuracy, that the same skipper quantified in 50 m. This fact, and assuming that the beacon of Punta Castrelius operated normally, suggests that the skipper sailed by one of the shaded light beacon areas, which was the reason that the skipper did not see the light until time of stranding.After examining the available images of the event, it appears that the vessel ran aground in the shadow of the beacon (see Figure 3 on the Report), so that the skipper still did not see its light during emergency until he was rescued.From the above it is concluded that the skipper did not follow good practices required to a navigator, especially when it comes to maintain an effective surveillance using all available means appropriate to the circumstances and conditions of the moment. This action can be identified as a planning error committed by the skipper, driven by overconfidence and low perception of risk associated with his good knowledge of the environment.RECOMMENDATIONSAfter investigation the CIAIM does not formulate any recommendation.

ShipsInvolved: BAI CHAY BRIDGE (IMO 9463346), SEIHOU MARU No.18 (-)
SOLASStatus: BAI CHAY BRIDGE: SOLAS, SEIHOU MARU No.18: Unknown/unspecified
Location: SOUTHEAST OFF KATSUURA CITY, CHIBA JAPAN
SummaryOfEvents: The Japanese fishing vessel SEIHOU-MARU No.18 and the Panamanian container ship BAI CHAY BRIDGE collided with each other at about 10 mile southeast off Katsuura city at around after 23:00, January 23. Due to the collision, the fishing vessel hull sustained listing, but all crew members onboard the fishing vessel were rescued with no injuries. The fishing vessel is not found at this time.

Le 23 Janvier 2013, en début d'après-midi, le ponton Galaad quitte le port du Palais à Belle-ïle, avec en pontée des éléments d'échafaudage, pour se rendre à Saint-Philibert.
Pour rentrer en Baie de Quiberon, il n'a pas l'intention de prendre le Passage de la Teignouse mais un raccourci, la passe dénommée "En Toul Braz". Pour rejoindre ce passage, sa route le fait passer à proximité des hauts fonds de "Goué Vas Quest". La houle d'ouest/nord-ouest est forte, de l'ordre de 2.50 mètres, et la mer brise.
A l'approche des brisants, probablement par crainte, le patron hésite et fait un tour complet, avant de reprendre sa route initiale. Peu après, le Galaad qui reçoit la houle par l'arrière du travers enfourne et est chaviré par une déferlante.
L'alerte est donnée par sa balise de détresse. La coque retournée est rapidement repérée. Le corps d'un des marins est découvert par les plongeurs dans l'épave, l'autre corps  ne sera pas retrouvé.

MV ASPAM SAMRAT, a chemical tanker of DWT abt 6700 mt owned by ASPAM SAMRAT SHIPPING INC. and managed by ARUM SHIPMANAGEMENT FZE based in UAE, sailed from Pasir Gudang, Malaysia on 18th January 2013 with total quantity of cargo RBD Palmolein on board 5011.263 m3 and with RBD Palmolein IV 64, 500.208 m3 and RBD Palmolein IV 60, 501.365 m3. Vessel stayed in Pasir Gudang anchorage area for bunkering until 19/01/2013. At 19 January 2103 bunkering has been completed and at abt 6:30 vessel sailed for Jebel Ali.
On January 22nd, January 2013 on 04:45 hours as per Bridge official log book records vessel encountered Main Engine break down.
At abt 1545 hrs LT (+5,0 GMT), while the ME was under repairs and vessel was drifting at a position Latitude 06 19.4 N / Longitude 092 96.3E (Approximate 165 NM from Great Nicobar), the Chief officer and A/B entered in enclosed space of Ballast Tank Nr.5 (P).
The 3rd Officer was the standby crewmember on Main Deck located at the entry point of the Ballast Tank No 5 (P) communicating via portable VHF with C/O. Few minutes thereafter C/O was not responding to communication from 3rd Officer. 3rd Officer informed the Bridge and as per master instructions general alarm was raised and crew mustered.
Two teams of crewmembers carried out SAR operations. Both C/O and A/B were found lying in unconscious condition near frame No. 69 inside Ballast Tank No.5 (P). A/B was retrieved from Ballast tank No.5 (P) on 22/1/2013 and upon his body was on main deck ship’s crew carried out the CPR. It was reported that there was neither response nor signs of life and A/B declared dead and stored in Cold room.
The body of the C/O could not be retrieved by the crewmembers of the ship and Master notify the company and he was instructed by the company to divert to nearest port of Refugee.

The body of C/O remained inside Ballast Tank No 5 from January, 22, 2013 until the evening of January, 28th, 2013 where the body of C/O was finally taken out of Ballast Tank No 5 (P) by the teams of Indian Navy, who was called to assist, at the Port of refuge “Port Blair”, India.
Entry in the enclosed space of Ballast tank No.5 (P) has been resulted to two fatalities, loss of life, that of C/O and AB. Consequently this is a very serious marine casualty.

ShipsInvolved: Amy Harris III (-), AMY HARRIS III (-)
SOLASStatus: Amy Harris III: Unknown/unspecified, AMY HARRIS III: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents: At 15:00 hrs on 16 Janualry 2013, the skipper of Amy Harris III discovered  a fire in the engine room. The crew’s initial attack on the fire was unsuccessful. Doors and a hatch that were left open allowed smoke to rapidly spread forcing the skipper and his three crewmen onto the deck. No further attempts were made to suppress or control the fire, and the crew were airlifted off the ship by rescue helicopter soon afterwards. The ship was subsequently towed into Campbeltown where the fire was extinguished. Amy Harris III was later declared a constructive total loss.

On January, 16th, 2013, around 13:25 h LT, the fishing trawler “NEPTUNO” who was sailing around 18 mi SW of Figueira da Foz harbour, was received at INEM (CODU-MAR), some information about an occurrence on board. It was said that a crew member had a cranian traumatism, who had communicated with the Maritime Rescue Coordination Centre (MRCC Lisboa) informing him about the occurrence.
The crew member, Portuguese nationality, male, and with 46 years old, didn’t resisted due to the bad wound.
The available notices shows that the accident origin would be an accidental liberation of a wire hope who was fastened to one of trawl doors, who had violent strike the fisherman’s head. The diagnosis points to an immediately death.

On 13 January 2013, in the port of Huelva, Spain, Sichem Lily was undergoing a scheduled annual Cargo Ship Safety Equipment survey and inspection.
 
During the load-test of the rescue boat launching appliance, the three point lifting sling failed.  The boat fell in the sea.  There were no crew members on board.  The boat was eventually recovered and secured on board.
 
No injuries and / or pollution were reported.
 
Following the accident, the laboratory analysis after destructive and non-destructive testing of the three point lifting sling concluded that the material used for stitching the lifting sling splice had failed during the launching of the boat.  The tests further concluded that the stitching material had degraded along one side of the lifting sling for almost its entire length.  The weakening and eventual failure of the stitches was attributed to age, wear and tear, and exposure to Ultra Violet (UV) and the harsh elements of the sea.

On 07 January 2013, the Marine Safety Investigation Unit (MSIU) was notified of an accident that had taken place on board the Maltese registered Nin during an ocean voyage from Bahia Blanca to New Orleans.  The accident involved a brake failure on one of the lifeboat’s winches during a routine abandon ship drill. 

At 1055 of 06 January 2013, the master announced an abandon ship drill.  The weather was clear with a light to fresh breeze.  He decided to combine the drill with the weekly lifeboat inspection. This involved swinging the lifeboats out from their stowed position without crew.  The crew mustered at their designated boat stations.  First, lifeboat no. 2 (port side) was swung out and re- stowed.  Then, at 1118, lifeboat no. 1 (starboard side) was swung out by pulling the remote control brake handle on the boat deck.  When outboard and clear of the davits, the remote control brake handle was released to stop the movement.  However, the wire falls continued to run out.  Efforts to arrest the descent of the lifeboat by pushing down on the winch brake handle were unsuccessful. The downward movement continued until the lifeboat hit the sea.  At the time, the ship was underway making 11 knots. 

As a result of the impact, the lifeboat door opened and water started flooding inside.  The starboard lifeboat started to list.  In the meantime, the master slowed down the main engine.  Shortly afterwards, the forward on- load release gear opened and the painter parted.  The lifeboat held by the aft wire falls was pushed further away by the motion of the vessel.  A line from the aft mooring winch was passed and the lifeboat was hauled-in under the davits.  However, the pounding and pitching of the lifeboat caused the wire falls to slack, resulting in the release of the remaining on-load hook mechanism.  The lifeboat was now adrift and floating free. 

The vessel was turned around to recover the lifeboat.  After several attempts, the lifeboat was brought alongside and at 1405, it was finally hoisted up with the ship’s cargo cranes and secured on deck. 

The safety investigation identified poor condition of a ball bearing inside the winch as the immediate contributing factor to the uncontrolled descent of lifeboat no. 1 during the routine abandon ship drill at sea.
Fishermen were hauling down the gill nets when they noticed that the propeller was clogged. They tried to fix the problem but they couldn't. Finally the ship sank.

SOLASStatus: COS OTERO: Unknown/unspecified, NOVO JUNDIA: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents: SUMMARY During the tow manouver of the fishing vessel NOVO JUNDI A, the tug COS OTERO was hit into her port side by the bulb of NOVO JUNDI A. The tug flood and sunk after few minutes. No crew were onboard NOVO JUNDI A. CONCLUSIONS 1. The collision between the service boat COS OTERO and the F/V NOVO JUNDI A was caused by an excess of confidence on the part of the E/T COS OTERO skipper and by the lack of human and technical resources available to him to carry out the unhooking, towing and mooring manoeuvres of the fishing boat. 2. The CIAIM considers that the described service, which included undocking, towing and mooring manoeuvres of a vessel of the size of the aforementioned fishing vessel in the port of A Coru a, constituted a practice that involved risks, whose control should have not be left to the discretion of the participants in the activity, and should be regulated by the competent administrations.

THE RUSSIAN-FLAGGED GENERAL CARGO SHIP 'DANADI 1' CAUGHT FIRE IN CAPTAIN'S CABIN WHILST BERTHED AT YEYSK, RUSSIA AT 0630 HOURS LT ON 01/01/13. SUBSEQUENTLY REPAIRED AND RETURNED TO SERVICE.

FIRE FIGHTING ATTEMPTS BY CREW UNSUCCESSFUL. BLAZE SUBSEQUENTLY EXTINGUISHED WITH ASSISTANCE FROM LOCAL FIRE SERVICES. 1 CREW MEMBER DEAD. 2 OTHER PERSONS SUSTAINED SMOKE INHALATION INJURIES AND TAKEN TO LOCAL HOSPITAL. INVESTIGATION EFFECTED. EXTENT OF DAMAGE UNKNOWN. REPORTED CAUSE OF FIRE WAS ELECTRICAL SHORT CIRCUIT IN HEATING EQUIPMENT.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Ship remains fit to proceed

Location: 115 MILES WEST OF KRUTOGOROVA, KAMCHATKA, RUSSIA
InitialEvent: Hull failure / failure of watertight doors / ports, etc.
SummaryOfEvents:
SUSTAINED MAIN ENGINE FAILURE IN THE SEA OF OKHOTSK 115 MILES WEST OF KRUTOGOROVA, KAMCHATKA, RUSSIA IN LAT. 55 03N., LONG. 152 20E., AT 0130 HOURS LT ON 01/10/13. SUBSEQUENTLY SOLD FOR BREAKING UP.
FV 'ANASTASIYA' ATTENDED THE SCENE AS SAFETY VESSEL. TAKEN IN TOW OF FV 'K. EMERALDA' ON 01/10/13. TOW SUBSEQUENTLY TRANSFERRED TO FV 'BUZANSKIY' AND CONVOY ARRIVED AT PETROPAVLOVSK-KAMCHATSKY, RUSSIA ON 08/10/13 FOR INSPECTION.

Location: ATLANTIC OCEAN 75 MILES SOUTHWEST OF CAPE AGULHAS, SOUTH AFRICA
SummaryOfEvents:
THE SOUTH AFRICAN-FLAGGED STERN TRAWLER 'HARVEST GARDENIA' FOUNDERED IN THE ATLANTIC OCEAN 75 MILES SOUTHWEST OF CAPE AGULHAS, SOUTH AFRICA IN LAT. 35 18S., LONG. 018 48E., ON 01/01/13.

ALL CREW RESCUED BY NEARBY VESSELS. NO INJURIES REPORTED.
